description:
Came here with my parents and bf on July fourth. We were trying to go someplace else, but so many businesses were closed that day. Waited 20 minutes to get seated and an additional 40 minutes to get food. Pan fried buns were amazing and fried chicken was very good (different flavor than San Tung, but just as crispy, if not more!). Shanghainese noodles were good, but a little too flavorful. Lion's head was not quite what I'm used to, and the one dish we had that I wouldn't reorder. 

Overall, this is a legit shanghainese place with one lady running the show (takes orders, serves food, cleans tables, sets up tables). The pan fried dumplings are amazingly good, but you have to wait forever. Next time in in the area, I'm ordering it for takeout.
author: Stephanie C.

description:
The food was AMAZING to the point that I may have to say that it was the probably the best Chinese food I've had in SF in the 4 years I've lived here. 

HOWEVER, the service.... unwelcoming behavior and a 25 minute wait taking our order (clearing the tables was given higher priority when no one else was waiting to taking an order). It seemed  wa as if the lady wanted us to get frustrated and leave voluntarily.

Will I be going back? F$&@ yes, the spicy eggplant and the Shanghai Pan Fried Dumplings (dumplings that made me take a break from my vegetarianism) will def make me succumb to this place. 

UPDATE: So... we went back again... and the old lady for sure seems to have a racist bone. Same old grumpy face to the brown guy (me) while a nice smile to the caucasian customers. I thought, maybe I was overthinking but nope... when we asked for a box, she tossed two empty boxes on our table and walked away. When our Caucasian neighbors asked for boxes, she packed their food, put it in a bag and handed it to for them with a smile and a goodnight! 

Dang old lady, why'd you have to be so mean? I'm def going to miss your cooking!  ‍
author: Brij S.

description:
Prices listed here are bullshit; they are much higher. 
Chicken entree and one order of egg rolls; $17.75!
Mediocre food with a consistently burned taste. 
The place is a dive but has top tier prices. 
Prepare for long waits; both carry out and dine in take forever to get your food. 
Convenient location drives most of their business. 
No sense of urgency and they could care less about your feedback. 
No air conditioning or it's never on.
author: Bert V.

description:
It has been over 8 years since I last visited the Shanghai House and now I remember why.  The service was and continues to be horrible.  It is slow and unfriendly.  The food was mixed.  The kung pow chicken was good.  The wonton soup was very disappointing. Frozen dumplings are never a good thing and the soup was very greasy tasting.  The broccoli beef was okay - too sweet. 

Not recommended
author: J Z.

description:
One of my friends who lived in the area recommended this place. We had tried to go the other location down the street but it was closed.

My friend and I were told that the line can get pretty long sometimes forcing us to wait because the location itself was small. However, we lucked out and were seated right away.

Ordered the Shanghai steamed baby dumplings (Xiaolongbao) to share and I believe it was the Shanghai noodle special. The Xiaolongbao was the definitely the best thing about this place. I haven't had soup dumplings in so long so this was a nice refresher. The noodles were okay at best, but there were probably better options on the menu either way.

Overall, a great restaurant and will be looking to come back, but it is just a hike for me haha.
author: Timothy D.

description:
From sitting down to getting the first dish we ordered was 1 hour. Needless to say, that's a ridiculous amount of time to wait. We placed our order about 10 minutes after we sat down. If this restaurant has more than 2 parties, I suggest you stay far away unless you have 1+ hours to spare. 

The food was mediocre and not memorable. The pan fried hand pulled noodle was lacking in flavor. The xiao long nap had no soup. The potstickers were okay. The dry pan fried garlic string beans were good. The green onion pancake was too thick for my liking and too brown. It wasn't burnt but it was getting there. The chicken chow  mein was okay. 

I ordered the fried chicken but they forgot to write down that order so I never got it. That's a bummer because the table near us got it and it looked good.
author: Michelle T.

description:
Came here for the first time and found it to be a small cozy neighborhood Shanghai restaurant.  It seats about 26 people when full, so we came especially early at 5.30 pm and managed to get a table for 7 by joining two smaller tables. The lady who served us, seemed to be the only person taking orders and clearing the tables, so you have to be patient.  She looks like she could be the owner but not 100% sure.

We ordered the usual dishes such as drunken chicken, hot pepper tendons (too spicy for me) saute fish in egg whites (one my favorite dishes served with vinegar) roasted carp with green onions, fried vegetarian beancurd wrap, 8 precious rice pudding (not crispy enough) fried vegetarian beancurd and 2 orders of fried meat buns, which was excellent.  It was crispy on the bottom and the thickness of outside bread was thin and best eaten with dark vinegar. I was impressed that everything came piping hot and that's the way I like it.

I wish the menus weren't covered in spills, sauces and strange marks. So I they would clean up the menus by wiping them down.  Overall the restaurant is clean and the food is decent and served really hot which is a huge plus for me.  The owner was nice and efficiently managed to keep up with orders and cleanup by herself.  Would definitely return to get the pan fried pork buns again.
author: Elaine Y.

description:
I visit this place often when my lunch buddy crave for Shanghai food. This is my favorite place to get shen jiang bao! It's absolutely amazing with thin but fluffy skin and the broth inside - OMG. Other than that we would always order the dry fried chicken which is mildly sweet and spicy; definitely different from San Tung. XLB is pretty darn good too. I would also get the vegan duck which is soy paper wrap with mushroom and deep friend, delicious. 

Though food is great, service is run by a lady who is probably the owner as well. She's not the friendliness but pass for the service she provide. She made up the lost points on the food they provide. 

I am a returning customer year round!
author: Maria H.

description:
Hidden gem indeed. I got 4 dishes: xiao long bao, spicy dumplings in peanut sauce, green onion pancake and shanghai pan fried noodle. Except for green onion pancake which is meh, the rest are excellent. Their XLB is so good. Very juicy. Spicy dumpling in peanut sauce is amazing. Quite spicy so be careful. 
My standard for dumplings is high and I haven't seen any restaurants in SF that serve this great food at an affordable price. I love this places so much and will definitely come back.
author: Vy T.

description:
This is a small family owned restaurant where only one lady (the owner) seems to be taking the orders and handling the money, so be prepared for slow service and to wait a long time for the food. 

We got the Shanghai chow mein, fried chicken wings with garlic sauce, and xiao long baos. The xiao long baos were amazing with a soft outer skin and a juicy inside. The chow mein was average and the chicken wings were pretty crunchy and tasty, but it was on the dry side. And when it got cold, the fried skin and sauce hardened, making it less crispy.  

Would I come again? It would depend on how much time I had, because from getting the lady's attention to waiting for the food, I would have to prepare to spend at least an hour dining here.
author: Kristine P.

description: Mediocre food, the service was subpar, and it only accepts cash which they don't state anywhere before entering the restaurant.
author: Sydney N.

description: Family owned. I like that fact that a lot of these shops are not owned by big names and turned into franchises. Started coming here when it first opened. Customer service is not impeccable, it's ok. Food wise, i loved their Shang hai dumplings. The last time i visited was at the beginning of this month. Their food tasted different. It doesn't taste as fresh as it was before. Took forever for them to serve us as well...
author: Shaeli Z.

description:
Highly recommend if you have 2-3 hours to spare waiting for your food to come out.

Seated ourselves.
Grabbed our own menus.
Waaaaaited for our order to be taken.
Waaaaaaaaaaited for dishes to come.
Dishes came One. At. A. Time. (Rice was last.)
Gave up waiting for 2 dishes.

During this, 2 separate customers got pissed off waiting over an hour for their takeouts; a lot of yelling in the kitchen was heard; 3 tables got frustrated waiting for their tabs/change; and the RBF waitress only lit up when we went to her to pay our tab.

Salt & pepper spare ribs & spicy green beans were good. Won ton soup and combo chow mein were meh. Never got the dumplings.

Towards the end we sat laughing because it felt like a Seinfeld Soup Nazi experience.

You come to be punished.
author: M F.

description:
Other than a small shop, nothing is wrong with this place. The dry chicken was awesome, in my opinion it's better than Santung. Its crunchy with the perfect amount of sweet sticky garlicy sauce covering the delicious chicken. 
Well, return for the chicken for sure.
author: Paulie L.

description:
Zero star!  That's what this review should give, but Yelp is too generous and sets one star as the lowest rate.  But they really deserve zero star, and I'll tell you why.

Service:
How do I put this... the lady just didn't give a sh*t.  My friends and I arrived, sat down, and then lady just came to our table and literally slap the menu on our table.  After the food came, as we were eating, we noticed that the lady was on her phone the whole dang time at the cash register table, MEANWHILE approximately three tables were still full of dirty dishes left by the guests that had already gone for almost 20 mins!!!  I mean, come freakin on.  We were trying to eat here!  So at least you could try to keep the restaurant clean and tidy.  And it wasn't like you had other things to do!  And after we had our food, we had to ask for the check three times, yes THREE TIMES, before she finally brought it to us.  Uhhh, gurl, I know you hate your job, but we needed to get outta there.

Food:
Greasy greasy greasy.  I had 4 things actually.  3 didn't come looking appetizing so my asian instinct to take pictures of them just didn't kick in.  They were beef tripes in chili oil, pork and leek dumplings, and mushy pork.  Flavor was ok, but I could tell all the dishes were just low quality cooking.  Sorry but it's true.  The last thing we ordered was the dry fried chicken wings (I have a picture of this).  Omg, TERRIBLE.  The batter was waaaaaay too thick to the point I wasn't sure if I was eating the chicken or the batter.  And the sauce was...well, there was no sauce actually; instead, they're just soaked in chili oil!  Yes!!!  They fried the wings and probably decided they were not oily enough so they drenched the wings in a pool of chili oil.  OMG!  Nooooooooooooo..........

Rating:
It should really be zero star.  Oh, and it's a cash only place.
author: Kev H.

description:
Long story short:

Food - Decent. Not something I'd order outside of the xiao long bao

Atmosphere - Lifeless

Service - What service? Waited for a table for 20-25 minutes in a small restaurant? That's fine with me. Single server? Okay, I'll give her the benefit of the doubt. But 15-20 minutes to order? Okay..... Had to ask for tea, table wasn't set, food came out in increments of 20-25 minutes. 

Not coming back
author: Michael C.

description:
Wow.... The wings game just got real.

We came here just because we were in the vicinity and it looked like it was poppin'.

We got the xiao long baos, wings and green onion pancake. My least favorite was definitely the green onion pancake, however, it wasn't bad. The XLBs were pretty good and i would get them again. The wings were out of this world, in my opinion better than San Tung.

I wish i had room to order the honey walnut prawns and Shanghai noodles, because they looked amazing. 


These place is great, one of the best chinese restaurants in the area.
author: Josh Giosue D.

description:
No wait on a Sunday around noon, though there were a lot of people coming in and out and ordering items to go. First let's talk food.

Shanghai steamed baby dumplings ($8.50) - aka XLB, comes with 10. This was made very well - the skin was nice and thin but strong enough to be transferred onto my spoon without breaking and letting the soup escape. The meat was soft and moist and the soup was great. I found a hair in one of them (ew, but this happens often enough in Chinese restaurants that I'm not even that fazed anymore), and the waitress apologized and quickly brought us a new batch.
Shanghai pan fried dumplings ($11.95) - comes with 8. This came out looking delicious with nicely browned bottoms. The outside was slightly crispy and the meat inside was soft and juicy. Done really well and in a great size, too!
Savory rice roll ($4.25) - perhaps the smallest rice roll I have ever been served at a restaurant. This meant that there wasn't so much filling, although the actual ratio of filling to rice was good. I personally would have preferred more pork floss inside, but it still tasted good. Only problem was the portion.
Cucumber & bean thread sheet ($9.95) - not bad but expensive for $10. I would have liked less peanut sauce. I took a bite of the leftovers the very next day, and it had a terrible mushy consistency, so definitely finish this the day of if you're going to order it.
Dry fried chicken wings (did not see item on menu) - definitely a disappointment. The basil on top was black and in a clump, which did not look appetizing. The outside was way too hard and crunchy with a thick layer of batter. The sauce itself was decent, but doesn't even hold a candle to San Tung.

Service was not good. When we were waiting to order, the lady was just standing behind the counter, where there is a big plant in the way. Not sure if she just couldn't see us or was taking a break, but I saw a customer from another table walk up to put in her order because she had been waiting for a while already. That same lady at the counter yelled into the kitchen so loudly once that a little girl sitting a few tables over said, "It's so loud!" hahaha. Two of our items came out separately with the servers not knowing which table they were for - there aren't that many tables in there! When they were confused and looking around, we had to tell them that the dishes were ours. When the waitress took away my soup spoon with the hair in the dumpling, she didn't give me a new spoon until I asked. And finally, we sat next to the door and it didn't close properly so the draft was blowing at us each time someone walked in or out. I am fully aware that some of these things are nitpicky, but when combined with hair in my dumpling, subpar service, and only okay food, this makes for an overall unsatisfactory meal that deserves a rating of "Meh. I've experienced better."

Also, what's with using saucers as plates??
author: Nicole M.

description: Great food. Don't come here expecting 5 Star bourgeoisie service. Juicy xlb. And a new twist for me on xlb...fried bottoms...still juicy! Great flavors. Spicy wonton are not too hot but full of flavor.
author: Charles P.

description:
I recommend the spicy peanut wontons, cucumber and bean curd noodles and of course the best Shen jiang bao and soup dumplings I have had in the Bay Area. 

We came at 5:45 PM and were seated right away.
author: Jennifer S.

description:
The wait can be long and the service is the bare minimum, but the food is awesome!

This is my second time here and both times I've had good experiences. The first time around I remember I had to wait a bit to be seated, but this time my party and I got seated immediately. The same individual (I assume is the owner) took our orders. Both times, this individual did not show much emotions or expressions, she just took our orders, refilled our tea pot from time to time, and that was about it. Food was delivered directly by the chefs.

We ordered:

- Xiaolongbao (soup dumplings)
- Stir-Fried Shanghai Noodles
- Dry Chicken Wings
- Pan Fried Dumpling
- Pan Fried Potstickers

Food was delicious! The Xiaolongbao had a thin exterior that held the soup fairly well and had a juicy filling. The Pan Fried Dumplings and the Pan Fried Potstickers had a nice crispy, yet chewy exterior. Both of the fillings were tasty, as well. Out of the three, my favorite was the Pan Fried Dumplings. The Stir-Fried Shanghai Noodles were okay, nothing really made it stand out though. Lastly, the Dry Chicken Wings were excellent! Some say it's comparable to San Tung's wings, but honestly they're incomparable. It's not horrible, it's just different in looks and taste, so one cannot simply compare the two. The wings here have a nice crunch to them with a sweet caramelized sugar glazing. Not to mention, the size of the wings are generous.

Overall, a great Shanghainese restaurant on Balboa. Parking can be a hassle in the area and the service isn't particularly outstanding, but food definitely hits the spot!

PS: All photos were taken by the bf since I was too busy eating (he takes better photos than me anyway).
author: Julia L.

description:
Really liked the sheng jian bao here! I would definitely come back to order them again. We also ordered Mushu Pork (comes with 4 pancakes) and a House Special Shrimp entree (spicy), which both were not bad.

Though the food was good, the service was pretty bad. There is only 1 waitress, and she does not seem to care that much about the customers. You have to call her multiple times to get her attention for anything: getting seated, ordering food, getting more water, getting the check, etc. There also is no proper wait list. The waitress just tells people to wait outside.
author: Celena C.

description: You're in for the best fried baos, very good soup dumplings, and gigantic fried chicken wings. A day after eating here for the first time, I couldn't stop thinking about the baos and wings! If you dine here, come early or be prepared to wait for a table. There isn't a lot of seating inside.
author: Deborah L.

description:
Craving xiao long bao without a trip to New York or Shanghai in your immediate future? Look no further than this no frills hole-in-the-wall in a bustling area of Balboa. There might be a few naysayers who swear by Shanghai Dumpling King a few blocks away, Kingdom of Dumpling over on Taraval, or even Yank Sing across town (bless their souls...). Think twice before you try to convince them that Shanghai House is better because it'll be a win-win situation for everyone -- they'll continue to believe what they want to believe and you'll keep your wait times at Shanghai House down because this place is tiny.

I can only speak to the weekday lunch or weekend brunch at Shanghai House, the latter of which I would recommend if you've started to feel a bit jaded about San Francisco's pricey and occasionally over-the-top brunch scene. This is one of the few places in the city, if not the only, where you can enjoy an authentic Shanghainese breakfast. Start off with a bowl of savory doujiang (soy milk) and drink in the subtle flavors of the pickled radishes and floating youtiao. And speaking of youtiao, don't sleep on a side order of them. Who needs millionaire's bacon when you can have fried dough?! And in case you wanted more carbs (who doesn't?), order a savory rice roll, which is kind of like an uncut sushi roll without seaweed, filled with rousong (dried pork with a cotton candy texture) and more youtiao. Follow that up with an order of scallion pancakes, which are delicious without being too greasy.

Now, onto the main dishes. You clearly came here for the xiao long bao and they certainly do not disappoint. The thickness of the dumpling skin can critically affect the tastiness of the xiao long bao: too thick and it'll absorb all of the soup. Shanghai House consistently hits the nail on the head with their soup dumplings. I'm also a big fan of their shengjian bao, which is like the xiao long bao's crispier cousin. And I hope you didn't plan on eating for the rest of the day, because you can't miss out on the chicken wings or the nian gao. I daresay that the chicken wings here are better than the ones at San Tung because I don't have to worry about the sticky honey glaze eating away at my enamel.
author: Amy C.

description: Terrible service. We had a small complaint that one dish was burnt (which it was), and the server lady kept insisting that it wasn't and that I was being stupid.  Extremely rude. The other dishes were just okay, nothing worth coming back for. Overall a terrible experience.
author: C H.

description:
Best sheng jian bao I've found so far in the city. Great texture and flavor but no soup inside.

The wait can be long even for one order of sheng jian bao (20-25 mins).
author: Hao H.

description: This is the best Chinese food in the city. Get the dry fried chicken, the green beans, and the soup dumplings. The decor is minimal and the service is a one-woman show, but the place is clean and everything tastes like magic.
author: Bethany H.

description:
I've been to Shanghai House various times now and the experience ranged from pretty good to just a-ok. I'm settling with the latter for now: decent Shanghainese food that definitely hits the spot when you're looking for a greasy-spoon experience. It's tasty and the portions are plenty. It's also not too expensive...but overall I'm missing the wow factor.

Oh and the service is terrible: the same lady always runs the show and she couldn't be more non-caring. I know this is a hole-in-the-wall kind of place and you oughtn't expect good service, but just know that I will have an uninterested serving staff, refrains me from coming here anytime again soon.
author: Uli B.

description:
Only reason this place is getting a 4 stars is for the food. The service, on the other hand, could be better. For such a small restaurant, I felt like it was so difficult to get the attention of anyone. Once you walk in, you're seated almost immediately, but after that, it's like they completely forget about you. The workers are completely unaware of their surroundings and don't check up on their customers often enough. 

We ordered their xiao long baos and their dry fried chicken wings. The wings are HUGE, but you can definitely tell that most of it is the breading. The sauce is good and similar to the one at San Tung's, but not quite. The xiao long baos though... they were probably the best ones I've had in the area! They were perfect.

It's funny how we ended up here. We were supposed to try out Shanghai Dumpling King a block down, but we accidentally went in here, and when we realized it, it was too late, they already served us tea/water, lol! But I'm glad we stayed. 

I would definitely come again. Hopefully their service improves! It's cash only btw.
author: Sydney C.

description: Just like what most other reviewers said, the service is horrible. We waited 1 hour for the dry fried chicken wings, the lady who waited on us had no expression on her face, and she was on her phone when we tried to flag her down. The food on the other hand was pretty good. Would definitely recommend the green onion pancakes, Xiao Long Baos, and the dry fried chicken. The shanghai pan fried noodles were below average. Overall, if you came here for the dry fried chicken, just stick to san tungs.
author: Charles S.

description:
Bottom line: Tasty Chinese food at a reasonable price.

Context: Friend and I visited for lunch around noon on a Sunday.

Environment: Small space seats around 25 people, but didn't feel cramped.

Service: Seated immediately. Food came out as ready. Otherwise it was difficult to flag people down.

Food: We found it satisfying.  Two people split three dishes.  Including tax and tip, the overall bill was under $30.

Tea was pleasantly floral.  The temperature was enough to warm the teacup in your hands, but not too hot to drink.

Green onion pancake - thicker and more onion-y than I am used to, but I liked it.  Nice browning on the outside.

Shanghai style pan fried noodles hit the spot.

The pork soup dumplings (also called xiao long bao or xlb) were tasty.
author: Elizabeth C.

description:
Shanghai House is the best place in San Francisco to get affordable XLB. A staple in the outer Richmond. 

This tiny, hole-in-the-wall restaurant is intimate and can get very busy and full in a matter of minutes. It's worth the wait. Don't be offended by the lady - she is a hard working woman and the only server. As a 20 year customer I recommend: 

Green onion pancake 
XLB 
Sautéed string beans 
Dry fried chicken wings 
Hot and sour soup 
Wonton soup 

If you come for lunch, you can't go wrong getting a lunch special.

If you're a wing lover then you'll absolutely LOVE the dried fried chicken wings! 

Closed on Tuesdays like all the OG restaurants 
CASH ONLY
author: Shannon M.

description:
Exceptional chicken wings and amazing Shanghai dumplings.   The food is really fresh and well made and the prices are very reasonable.

The waitress on the weekend is always very dour.  We come a lot and I have never seen her smile ONCE.

The place is really small, so be prepared to wait for a table (outside- dress warmly!)

Parking in this neighborhood can be a real bad bummer.

There is only one bathroom, which is up a really windy and narrow staircase.  I cannot, for the LIFE of me, figure out how they have not been busted for a violation of the ADA.  If you (or your dining companions) have mobility challenges, I would not go.
author: Gary A.

description: It has been a while since we have been out here.  Dried chicken wings are still great although I am not a big fan of the rice and vegetables that come with it.  Do not rely on the lunch price as seen on yelp.  Shanghai House does not have a website. I know restaurants add stuff in like tax but you will not be paying $4.99.  You will be paying $10.40 plus tip.  I expected to be paying more, just not double.  One other thing, I made the mistake once of over ordering so that I could have an extra treat a day later.  Dried chicken wings are best eaten soon after you get them. And as is typical sometimes it is hard to be sure that we are understanding each other when speaking to someone where English is their second language. To me, calling in an order to save time seems to exacerbate the communication problem. Take bus 38 and walk a couple of blocks or bus 31 runs less frequently but stops a block away.
author: Vickie B.

description: Only 1 waiter and she treats customers like ...totally ruined my day! Would never come back again. Btw they only takes cash, no venmo no paypal no anything
author: Phili W.

description:
This Shanghainese restaurant has a very small exterior, which can be hard to find. They are in direct competition with "Shanghai Dumpling King", which is just a couple blocks down the same street.  They are not nearly as busy nor as crowded, but they do closed every day after the lunch hours between 3:30pm to 5pm. 

"Shanghai House's" interior is extremely small with just a handful of tables, so they too can get crowded with a long wait time during their busy hours.  I found out that the best time to dine here is right after 5pm, once they're open for the dinner hours. 

Parking on Balboa St. is metered and can be difficult to find. The parking meters are operational from Monday-Saturday at 9am-6pm. There's a 2-hour parking limit and it's at $2.25/hr, as of January 2017.

FYI.., their restroom is NOT user-friendly for the elderly or someone that has difficulty walking.  In order to use their unisex bathroom, you have to walk upstairs and through their kitchen. Their stairways are also very narrow too. 

If you're a fan of boba milk tea, there is a "Purple Kow" right across the street from "Shanghai House", which is very convenient to go to right after a meal here. 

I personally like the overall food at "Shanghai House" more than "Shanghai Dumpling King", but just a little bit more. FYI, they do not accept credit cards, as they're CASH ONLY!
author: Johnny W.

description:
Immediately upon walking into the restaurant, I could see why this place was rated so poorly.  There was a grim and uninviting air to the place that was difficult to ignore.  The waitress was not rude but, instead, had a haggard, defeated demeanor that screamed "life sucks and so do you."   She shuffled slowly from customer to customer, looking as if she would rather be anywhere than where she was and not seeming to care whether a customer was happy or sad, pleased or displeased.  I can't explain the service better than that but it did subconsciously dampen the pleasure of the experience. 

I helped myself to a menu and looked it over, confused as to why none of the items that other Yelpers raved about were not on the menu.  The waitress saw me looking back and forth in confusion between the Yelp review on my cellphone and the menu in my hand and simply said "two menus" as she handed me a different menu that I had not noticed before.  

I ordered the dry fried chicken wings and the pork dumplings.   She shuffled to the kitchen with my order.  A gloomy, dark cloud loomed over her head, making Eeyore's look like rainbows and sunshine.   

Getting the food took awhile but was definitely worth the wait.   The meal came out piping hot so I'm certain that the delay was just the cooking time and was no fault of the waitress.  

The dry fried chicken wings and pork dumplings (xiao long bao) were great.  The chicken was coated in a spicy honey glaze that crystallized the chicken skin into a heavenly, decadent candy shell that stayed crisp even when reheated and eaten the next day.  The dumplings were fresh, tasty and juicy.  The tender skin encapsulated a delicious broth that pleased the senses.  So delicious!Compliments to the chef! 

Given how delicious the food was, I can NOT give this restaurant any lower than a 4 star rating despite the bad vibe.  I highly recommend trying the dumplings and the chicken TO GO so that you can truly enjoy the meal!   And please, be kind to the waitress.  I don't know what caused the doom and gloom but let's just pretend we're Care Bears here and spread the love to someone in need.
author: Linda H.

description:
Food = great.

Green onion pancake = A bit crispy, a bit doughy and quite delicious. $5.95.

Xiao long bao = juicy dumplings with great filling. Ginger heaven. Best to eat them when they land on the table. Piping hot. $8.50.

San jian bao = awesome. Crispy dough and juicy filling. It doesn't run like the XLB but it's quite good, too. $11.95

Hot & sour soup = good.  It's his go-to dish. He liked it. $9.25. (Regular size, they have a small one as well.) 

Shanghai noodles = okay. The flavors were good but the noodles were a bit undercooked. $9.25.

Dry sauteed string beans = awesome. A bit spicy, tangy and sweet. The pickled vegetables were a great addition. Well cooked beans. (I loathe undercooked beans that are squeaky as a result.) $9.50

Service = okay. Basically one person takes the orders, answer the phone, and serves the food.  (More people in the kitchen than in dining area.) Chinese & ESL.  You were warned about the service and ESL.  

Prices = reasonable to moderate. Dinner for 3 came out to $59.15 with leftovers.

Seating = about six 4-tops (might seat 5-6 if you find the chairs) and a few 2-tops. 

This place gets busy. There's a wait list...I guess. We waited around 30 minutes for a table on a Friday evening.   

We'll be back for those sticky spicy wings...saw it on other tables, but our table & bellies were full.
author: Fannie S.

description: Let me start by saying this is my first yelp review i have ever written. The food (especially the xiao long bao) was good, definitely up to par with the reviews that it gets. The service, however, was horrendous. My friends and i received hints of utensils every 10 minutes and that's only if we asked for it. Our server, an older Chinese woman, was extremely unenthusiastic, dragged her feet around as she slowly brought things ovand didn't come check on us once the entire hour and a half we were there. Simply put, come here once to try the xiao long bao and never come again.
author: Chris C.

description: Small place so there's only one waiter (long waits) but the food is delicious. Definitely recommend the more traditional dishes, like Xiao Long Bao, over dishes like broccoli beef. Pro tip: use the Chinese menu, it's way better.
author: Christopher L.

description:
Bad bad bad.....give them another try today with a to-go order of 2 Xian Lun Bao. I was hoping to-go order would be faster. The boss lady did not even confirm the order, she hung up without telling me how long it would take, how much. Showed up at the store 15-20 mins later, still needed another 5 mins.

Paid, went home and realized she had 2 orders of fried chicken wings instead. 

Bad bad bad service!!! Can't expect much frim this place if you can't even get my order right!
author: Elm E.

description:
I love Shanghai House! I have been going there for awhile, thanks to a friend recommendation. But first things first: get there early! Because that place gets packed! Make sure to check in with the waiter! The food to try are pork dumplings  and the spicy fried chicken. it's a must if it is your first time there! 
 The food is excellent, but the only bad part is the service. During a couple of visits, I noticed there's really just one waiter for the whole restaurant and a helper to deliver the food with minimal English. The waiter is a bit slow and sometimes have an attitude problem. And once and awhile, she would not be considerate of the customer. Last time I was there, I was not given a tea pot for my tea and to get her attention, I had to wave my hand in the air. Another downside is that you have to pay the bill in cash so bad luck if you have only a credit card. 
But overall don't let the downside deter you, the food is awesome, a real SF gem, just get ready for the somewhat bad service.
author: Sebastian F.

description:
Despite warnings about the draconic service, we decided to try this place and managed to get a table at around 7 pm. Five minutes later, the forewarned waitress arrives with menus and the "esteemed" resting b*tch face. The lack of organization in service reminded me of the movie Matilda with Miss Trunchbull - the kitchen chefs (or staff) were so sweet and helpful while the waitress disappeared into the kitchen. 

The food was pretty delicious. We had the Dry Chicken Wings, Mushu Pork, and Pan Fried Dumplings. The coating on the chicken is like a hard caramel strengthened by corn starch and the sauce is heavily thickened with honey (do not get this on your clothes!). The mushu pork dish consisted mainly of onions and eaten together with the bread wrap and sauce was pretty tasty.  The pan fried dumplings were also good - the skin on the bottoms nicely browned and crisp. Not overly generous with the filling (I'd say about 40%) but the inside is moist and flavorful. All leftovers tasted great the next day even reheated. 

On the fence about coming back because having to deal with attitude is kind of a pain when trying to enjoy good food but she kind of softened up by the end of service. Let's not forget that she did give us side-eye at the beginning but stopped after  because I was scrolling through the one-star reviews on the table to her face as we were ordering. Overall, what an experience. For Zagat to review this place so highly and comment so little on the service says a lot about how people view restaurant reviews, doesn't it?
author: Austin L.

description:
Holy mackerel, they should really think about investing in a boombox or radio for the  customers to listen to if they're gonna have World War 3 in the kitchen. 

Shanghai House is your typical shanghainese restaurant. Nothing too special but definitely less packed than Shanghai Dumpling King which is a block away from here. The grandma loves their xiao long bao so we came here for a late lunch on Friday. 

With only three other tables, service for us was efficient and prompt. Maybe cause we sat at the two seater table right next to the register and in front of the kitchen door so we literally ordered from the boss lady as she was doing stuff from the register. 

The food came out in a timely manner. First was the two orders of pork xiao long bao. They were hot, juicy, and flavorful. Not bad. The grandma and I killed one order each. Next came the shanghai cho chow mien. I ALWAYS get this dish at every shanghainese restaurant because I love the thickness of the noodle and how great it taste. But to my disappointment, the cho chow mien here was VERY bland and tasteless. sigh...

Throughout our meal, the grandma and I were interrupted occasionally by the noise coming from behind; the kitchen. The boss lady and the staff were arguing pretty loudly in mandarin. The way they were arguing was kinda scary and very unpleasant.... Needless to say, I'm gonna introduce my grandma to Shanghai Dumpling King next time..
author: Anissa D.

description:
By a stroke of bad luck, we ended up having to wait over an hour for a table. Another factor is how cramped the interior of the restaurant is. It really can't be more than 10 x 20 feet, with around 10 small tables for seating.

I had really high hopes for the food, but a lot of the dishes disappointed. The Shanghai soup dumplings were decent, but definitely not worth waiting an hour for. The stir-fried shanghai rice cakes was pretty poorly done and came out lukewarm. The two best things we had were the fried chicken wings, which tastes very similar, but not as good as, to San Tung chicken if you've had those, and the pan-fried buns which have a soupy interior but a deliciously crispy exterior.

Overall, wouldn't say this place is worth waiting for, so come near the end of lunchtime to avoid the lines.
author: Anderson H.

description: Seems it was just a one day close.  Just picked up my to go order. Yummy chicken wings!
author: Janet Y.

description:
We came here with a friend because she loves Xiao long bao (soup dumplings) and said the fried chicken here was tasty.  She also added she comes here for the food only, as the service can be pretty spotty and rude!

It's a small place but thankfully we didn't have to wait.  We got an order of xiao long bao, the green onion pancake, the deep fried chicken wings, and the Shanghai stir fried rice cake.  I have to say that all the dishes were pretty good but nothing was screaming spectacular at me.  We especially like the stir fried rice cake and the xiao long bao were good, but I prefer the wings at San Tung better.  Good place to go if we're in the area.
author: Jeff C.

description: True Shanghainese food for the win. The spicy wonton with peanut sauce was so good that we ordered two dishes. The Xiao Long Bao is a must and the Stir-Fried Shanghai Rice Cakes was also a great noodle dish. The Fried Chicken Wings were also delicious! Come with a group so you can share and you'll definitely leave feeling satisfied and full.
author: Grace L.

description:
Overall Rating: 3.5/5 

Food: 4/5 
After going to several Shanghai restaurants, this location serves the best shanghai restaurants. I would highly recommend 
- Shanghai Dumplings (Xiao Long Bao) : The skin is nice and thin while the meat inside is juicy and flavorful
- Green Onion Pancakes : Not too oily and has a nice crunch and flavor to it
- Pan Fried Buns (Sheng Jian Bao) [pictured] : Definitely one of my favorite dishes. The presentation, taste, and texture is ON POINT. It's like a 2.0 version of the shanghai dumplings. However, it can sometimes be a bit oily but that's what makes it good. 
-Shanghai Cu Chow Mein (Stir-Fry) : This dish is my favorite noodle dish by far. Nice flavor and love the thick noodles.

Service: 2/5
Since they mainly have one waitress, the service is really slow. It usually takes 40 minutes until the food begins to arrive. There also isn't much space and somewhat cramped since the restaurant is really small. 

Overall, the food is great and affordable but the service and wait is often terrible.
author: Rachel C.

description: I have order the pan fried dumplings and it was so good. The Chicken wings is a must try. (Its my favorite in SF!)
author: Jess T.

description: Really enjoyed the spicy wonton and the dumplings. The pork filling was amazing. The spicy wonton wasn't too oily,had the most flavors out of all the dishes I tried because there was this delicious peanut sauce underneath in the sauce. Definitely my favorite dish there. :)
author: Vy D.

description:
Decent food (except the steamed dumpling!) but overall average experience.

I could see this as a popular local spot, but wouldn't come out of my way to return! BUT - I will say, their potstickers are pretty bomb. They are plump and the skin outside is not too doughy, and perfectly browned & crisped.

Service: Standard, for a typical Chinese restaurant. No smiles here!
Ambiance: Looks & feels like a hole in the wall spot.
Food: Overall about 3.5 stars. 

BREAKDOWN:
Dumplings - 2 stars. Too doughy and not enough filling.
Potstickers - 4 stars!
Noodle dish with meat (Forgot what it was on the menu, lol, but it was near the Tan Tan noodles) - 3.5 stars - felt like the noodles were home-made - or just really fresh! Silky and bouncy, and the sauce that accompanied it was pretty good too!

If I were to return, I'd like to try the chicken wings! The portions looked hefty and it looks like it's twice fried.. which means probably delicious.
author: Emily C.

description:
Dumplings (4/5): they were pretty good, but nothing different that what I've had elsewhere.

Shredded Jellyfish (1/5): I was expecting it to be like the typical Chinese jellyfish dish, but it wasn't and it just tasted gross and vinegary.

Chicken Wings (2/5): I heard they were comparable to San Tung's wings, but no way. These were overly sweet.

Noodles (2/5): just greasy and didn't have much flavor. We ordered the green onion pancake but they gave this to us instead by mistake, we were too lazy to correct them.

Overall I would just come here for the dumplings only.
author: Cheyne T.

description: I wasn't a fan of this place before when the chicken was too crispy. But whatever they did, they definitely brought back the good times. Special thanks to the staff! They work very hard, considering the working conditions if you manage to find your way to the restroom upon a flight of stairs.
author: John C.

description:
Average Jiangnan (Southern China). Good for a change of taste in SF! 

I am a Suzhou-native (a city close by Shanghai) and our food is very similar to Shanghai-nese food. Although the food here do resemble the mildly-spiced dishes from Jiangnan, the taste is still not quite as delicate as what I remember from back home. Everything tasted very similar, and some dishes were overly sweetened. 

[FOOD]
- EIGHT TREASURER SOUP [4/5]: I've never had this dish back home. It's a little bit spicy and has a lot of goodies inside, as suggested by its name. The noodles on the bottom was very fulfilling with the peanuts, preserved tofu, and the other small bites. 

- PAN FRIED DUMPINGS [2/5]: This is one of my favorite breakfast food back home and was so looking forward to eating it. The skin was pretty good - a little thinner than I liked. But the filling was extremely gooey - we were wondering if it was even cooked or not. I think they mixed a bit too much flour with the meat. 

- RICE CAKE W/ SHREDDED PORK/ & VEGGIE [3/5]: This is one of my favorite dishes back home, but I was disappointed by how few rice cake there was. The flavor was also very similar to the Shanghai cu chow. 

- DRY FRIED FILLET [3/5]: Fillet coated with flour and fried. It is served very sweet sauce that almost resemble maple syrup. 

- SHANGHAI CU CHOW [3/5]: I liked the thick noodle. If you are looking for a dish that will fill up your stomach, this will be a good pick. 

[SERVICE/SETTING]
The place is owned by Shanghai-natives and it's not a big place - there are 5-6 tables inside. Street parking is available in the neighborhood. 

Overall it's not a bad place to grab some non-dim sum Chinese food. I have a high standard for Jiangnan food since I grew up eating them, so I wouldn't say this is authentic Shanghai food.
author: Wendy F.

description:
Confused this place with Shanghai Dumpling King up the block, since they're 3 blocks away from each other, serve similar food, and have a similar name. Go figure.

Food:  4 stars
My grandparents say they have come here several times in the past, and I trust their judgment in Chinese food. For the 3 of us, we ordered XLB (comes with 10), shanghai noodles, and the shredded pork + cabbage with rice cakes. The food was pretty damn good actually! I would return for the food itself. The XLB had good soup, the pork was tasty, the shanghai noodles were chewy and saucy and wonderful, and I loved the chewiness of the rice cakes too. All were great. Can't say either were the best I ever had, but this was a great way to end a Shanghainese food craving!

Service:
I came here on a Wednesday for lunch with my grandparents. Got here around 12pm, and sat down immediately. Our plates weren't ready though, and neither was a menu handed to us when we sat down. Not only that, the owner was talking to someone outside for the longest time (at least 7 minutes). It looked like she was taking a to-go order, but it also looked like they were talking about a deep family issue. It was super frustrating, since the owner/waitress was the only waitress in the house. We didn't get a menu for about 10 minutes! The food did come out fairly quickly though, considering we ordered 3 plates and there were plenty of other tables in the restaurant. It took forever to get the bill though. We were waiting to get change back, and my grandparents and I were so frustrated, that we just gave exact change, and left. Ughs!

I guess I'd do to-go for this place, except for the XLB. It's just so frustrating the service sucks so much.
author: Jocelyn L.

description:
Don't get me wrong, the food at Shanghai House is exceptional and I do feel bad giving a three star review, but everything else about the experience is mediocre at best. 

Let's start with the positives: arrived on a Friday evening around 7 with four friends and got sat immediately. We ordered a ton of food and EVERYTHING was fantastic. Service was pretty quick and the server was pretty responsive. Highlights include:
- Green onion pancakes: great texture and not too greasy
- Shanghai dumplings: honestly some of the best dumplings I've ever had - so juicy!
- Dry fried chicken wings: fantastic sauce, wanted to put it on everything else
- Mu-shu pork: great dish to share
- Hand cut noodles: my favorite dish - incredible noodles!

The not-so-great:
- We realized that we were given two completely different menus, so make sure that you get both menus to ensure you're seeing all of your options
- Cash only! Normally not a problem when I'm just picking up something for myself but for a large group it's a bit of a hassle
- Staff relatively unfriendly/aloof
- State of dining area could certainly use some upgrades/deep cleaning. Don't even get me STARTED on the state of their bathroom.
- Pretty far out there in the Richmond; it's definitely a trek to get over there from the other side of town

All in all, super glad I got to experience their food, but there are a ton of good places in the Chinatown area that would hit the spot and save me a ton of travel time.
author: Regina L.

description:
+ food is decent

- waitress is rude and disorganized; ruins everything about this restaurant
author: Steve T.

description:
Been here many times but will not recommend this place unless they change their waitress.

Food is good but the service is terrible. The waitress is rude and very unorganized. You can be first seated but last to get your food. She does not write down your name for wait list.

Do not call in to order food. They will not start your order until you go to restaurant and pay them. So what's the point....
author: Gina L.

description: Very good Xao Long Bao steamed and fried. Tea Infused Duck was super tasty. Tofu Sheets and Soy Bean was fresh and flavorful. The portions are large. Small restaurant, about 8 small tables. Cash only.
author: R S.

description:
Hidden among the foggy depths of the outer Richmond a small Chinese restaurant across the Balboa theater shyly sits.

It's a tiny place. And maybe three people work there at a time max. It's clearly a family run operation, and while the service could be better, and they could maybe hire another person on shift, it is worth it. You get a taste of some of the best Chinese food you can get for the price in this oh so competitive city. The dry wings, xlb, clay pots, and everything are amazing. Make sure you get in early while you don't have to wait long.
author: Griffin S.

description: Firstly I am from shanghai and I am so sad that Bay Area has a such bad shanghai restaurant like this.If I can give 0 I will absolutely do. This restaurant is a robbery. I never seen a shanghainese restaurant selling the food in this ridiculous price and the server is absolutely slow and bad. My wife and I have been waiting for our food for over 45 mins even though there were only 2-3 tables in server.  We were never served for add teas or sth. However! When the check given to us. I checked carefully that the waitress automatically added 15% tip at the end. Omg this is a cash only(tax cheating) restaurant and very poor environment and service. How come she added 15% tip on our check? And when we got our change, she gave us plenty of 1-dollar, did she suppose we didn't look at the check and give her double tip? What a cheating restaurant. Plz don't never go there! 华人上海人千万别去 垃圾老板娘服务差菜贵还骗消费！
author: Jack C.

description: Following the advice of Yelp legend, Tian Q., I sought out Shanghai House for my Xaio Long Bao fix. In spite of a stupid parking ticket, I still enjoyed my lunch. The XLB were not as good as Din Tai Fung but satisfying nonetheless. The dry fried chicken wings were amazing, probably the best I have ever had. Pan fried buns had a nice crispy exterior but just a pork meatball inside. A veggie version would have been better for me. Staff were great and prices were OK. Make sure you make the trek to the bathroom, as it takes you though the kitchen so you can see the chef at work.
author: Jeremy R.

description: As someone who is always on the lookout for good dumplings, I really enjoyed the Shanghai pan fried dunplings.  The bottom of the dunplings were fried just the right amount (not too burnt or under fried) and the seasoning was great.  For dinner I ordered those Shanghai dumplings and the pork steamed dumplings, which were also made well.  I usually don't like the smell of food in my car, but I will enjoy this smell on my drive home. Whenever I'm in this area and craving dumplings or Shanghainese food, I will make this place my default.
author: John L.

description: I'm visiting from Dallas and had a crave for good Chinese food. They served amazing dumplings (pan fried and soup) and green onion pancakes were delicious! CASH ONLY!!!
author: Rebeca K.

description: Service sucks but man those pan fried dumplings. I'll drive through traffic across the peninsula for those damned things. Don't skip out on the chicken wings either.
author: Mareesoul E.

description: My family comes here for the dry chicken wings. Food is delicious. Some dishes are overly salty... too much msg? The service isn't the greatest but the food makes up for it. Depending on the day and time you come... sometimes there's wait because there's only a handful of tables.
author: Karina L.

description: Food is great. Price is even better. The service is a bit lacking, but it is a very small Resturant. I recommend the Shanghai dumplings and the Shanghai Rice Cake. Waiting for food was a bit long, but worth the wait in the end .
author: Erin M.

description: We waited 30 minutes just to find out there were no more soup dumplings. Service was brash and in accommodating. Pretty hard to understand how it was so difficult to keep us updated with the lack of a popular item. Definitely would not come back here again nor do I recommend the wait.
author: Mark Z.

description:
Took my girlfriends here on the recommendation of my son.  Horrible experience.  Here's the deal: if you don't want Caucasian people in your restaurant then you should put a sign on the door!  The service was absolutely horrible!  We saw another non Asian couple there who were having the same bad experience. 


We came in, no welcome, nothing.  Another table emptied so we took it. Then waited another 10 minutes for them to clean the table.  Waited and waited again for the menus.  Then they bring tea that was lukewarm at best.  One of the servers is wearing an apron that clearly had not been washed in weeks. Disgusting.  The waitress finally shows up to take our order just as we were getting ready to leave. She was downright rude.  

My girlfriend asks for a fork - we had to ask 3 more times to get it.  We order 2 Diet Cokes (don't judge !) and they bring 1.  The dumplings were gummy and tasteless.  

At the end they did not offer a box for the leftovers (which I would not want anyway).  Overall place was not very clean either.  

There are plenty of other great dim sum places in SF that will get my money. This place stinks.
author: Debi S.

description:
The food is overrated. Some dishes are too salty and the oil used were old. The service was slow bc there was only one waiting staff, which explains why she was so cranky. The table next to ours who were there before us gave her a code name, "mean lady," and the other guests nodded and laughed. I first thought it was a joke, but little did I know.

We ordered a total of six items, all with disappointment. I felt cheated when I'd ordered the ham hock ($28.95)and Chinese donut ($3.50). The ham hock was soggy with grease and tasted like the worst case of salted meat. The fried green used to garnish the ham (possibly seaweed) was over seasoned with MSG! I saw small globs and clumps of it. The Chinese donut was over fried (hard as brick throughout) and oozing dark smelly old oil. These two items are disgusting and way over priced.
author: Boune T.

description: Love this place.  Xiao long bao rock !!!  Pig knuckle , hand cut noodles everything is fresh and tasty
author: C W.

description: Went here thinking things would be okay. Def a no no. Worst service ever. The lady who was serving (probably the owner) came to us in the beginning and threw our utensils on the table. She looked like she hated her life. She took forever to come and take our order and when the food came it was a disappointment. The hot and sour soup tasted like vinegar and water, soup dumplings were okay, stir fry beans were salty and drenched in a pool of hot oil. Saw me spill my tea, stared at me, and didn't even bring me any napkins when I tried asking. When it came time to pay the check she took forever as well. Had to go to the counter and pay the bill. She also told the people waiting in the front that they would have to *points at us* wait for our table. So rude. Never again.
author: Monica L.

description:
Short Version: Bigger better dried fried chicken wings than San Tung. Enough Said. 
**CASH ONLY**

***Food***
*Dry fried chicken wings (5/5)
My boyfriend and I had quite a debate over this for years on whose chicken wing reigned supreme. He eventually won me over after the last time I went to San Tung the wings were a little overdone. SUPER SWEET and is amazing over rice. Pet peeve of mine is when wings have no meat on them. This place has HUGE wings and the crispy skin wins my heart every time. It is a bit tricky to eat but my boyfriend still loves me so long hair don't care. If you are ordering for a large table I suggest getting 2 orders.

*Dry sautéed green beans w/shrimp (5/5)
We usually just order it as-is w/o adding meat/shrimp but we felt fancy I guess that day. DELISH. Green beans were perfectly crunchy and snappy(?). Will be adding to our normal repertoire.

*Pork and veggie dumplings (4/5)
Simple dumplings with juicy filling. Pretty basic so good to mix with the vinegar and ask for hot sauce if you like heat.

*Shanghai dumplings (3.5/5)
Technically prefer Dumpling Kitchen on Taraval better but I haven't had Shanghai dumpling king which is also on Balboa to compare. The skin is a bit thicker here than others but it's easy to eat and satisfies my craving. I appreciate the fact that the soup isn't boiling hot here too so you can eat it w/o scalding off all your tastebuds.

***Service***
Small place, one amazing woman servicing everyone. Order can take awhile to get them wings extra crispy but it's worth it! Also come early since there's normally a wait. Not good for big groups since the place is so small. 

***Location***
Parking is a bit rough since it's near the movie theater, purple kow and a ton of hot pot places and more restaurants. Just drop off a friend to put your name down since there can be a wait.

Whenever I'm craving wings we always go here. Pour that sauce over your rice, on your dumplings, shoootttt....I'd put that ish on everything!!
author: Rosie E.

description:
Can the guy who works there be any friendlier? He's so nice!

Food was ok and wasn't laden w/ MSG. The tea smoked duck was incredibly smokey...maybe too much so. Dumplings were juicy. Noodles were saucy. Pan fried dumplings had a super seared bottom which some like but I found just stuck to my teeth. 

Didn't find any standout dishes but it wasn't bad.
author: Julie L.

description:
My boyfriend and I absolutely love this place. He introduced me to this restaurant on my first visit to SF, and I can't get enough of this place! Our last trip to SF, we ate there twice within the 5 days we were there. We keep it simple and order the dry fried chicken wings and two orders of xiao long bao. That's it! 

Keep in mind, service is EXTREMELY slow. It seems like they pay more attention to take-out orders because they are always on the phone and working in the kitchen. They hardly ever come out to the dining room unless it is to bring an order to the table. So make sure you catch their attention when they are out in the dining room, because who knows when they will come back out from the kitchen. 

They also don't know when a customer comes in through the doors. There was a time my boyfriend and I were standing by the door waiting to be seated and it took a couple minutes for someone to come out and seat us. There was one instance where a couple was ready to order, but it took too long, they left. I only deduct one star for service, but their food is sooooo good, it really makes up for the terrible service.
author: Heather O.

description:
Food here is good, no doubt about it, however this place has the worse waitress I've seen before.
The lady with long hair that works in the front is rude, drops the menus on the table, no "hello" no "thank you" no "anything I can help you with?".
She brings hot water to the table in a rude manner and is hostile.
I have come here five or six times before because as I said, their food is good, but service is terrible. 
Today while I was sitting at the table towards the back wall and close to were the Lady stands by she started clipping her nails! Clipping her nails! 
Come on...

This lady ruined everything for me.
author: Diego M.

description: I've been eating at Shanghai House since my childhood with my family. I love the place. Shanghai Soup Dumplings & their chicken wings are always my go to. It's usually just the owner working the restaurant so just have to be patient with her service at times.
author: Elsie W.

description:
Come to Shanghai House for the short lines, and the Shanghai street food, not for the XLB's. If you're looking for XLBs go to Kingdom of Dumpling! 

* XLB - 2 stars: Kingdom of Dumpling is nearby and much soupier. This one is hard on the outside, and mushy on the inside. 
* Fried Chicken Wings - 3.5 stars: Not as good as San Tung, but no wait here! You can find my favorite wings at Hot Sauce and Panko
* Fried Silk Buns - 3 stars: I ordered it because it looked cool on Yelp. Didn't realize these are deep fried buns served with condensed milk. Didn't like the oily aftertaste and was too sweet for me.
* Rice Roll - 4.5 stars: Excellent ratio of rice to meat/fried roll! Loved this, just wish it was bigger!
author: Jess C.

description:
Hole in the wall joint. 

Service was atrocious, but we came for the XLBs and dry fried chicken. The best dry fried chicken we have had. XLBs were yummy, but not the best I've had. 

We also got a green onion pancake. I've had better in Boston's Chinatown.
author: Erin D.

description:
The food was good but we waited over an hour AND got scammed. I know the one waitress works hard and maybe needed the money but what she did was extremely unethical. She overcharged us by $15 and she definitely knew it. We went up to tell her and she acted dumb pretending like nothing was wrong. It took a lot of persistence for her to finally give in and fess up about the mistake. Then she had the guts to only give us $2 back!! She told us that the additional $13 was for tip.... (which when we calculated it came out to over 25% tip that was completely undeserved). 

What she did was wrong but I'm not saying you shouldn't support their business. I'm sure it was out of desperation but I just want people to be aware. 

To the restaurant: Please don't take advantage of your customers. Your food is very good (especially your chicken wings) and we want to want to support you! However, it makes it very difficult to want to support you when you take advantage of us. I know that the restaurant business is stressful, but charging your customers more than they ordered is not the way to earn a little extra money.
author: Stephanie P.

description: The food was really good. The service sucked. I live a block away and after dinner there was reminded why I never go there.... I've been in the hood for over 15 yrs... many chances they've had...booo
author: steph b.

description:
This place SUCKS. The waitress was rude and impatient. She did not even bother to look at you when taking orders. They also CHARGE YOU 15% FOR TIP AUTOMATICALLY. When asked why, they said because "WE CAN CHARGE YOU". No lady you can't. I understand if we are a big party, restaurants normally have mandatory tips. But we are a party of two! 
Anyway, I will never come back.
author: R L.

description:
A great semi hole-in-the-wall dim sum place despite flaws in service!

1) First Impression
It was a Monday night around 7PM and there were many tables open. The lady quickly seated us and you can tell right away she's one of those grumpy old Chinese ladies. Nothing wrong with that though, but just saying. Also, this place is definitely quite small and I can imagine it being completely packed in here on perhaps a Friday night or weekend night.

2) Wait Time
My party of 3 did not have to wait on a Monday night around 7PM.

3) The Food
We decided to order the Potstickers, Shanghai Dumplings, Dry Fried Chicken Wings, and Green Onion Pancake. All four of these dishes pertain to the basic dim sum meal, so we thought it would be a good idea to order these items. 
The potstickers weren't noticeably magnificent in taste, but they're still good!
The Shanghai Dumplings/Xiao Long Bao was great and definitely worth the order!
The chicken wings are probably close to San Tung quality and something worth checking out.
The green onion pancake was also pretty crisp and is a great staple to have with the meal.

4) Service
The lady didn't smile a single time throughout the whole time we were there.
It seemed like she just wanted to get through the rest of the night and could care less about impeccable customer service. In addition, it took her about 20 minutes to give us our bill after we asked for it. However, this was OK because we were all having a nice conversation and wasn't in a rush to get out of the restaurant. To be honest, you shouldn't have high expectations on service if you're going to an authentic Chinese restaurant.

5) Pricing
The items are definitely leaning towards the pricey end of around $7-$11 per dish.
I don't know if the chicken wings are worth the ~$11 the menu advertises, but we were all full in the end and finished everything without any leftovers.

Keep in Mind: 
Parking may be harder to find, especially with Purple Kow across the street.
Speaking of Purple Kow, we went there right after dinner so it's a convenient location for some Dim Sum + Purple Kow combo.

*Final Verdict*
If you're looking for a good Dim Sum place and don't care too much about incredible customer service, then this is the place for you. I gave it 4 stars because the fair customer service really didn't bother me too much at that time.
author: Jeffy Y.

description:
3.5 Stars. 
It's a smallish restaurant with two front of the house staff but the food is well prepared; so it's an intimate experience. Expect slow service and pay everything in CASH ONLY.

- Dry fried chicken which is fine, large winglets with thick crispy batter but overall this didn't quite hit the home run experience I was searching for.  
- XLB is quite excellent with delicately thin and chewy shell and nicely seasoned and toothsome pork stuffing housed within. 
- Hot and sour soup is high on the sour note and unbalanced so if one likes a sour and sour soup, this place has a bowl just for you. 
- Fried shanghai dumpling, which is basically the XLB but pan-friend to produce a crispy bottom. If you've ordered this and the XLB, consider yourself having XLB two-ways. It's a different texture with the shell being crispy on the bottom but still with nice taste pork filling in the middle. 
- Bean curd sheets with soybean, and pickled mustard greens-not great but does its job, the cook didn't bother to tease out the sheets so the whole thing clumped together making this less appetizing to look and irksome while trying to consume. 
- Shanghai noodle tastes more or less like your run of the mill shanghai stir-fried noodle with strips of pork and some soft and mushy noodle with napa cabbage and spinach.
So, the verdict is, if you're around this part of town and have an hankering craving for XLB, Shanghai House is the place for you.
author: Taffany H.

description:
This place is legit! Highly recommend the green beans, pan fried dumplings, Shanghai dumplings and sesame chicken! 

The wings imo were jus average, I would probably not get them again since they are difficult to eat. 

Food is super fresh and comes out pipping hot. Came here with a party of about 5 people and waited about 15-30 minutes for a table at around 8pm on a Saturday. 

It's a tiny place, but I would definitely come back here again!
author: Leah A.

description: I have no idea how this place gets positive write ups. The Shanghai dumplings aren't very soupy and the dough is far too thick on top of the dumpling- almost tasted uncooked at the top. The coating on the chicken wings is too thick and battery, plus the sauce they come in is overly sweet. The only redeeming dish was the fried Shanghai dumplings but not worth going just for them. Place is also a little too dirty, for example touching the menus illicit almost an immediate need to go the bathroom which is an experience itself. You have to go through the kitchen and upstairs where you can only help but question the cleanliness. For example you can see the dishes in buckets of dark brown water where they rest before getting hand washed. And yes, hostess/server is rude and difficult to flag down but unfortunately there are far worse aspects to the dining experience here.
author: Alana C.

description: Horrible service! It seems that the owner doesn't want to run the business at all. She looked very unhappy for our visiting and kept a long face during the service. At the time of payment, she told us she only accept cash. After we told her we didn't carry cash with us at all, she then said she also accept credit cards but one extra dollar must be charged. There are not any signs showing such a payment rule. She didn't even look at you when talking with you.
author: Longfei F.

description:
Went to this place after having it catered at my office during lunch. Thought that going to the actual restaurant would be a fun and exciting experience. Wrong. 

My partner and I were waited on right away and was given a seat without having to wait at all. Great. But service the moment we sat down, absolutely horrible. 

The waitress, which only seemed to be one, was absolutely rude, unkind, unprofessional, and down right unhappy. First, as other reviews stated, her apron didn't seem to be clean whatsoever and neither did the menus given to us to order our food. If you do not like having white people there, please state that, as she did not treat us with respect and had a merry ok time with other mandarin groups. I'm not one to be racist at all, but that is not right.  

This was my first time here and wanted to order dumplings, which I did, but ordered the wrong kind (I ordered veggie and pork dumplings when I later found out, once my food arrived, that I should have ordered the Shanghai house dumplings.) The 'dumplings' I ordered looked more like potstickers than a dumpling. Disappointed with my meal, I asked the waitress if I could order the Shangahi house dumpling rather and have the incorrect dumplings taken back. She looked at me and said 'no no the cook already made the food, you can not have that taken back at all.' So I was caught off guard and pissed at this point. As soon as she walked behind me and at the kitchen, my partner saw her look at me with disgust and talked to her coworkers in mandarin. I don't like to judge or assume, but she was more than likely talking about me in a negative term. The waitress made our entire experience horrible. Even having to pay was a nightmare. 

BRING CASH ONLY! We were not aware of this restaurant being cash only. There was no sign out front, nothing labeled on the menu, and certainly not told by the waitress before hand. We finished our meal and wanted to pay by credit card. Left it on the table as we predicted it would be a hassle to ask for the check. As we waited we finally flagged her down as she was not giving us the time of day otherwise. She approached our table, saw the credit card, picked it up and actually threw it back down on the table stating 'we do not take credit cards, only cash.' With a total disgust on her face. As we did not have any cash on us, I was forced to go to the ATM a block away and get cash for the bill (which isn't a big deal but wish I had known beforehand.) We were so unpleased with this experience. 

On a better note, and the reason I gave it a two star rather than a 1, is because the food was good considering everything else that happened. Nothing was wrong with our food, we ate everything we had ordered, and nothing was cold. That's all this place has to offer is the food, which is a given, but was really hoping it would have great service and a more welcoming environment.
author: Michael T.

description:
This is a small restaurant with about 10 tables, it was a little stuffy and we were the first people (4) to wait for seats, it took about 10-15 minutes. 

We ordered the dry chicken, sautéed string beans, and green onion pancake. The pancake came out first, and it was pretty good, better than some other places- it was crunchy and not too oily. The sautéed beans were very good, the beans were fresh and green and the sauce was a little spicy. The chicken came out last- it was similar to san tungs but crunchier and a little on the sweet side. 

Overall, the food was really good, the food that came out was very hot and fresh. 

The customer service is okay, if you need anything just ask and they'll help you out. 

Price was reasonable for the amount of food that we got. 
Don't forget-cash only!!
author: Letty H.

description:
If I can give them no stars, I would have. First, the service sucks. I appreciate the fact that they were opened on NYE but if they are so unhappy about their life then don't open. The server threw everything at me and my friend with a bad attitude. If you are not white don't go there. 

Food is bad, except for the soup dumplings. Hot and sour soup tasted like hot vinegar.
author: Maple L.

description:
Place was OK but I wouldn't go back. There are definitely better places in SF to get your Shanghainese/Chinese food fix. The restaurant is super small and compact. Seems like this place is family owned, where there's only 1 waitress taking orders and 1 person just serving the food. 

All in all, the service pretty much sucked. Super slow and inattentive. A 5 person family dinner that could've easily been 1 hour turned out to be 2 hours. The food came out pretty slow where my fam would eat 1 dish, finish the dish, then wait for the next to come out.

Their dry-fried chicken wings are pretty comparable to San Tung's, texture and flavor wise. But I wouldn't go back just for the wings. Note that there are less wings in their serving, but definitely bigger & thicker wings than San Tung's.
author: Tiffany Z.

description: People come for Dumplings but all the foods here are MSG based. So you will feel super messes up and sleepy. Don't recommended to come here to eat unless you want to fill mess up...
author: Simon L.

description: I am really disappointed in their food.  Whatever you do... don't go to the bathroom first or else you'll run out so fast!  I visit their restroom after my meal and I was disgusted!  I order their hot and sour soup, tan tan noodles, house special shanghai stir fried noodles, .  Below average. I can get better food for a lot less.  No sign in restaurant that said CASH ONLY!  Lucky we had cash with us or else we'll be in the back doing dishes!
author: Maggie L.

description: Chicken wings.... chicken wings.... chicken wings. Did I mention how good the chicken wings are? The rest of it... well Chinese business... enough said. But the wings are a must try
author: Ed C.

description:
Shanghai House is a small restaurant with plenty of parking around the area. It's also the only place I've been to that has both fried chicken wings and xiao long bao! Service is a bit slow, and it can get crowded since there's only a few tables, but the wait is worth it.

FOOD:
* Xiao long bao - One order comes with 10! The soup dumplings were good, with a nice thin wrapper and tasty soupy insides. These were some of the better ones I've had in SF.

* Dry fried chicken - One order comes with 8 pieces. The chicken wings were slightly larger than I'm used to. The chicken was sooo moist and tender, and full of sticky sweet and spicy flavor. SOO GOOD. My boyfriend says San Tung's wings are slightly better, but that these are comparable (and less of a wait!).

* Pan-fried steamed pork buns - This item wasn't on the menu, so show them a pic on yelp! Comes with 8 piping hot buns. The wrapper on these are tasty and chewy, like your standard Chinese pork bun, but pan-fried on the bottom. The inside pork was like a soup dumpling - it tasted good with the vinegar sauce.

Overall, 4.5 stars. Will definitely be back for the XLB and fried chicken!
author: Vivian H.

description: A very small with bare wall atmosphere and often a wait. The food is top shelf Chinese cuisine from the dumplings to the pigs knuckle, the pea shoot sautéed in rice wine. The dry fried chicken for which they use honey rather than sugar to sweeten the spicy sweet sauce is far and above better than the well known San Tung on Irving. You get less pieces in your order than San Tung but the pieces are larger with more meat. The Shanghai style braised meat balls are outstanding as are the spare ribs. If you are expecting 3 star Michelin service this isn't the place for as there is just one woman who takes orders and runs the dining room, thus you need to be patient. There are of course many many Chinese restaurants in San Francisco and after more than 30 years here I have been to quite a few. The food at Shanghai House is up on top consistently.
author: Steven B.

description: I love this place. Yes it is simple hallway of a space, and yes the owner/waitress can be a bit surly, but the food is out of sight and it is part of the charm right! The Dry Fried Chicken Wings are the best in town! They come out super hot and it is hard waiting for them to cool before eating them. The Soup Dumplings are also great, add a Green Onion Pancake and it is the perfect meal! We have also enjoyed the Garlic Eggplant. Expect a wait if you arrive during peak hours as it gets very busy! This place is a ton better than the other place nearby that sells Soup Dumplings!
author: Michael B.

description: Highly recommend their chicken wings - it was probably the highlight of my dinner. Given the XLB and pan fried buns are not bad too. BUT THEM CHICKEN WINGS! What can go wrong with deep fried chicken wings with a delicious delicious honey sauce?
author: Sandy W.

description: The XLB were passible, the hot beef on noodles were quite good, the potstickers were good.  The service was beyond atrocious.
author: Paul T.

description:
I was craving Xiao long bao and Dry fried chicken wings. I've had Shanghai house bookmarked for some time, so instead of trekking across the park into the Sunset to get my fix, I thought I'd finally check Shanghai house off my list. I called in the take out order and the roommate picked it up about 30 mins later.

Dry chicken wings - chicken wings deep fried in batter with garlic, ginger and roast red peppers
A little sweeter than I prefer. The roommate said it was cuz they use honey instead of corn syrup. Though honey is probably better for you, I prefer a different sweetener as the honey overpowered the savory aspect of the dish.

Xiao long bao
These were delish! The skin held up well in the take out container. None of them burst so they all kept their juicy goodness. I liked the thickness of the wrapper and the consistency of the filling.

Potstickers - pork and veggies
Meh! Average potstickers. Nothing to write home about.

Dry sauteed string beans - fresh green beans flash fried and tossed in a garlicky sauce with Chinese pickle
These did not taste dry fried at all! Almost like blanched strings beans mixed in sauce. So bland! They got better the next day but then they got mushy.

House special eggplant - shrimp, chicken and fresh basil
The roommate's pick since he wanted something healthier. I actually liked this dish. Had great flavor and the eggplant was cooked nicely.

Combo fried rice
Burnt! The whole dish tasted burnt. I know sometimes a little smokiness can be good, but not in fried rice and not to this degree! The cook should have known not to serve this. I'm surprised they gave it to us to take home. Probably hoping we wouldn't complain which we didn't so I guess they scored there.
