I might come back just for the Xiao long bao, but with Shanghai dumpling king just down the street with better offerings in terms additional dishes, I'll probably skip Shanghai house. No one should be serving burnt rice!
author: Elena N.

description: I'm a regular here. My wife and I came very often. Now I bring my daughters and grandchildren here. They love the food here also. I loved every dish I've tried here. But you need to come try and to discover your own favorites. The chicken wings, better than San Tong or anywhere else. Their siao long bow is the best in a SF. The savory soy soup, the vegetarian goose, the fried buns, the various kinds of noodles, are some of the many of our favorites.
author: Gene L.

description: My favorite place to get authentic Chinese food! I always come in on a Friday evening every now and then followed by a movie ( Balboa theater across the street) and order the "Handcut noodles" and the "Sesame chicken" and "Shanghai steamed dumplings" sooooooo yummy! :D Literally anything you order here is going to taste amazing, fresh and flavorful. The owner / waitress who comes and takes your order make seem little blunt and off putting but she means well and will bring you exactly what you need and ordered. This place is CASH only and can have limited seating sometimes. Other then that this is by far the best place to come and get a great tasty meal!!!!!
author: Taylor S.

description: I'm a regular here and the cranky old Asian lady that everyone complains about is actually really nice.  What do you expect walking into a Chinese restaurant? Service is definitely not it... Anyways, if you're persistent enough to flag her down, then you will get to try some delicious Shanghainese food that you can't really get anywhere else in the city.  I recommend the dry fried chicken wings, Shanghai dumplings (duh), Shanghai style rice cakes, hand cut braised beef noodles, green onion pancake (the flakiest I've ever had), rice roll (only served in the morning), and pan fried dumplings.
author: Colleen L.

description:
This place is CASH ONLY.

I'm pretty much a regular here. Any time someone wants xlb I suggest this place. I come with my tennis guys so we order at least 3 racks of xlb. Yum! We always order the dry chicken wings and xlb. These 2 have never failed us and these wings are comparable to San tung. I like these wings because I like the pepper addition. Its much more flavorful to me. 

Service can be a little slow though because its a mom and pop shop. But I think the two items that I mentioned are worth the wait. We've also ordered the sizzling rice soup and eel noodles. sizzling rice soup was not on the menu but you have to ask. Its pretty good. The eel noodles were okay... I've ordered a number of things so its hard to review them all. But, anyway order the xiao long bao and the dry chicken wings !
author: Lyra C.

description:
Ordered the Shanghai style pan fried noodles and twice pork and they weren't very impressive. Both entrees came with a lot of sauce, so I recommend ordering some rice. Service was abrupt, but it seems like a busy spot, so don't expect lots of smiles. 

Also prices on the Yelp menu are much cheaper than the actual menu. Most entrees were $8-12, with the exception of cheaper dim sum options (which is more expensive than most places) and pricier seasonal items.
author: Czarina L.

description:
I am somewhat of a xlb snob and shanghai house makes by far my favorite xlb in the city, way better than shanghai dumpling king, bund shanghai, etc. the skin on the xlb is not too thick and perfectly contains the soup inside the dumplings. I've also tried the fried chicken and I personally prefer it to the famous fried chicken at san tung. The chicken is incredibly moist and juicy inside and the skin is just the right balance of spicy savoriness and sweet. 

And yea, the service kind of sucks, but pretty standard and not egregiously terrible.
author: Jean J.

description: Great food soooo delicious!!! I crave it almost every week. Chicken wings and Shang Hai noodles are a must have.
author: Cindy M.

description: One of the best Chinese restaurants we've had in the city. It's not easy to compare but this one deserves a spot amongst the top. The perfect combination is the Shanghai noodle, spicy wonton in chilli sauce and the chicken wings. They are comparable to the wings at San Tung. Small place but its usually easy enough to get a table on a week night. Wait may be longer on a weekend but probably worth it!
author: Vikram D.

description: Friends brought us here so our first time. The chicken wings do compete with San Tung, I must say, though differently flavored. Very crispy! Not as big a portion and not as sweet which is ok. Very good! We had the siu loong baus which had good broth and thin skin. The fried baus were new and different.Don't need to order too many items to be full. Small place but no line on weekday.
author: B. K.

description:
I live in Nob Hill, but sometimes I take a 40 minute bus ride all the way to outer richmond for the:

Pan fried buns (Sheng Jian Bao) - not on the menu, just ask
Dry Fried Chicken - not on the menu, just ask as well
Jiu Niang!!! (Sweet rice wine dessert with sesame ball)

 - which makes a perfect afternoon snack for me.

Service can be good or poor depending on the person, but if you speak Shanghai-nese dialect with the owner, you automatically get better service.
author: Shelley C.

description:
Despite the often lackluster service, I do love this place, and am glad I live close by! Authentic Chinese, and so many options. Here's what we've had so far:

*Spicy beef tendon: I've had better. Would pass. Kinda oily, and not that flavorful?
*Dry chicken wings: so freakin' good. Definitely echo the "better than San Tung's" sentiment. Really gratuitous (I only ate an entire dish by myself and felt like I would physically suffer afterwards), but a GREAT choice if you're wanting some decadence.
*Lion's head meatballs: light and fluffy! Not sure how they get the consistency to be this way, but actually a refreshing (rather than heavy) meat dish.
*Soup dumplings: solid. Always delicious.

Looking forward to trying so much more of the menu!
author: Shendi X.

description: I will never come back to this place!! Ate here once when it wasn't busy I asked for chicken fried rice. The plate came back with maybe a couple spoonful of rice and topped with so much veggies and I'm talking about tablespoon size. I'd say about 10% was rice 15% chicken and 75% veggies. Server forgot my drink and she looked like a total mess apron was full of stains hands were greasy when she gave me my drink, food that I received was nasty. I'm sorry but this place is not good at all from my experience.
author: Kevin B.

description: The Shanghai dumplings and chicken wings are pretty good.  As it is a small restaurant, there was only one server, the service was slow.  I would go again if I was in the neighborhood, but I would not make a special trip there.
author: Egen T.

description:
The dumplings are always good. The soup inside is always served super hot and the whole thing usually melts in your mouth. Get a tray of 10 or 20, you won't regret it!

The chicken wings are amazing, so don't skip out on them. I haven't had San Tung's version yet, but this dish is delicious. Add green onion pancakes to your appetizer list too, your stomach will thank me later. Those are bomb-good!

This place isn't too expensive, so check it out if you're in the area. I'm taking a star off because the service is slow and the waiter--who is usually nice to my friend--is not too friendly to most customers. She needs to smile more.
author: Chinsin S.

description: Love this place.  Honestly, the service isn't the greatest, but there's only one emotionless lady who's running around doing everything and managing an ever busy location (this is also classic Chinese restaurant).  Even with the bad service, lines are always out the door, so make sure you do your part and get there early (or right when they open).  Food is 5/5 for sure.  Dry fried wings, rice cakes, green onion pancake, XLBs and pan friend XLBs...seasonal veggies...  Always craving this place when in the City.  Make sure to crack a joke with the waitress.  A smile (and a little bit of patience) goes a long way.
author: David W.

description:
Anyone that left a 5 star review for this place must be family members or close friends because this place is a joke. 
Good isn't worth the price they're asking for and worst of all is their service!
Never coming back to this place ever again.
author: Danny H.

description:
Don't go for the hospitality. Indeed you need to have a little bit of patience being served but it is worth the wait. Excellent quality of food for a reasonable price. I thoroughly enjoyed my shrimp fried rice. The food is piping hot when served 
The only thing that lacks this place is a toilet
author: Aerodaan ..

description:
I'm pretty sure I entered the establishment and ordered a good 5 minutes before this other party BUT WHERE THE HELL IS MY FOOD & XLB? 

Right now, I see that the other party ordered 2 XLB, whereas my mother and I only ordered 1 XLB, but in what world does a party, who orders later, gets their food first???? LIKE BRUH. 

if you really want good xiao long bao, go to Dumpling Kitchen on Taraval- at least they have good service there. 

If you really dig the dry chicken wings and San Tung's line is too long, try Chang's Kitchen, which is across the street from San Tung. 

Stop giving this place more credit than it deserves. This place is not worth a detour.
author: Fiona C.

description: Actually really enjoyed the food here. Service aside, the food was very good. New items for me. Top left - The amazing pan fried dumping that's not on the menu, basically tasted like a xiao long bao with crispy skin on the bottom! The bottom right- Tan tan noodles! Yum
author: O K.

description: My brother lives in the area, and couldn't remember exactly where this place was, so we spent at least 1/2 hour walking around looking for it. I was visiting from out of town and was getting a little impatient because it was getting close to closing time and you can't swing a dead cat in the Richmond neighborhood without hitting a dumpling place. Long story short, I was super glad he was so insistent about finding this particular place. Our parents are Shanghainese, and my Mom is a spectacular cook but I think she's met her match in this place. We had the pan fried dumplings, soup dumplings, and eight treasure sticky rice. My only regret is I got full so quickly, and also that we didn't think ahead to order additional takeaway because I continued to have cravings the next day. *sigh*
author: debora c.

description:
I would dine here for the food once a week if I didn't live so far from it! Cash only though and this place is small so expect a little wait depending on what time you arrive. I had to flag down the waitress a couple of times but what can you expect for a family ran Chinese restaurant.

My friends and I came here to taste Shanghai House's dry fried chicken wings that has been said to be San Tung's respective rival. Shanghai's wings have a more crunchy outer texture but San Tung's wings still edge in flavor just a bit. We also got their soup dumplings, eggplant with chicken & shrimp, spicy string beans, and noodles with meat sauce. I really liked each dish but they were definitely more on the thick saucy side (hello corn starch!).

All in all, good food and quite cheap when you eat it family style.
author: Kathy L.

description: Came here for a quick dinner with my brother and got seated right away. We had shanghai noodles and dumplings. I have to return for the wonton in chili oil because those are one of my favorite dishes and Shanghai fried pork dumplings. I would also like to return and try the deep fried saucy chicken wings. Not bad and service is quick.
author: Amanda C.

description:
Tldr: If you're not Chinese, you're not welcome here.

We sat down and ordered from a gruff waitress with a sour expression.  We waited for over 45 minutes, watching as other groups that arrived later were served before us (including the dishes we had ordered). 

After asking about our food, the waitress hollered into the back but nothing happened. We looked around as more groups who arrived later were served, groups who happened to be able to speak in Chinese to our gracious hostess. Finally, after waiting another 10 min and watching other later groups eat the dishes we had ordered, we left. 

I see from previous comments that this discrimination isn't unique. I'm tired of people giving Chinese restaurants a pass on service because "that's to be expected at a Chinese restaurant." Why?
author: Steve S.

description: This has really good chinese food. I had the spicy tofu and the pan fried steamed dumpling and it was amazing. I really liked the food here and have gone back a few times since.
author: Theo L.

description: This place was so good! I went here with the fam to get some grub after a few hours of hiking. We decided to get some dumplings, dry fried chicken, wings and Shanghai noodles. The place is a little small so there can be a wait. Besides that the quality of the food was great! Definitely loved the dry fried wings! I recommend checking this place out if you're in the area.
author: Deej I.

description:
TLDR: Best xiao long bao in the city, everything else sucks.

Best xiao long bao (shanghainese soup dumplings) in the Sunset/Richmond area, and probably best in the city. I know because my recent crazy obsession over XLBs prompted me to hunt them down and try them everywhere I can find.

Unfortunately, everything else at Shanghai House is lackluster in comparison to other chinese restaurants. Most dishes comes with an unnecessary half plate of oil.
-Dry fried chicken wings were okay, nice try (so hard) drenched in too much sugary glaze goo; I prefer San Tung's better dried wings
-Jellyfish, don't get it here if you're typically a fan; this is supposed to be a cold refreshing appetizer but the one here is weirdly warm and also super greasy
-Spicy combination beef (fu qi fei pian) isn't spicy or flavorful enough
-Hand-pulled noodles, generically bland huge pile of carbs

Cash only. Nothing else besides the XLB was memorable except the owner lady (I think) behind the counter looks intimidating and reminds me of the Landlady of Pig Sty Alley from Kung Fu Hustle.
author: Tian Q.

description:
Tiny storefront in a residential area with amazing food!  We stopped here before heading to the Legion of Honor, and were pleasantly surprised by something called Dry Fried Chicken Wings.  We saw three other tables getting something that looked strangely unlike anything we had seen before, so we asked what it was and decided to try it.

We were so glad we did.  They were crispy, spicy,  savory, sweet and tangy - and delicious. 

We also had the House special noodle soup with hand cut noodles, and it was another great dish. The noodles had great texture, the broth was flavorful, and all the other stuff was perfectly cooked.

Service was OK, but the food made everything else worthwhile.

There were so many other things we wanted to try.   We would definitely recommend going out of your way to eat at this place!
author: Nadine S.

description:
The food here is great, but their service can definitely use some work.

I walked in to order food at 9pm, and the woman tells me I can only have the food to go because they close at 9:30pm. However, 10 minutes after I placed my to go order, a couple came in, spoke to the woman in Chinese, and then she let them stay to eat. A couple of minutes after them, a Caucasian couple came in and she told them the same thing she told me: only food to go.

Pro tip: if eating late, come here with a Chinese-speaking friend.

I think I'll be sticking to Shanghai Dumpling King. Their staff is so much more friendly.
author: Melissa D.

description:
Came here after a fellow Yelper raved about their dry fried chicken wings. They claimed it was better than San Tung so we had to check it out. We waited a little over 30 minutes for a table outside (no waiting area because the restaurant is so small). They also don't have a waiting list so we just hoped the lady wouldn't forget about us.

The soup dumplings were the best thing we ordered. They definitely weren't the best I've ever had but we were uber hungry and ordered a second round.

As for the wings, they were crispy and tasty but I disagree that they are better than San Tung. It had a little kick to it but the sauce was off...think it was too sweet and not particularly memorable.

Overall, I'd say it's decent but by no means is it San Tung or "the best of the best" good.
author: Kat C.

description:
This was a cute find while out in the Richmond waiting for our Purple Kow! It's a tiny space with about 8 tables for sit down eating. We ordered to go & waited for our order. The service was pretty mediocre & it seemed like we were an inconvenience being there. After what seemed like forever, we got our food & we bounced. We ordered their fried chicken wings & chow mein.

Fried chicken wings: AMAZINGLY DELICIOUS! It's super super crunchy btw. Loved the sauce! It had a great kick!

Chow mein: was yummy! No complaints here!

The food I would definitely come back for, especially the chicken. But I would always order take out instead of dining in.
author: Gwyne P.

description:
I'm not sure how I can even describe the frustration I have for this spot. 

How does a restaurant refuse to take a table's order? 

You have a girl that pretends to be a waiter and some older woman that oversees everything, while finding the time to yell at the cooks in the back. 

We waited for 30 minutes to put in our order, even telling the fake waitress we were ready.

But, no, the People's Republic of Shanghai House decides for you when you want to order and whatnot. 

After over an hour of combined waiting times, all we had was an empty pot of tea. 

And to add insult to injury, someone in my party most likely dropped some cash out of their pockets while we were leaving. 

So, yeah, we essentially gave Shanghai House a $100 tip for the shittiest non-service imaginable. 

I'm a local and you have lost my business for life.

Seriously, you guys suck in ways that cannot be penned, described, or even contemplated.
author: Aren A.

description: Best asian fried chicken in the city, pieces are big and crunchy and the sauce is delicious. Also, there's this pork with seaweed dish thing that's really good. Servings are solid.
author: John R.

description:
Food (4/5): My bf and I split the pork and veggie dumplings, a vegetarian dish with bean curd sheets, edamame, and mustard greens, and pan fried pork buns. The first two were solid, and reminded me a lot of my mom's cooking. The pan-fried pork buns was the standout dish - they were crispy on the bottom, juicy on the inside, and flavorful throughout. 

Note - we didn't see this dish on the menu, but we just showed them a picture of the buns on Yelp and they made it. There were a few other dishes I saw on Yelp but not on the menu, so don't be afraid to ask!

Service (3/5): Polite but inattentive - if you want something, ask! Don't expect the servers to come refill your waters on their own.

Value (4/5). Between the two of us, our meal came out to $30, including tax and tip. We were definitely full, too.
author: Abby S.

description:
Came here on Friday at 7pm and were seated immediately. Seems to be popular with locals who don't want to venture out to Chinatown. 

The fried chicken wings and sweet n sour spare ribs came drenched in a caramel like sauce which hardened after a few minutes. What amount of sugar and corn starch was used to make THAT happen?? 1/5

Xiao long baos and Nian gao noodle were decent but not amazing. 3.5/5

Service was average - very business like and not all that friendly until they get your cash + tip. This place is cash only FYI. The only redeeming factor was Purple Kow across the street for dessert.
author: David P.

description:
3.5 stars. Some dishes were excellent, others were really skimpy. 

1. XLB - Decent - skin was thin and soup was plenty, but the pork lacked flavor.
2. Potstickers - not worth. Puny doesn't even begin to describe them.
3. Chicken wings - never arrived! FAIL.
4. Spicy sliced beef - thin sliced beef and tendon tossed in spicy chili oil. Laid over a bed of sliced cucumbers that definitely help cut the spice - very yummy.
5. Stir fried rice cakes - nothing special, but also not bad.
6. Deep fried pork chop noodle - lots of noodle, but the deep fried pork chop was all bone - LAME.
7. Pickled veggie and salted pork rice - liked the crispy rice on the bottom, but it would have been better if the salted pork actually infused the rice - kind of plain.

and last but not least...

8. Salt and pepper pork knuckle - DEFINITE WINNER. Fork tender meat with a crispy exterior. Served over a bed of crispy kale chips. I could just eat this alone with endless bowls of rice. So yummy! Portion is more than enough for multiple meals, so don't balk at the $24 price tag.

Service was okay. The young gent definitely seemed overwhelmed at times. He would deliver a dish and astutely comment that we needed serving utensils or bowls or whatnot....but then never bring them. Awkward.
author: Elaine Y.

description: Wow. I read about how shitty the service was here, and the newspaper article's headline in the window says "Shanghi house: worth the wait". I can tell you that the food is ok, soup dumplings we're just warm, the fried dumplings we're delicious, and the shanghai noodles flavorless and oily. We waited SO long for the food, it was ridiculous. We were in disbelief as we watched tables of diners arrive after us and get served. I had just come from Yoga, so I was in a fairly patient mood, and spent the hour we waited trying to talk my family off the wall. However, as I watched the table next door get delivered their 4th dish of food, I turned around and yelled "Excuse me! Are we going to get any food? Ever?". The staff works very hard to avoid catching your eye for any service request, and I knew that our food was probably going to be spit on after my outburst, but it really was unbelievably bad service. And to boot, they don't take cards, so we nearly ended up washing dishes to get out of there. We're cash poor, and still hungry. Do not waste your time here.
author: Maria R.

description:
We used to come here often for the xlb, but over time, we've learned their menu is really hit or miss, usually more misses...
There are only a few things we like to order here, each time we've veered off the menu, we've been hugely disappointed. 

What we typically get:

1. Xiao long bao (juicy, a little fattier so more flavor than at somewhere like Din Tai Fung) - although today, it was quite fatty and mushy...
2. Fried Chicken Wings (better than San Tung's for sure, comparable to ones at Tenglong), always a good go to
3. Shanghai Fried Rice Cake, with the chopped cabbage and pork. This is a comfort dish, kinda like a simple chop suey. 
4. Eggplant with chicken and shrimp is decent. 

Things to kéep in mind so you don't get terribly upset:
1. If there's a line, go in and make eye contact with the waitress, let her know how many is in your party. Everyone stands and waits outside. Stay visible in case waitress waves for you to come in. 
2. You'll have to ask 3 times before you get ice water. If you drink a lot of water, just ask for more than one glass, or you will have trouble getting refills.
3. Be very, very patient - or don't eat here.
4. The check might take a while to come. 
5. The waitress is very slow. We don't mind her too much. We just know to be patient with her here. She just looks very tired all the time and doesn't ever seen to get to sit down for a rest.
6. Don't veer off the menu and order something new if you already like certain dishes. My husband was craving "tan tan noodle" (description on menu) and what came out had 3 kinds of meat, including shrimp (which he is allergic to, so I had to eat the dish myself), cucumber and bean sprouts, toppings he also didn't like. The dish was bland and not spicy. We've noticed their recipes are usually different than what you'll find at other restaurants. 
7. If you have a food allergy or don't like something, ask if that dish you're about to order has that ingredient.
8. Cash only.
author: Minh D.

description:
Think twice before going! We watched the bay area's check please, and decided to check it out.
What a mistake, the Mongolian beef was so filled with chili paste and hot to the point it was not edible.  I returned it and settled for the Xiao dumplings, which were quite good. The chow mein my girlfriend ordered, had no flavor at all.  Maybe we should have just had wings, or the dumplings.  Better yet, go somewhere else .... sad part is I'm Chinese!
author: Jeff L.

description:
I know there is a waitress drives you crazy as F!
I understand. But I like the food very much.
Hand cut noodrow pan fly was really good.
Of course the XLB!
The pork/lettuce dumplings
Dry sauteed string beans - fresh green beans flash fried and tossed in a garlicky sauce with Chinese pickle
Dan dan noodles
Tan tan noodles
I like them all.
I can't help to come back.
When I come here with my gf, everything is fine, but when I am by my self, she treated me like crap! 
So, I sing this song for me and who ever had a so bad service in here because the waitress.
Here we go!

Fxxx the Bxxxx

when you have that 
special dumpling, that makes 
your heart skip a beat.
and your so crazy in love
your telling everybody.

that it's your life, your
heart, your soul, your
babydumlings but you just
don't know what it's
doing to you in this
world.

*CHORUS*

so i'm saying, forget
the waitress. i don't need
this shit. i'm gonna
live life to the fullest
and i have no regrets.

so forget the waitress.
i don't need this
shit. i'm gonna
smoke weed feel
high like it's ligit.

so forget the waitress.
i don't need this
shit. i'm gonna
live life to the fullest
and i have no regrets.
so forget the waitress. i don't
need this shit. i'm gonna
smoke weed feel high
like it's ligit.

and down the road
of your relationship
you realize. that
everything she said
to you was just her
lies.

and now you live heart
broken, and things seem
so strange. cause you
can't believe that the
waitress of your dreams
just played that stupid game.
author: Nobu K.

description: Good Lord is the service here awful. I can't rate the food, because we never ate. The waitress ignored us completely and semi-glared at us while we stood harmlessly waiting to be seated. Eventually a man seated us. The waitress never came to our table, but visited plenty of other tables that came in after us. I don't know what she had against us, but we left before we ever had the chance to order. I don't care how good the food might be, there's no excuse for such bad service.
author: Meredith B.

description:
I frequent here a lot. I usually order their steamed xiao long bao, pan fried xiao long bao, veggies, and their dry fried chicken wings. However, there was inconsistency in the food the last time I went but that's my only bad experience. 

I will still come back.

Do not expect great customer service. The place is small. Only Cash.
author: Ange G.

description: Dumpling and bread were good. Lunch special with decent ingredients but no way to eat it with so much salt - uneatable. Service, what service? We were in during a weekday around 11am with no one around. Waited over 15 minutes before taking our order, another 20 minutes for the food then never see her again. Need to wave her down for the check and some take home boxes. Cash only.
author: Frank W.

description:
A great hole in the wall!  I've been here more than a couple times. Since the place is so small, you kind of never know if there's gonna be a wait or not, but in most days and nights, a wait shouldn't be more than 10-30 minutes if you're coming with a small party (2-4 people)

I would say the best dish is the dry chicken wings! They are very similar to san tung's famous chicken wings, but I will swear they are better!  For one thing, the chicken they use here consist of wings and drumsticks! The chicken pieces are also big and they do not skimp!  Each dish consist of 8 pieces of chicken. The sweet and spicy flavors come together great with the sauce. I would say it taste a bit more on the spicy side compare to san tung. 

I honestly recommend you eat here if you've heard great things about these famous san tung chicken wings. come on, this place usually has minimum wait and I would choose this place over waiting at San tung for 1 hour+!!

Shanghai dumplings - always has the brothy soup inside each dumpling! Pretty delicious and a good amount of pork in each dumpling. They do not fail on the soup inside! The trick is to use your spoon and directly transport from chopstick to spoon ASAP! However, the skin on the dumplings are thick compared to shanghai dumpling king up the street. These are satisfying but definitely not my go to for dumplings. The better part is less wait than up the block and it will still satisfy your craving.


Shanghai style rice cake - great ingredients with a good amount of pork, cabbage and rice cake but really lacks flavor! It was not salty at all and I had to add soy sauce. I usually never do this at any restaurant cause the flavor from the meats with already added salt and soy sauce should do the trick.

Hand-cut shanghai noodles - same concept as the rice cake but with their hand cut noodles. Hand cut noodles had a good texture, but this noodle dish also lacked salt and flavor!  They can definitely improve on this.

Green onion pancake - delicious, crispy and a good amount of green onion! 

pan fried baos - prob the best dish after the chicken wings and dumplings =)  highly recommend!!!!

The best part is that these dishes do not kill your pockets. If you're ballin on a budget and want some good eats, come here!

warning though: service is super slow, so pro-tip.... once you sit down, order right away!
author: Josie L.

description:
we came around 1130 on a thursday? No customers and no one to greet us...we can hear them working in the kitchen so we sat ourselves and got our own menus.
seems like the guy in the kitchen was the only guy there as he came out to take our orders eventually. A lady came to work later around noon? 

we ordered
jelly fish with green onions- yea...not the same as dim sum jellyfish. SKIP~! more random veggies than jellyfish anyways!
xlb- fairly juicy...most were broken...thick skin..
pan fried dumpling- yummy! still had juice inside!
shanghai noodles- maybe from the cabbage...but it had a slightly sour/tart taste. not my favorite.
dry fried chicken wings- pretty good, can taste the honey in it

overall, I think I'd prefer dumpling kitchen on taraval, better service and food is on point for me.
I'm kind of surpised to think this place gets packed/ there'd be a wait...I would not wait~!
author: Christine M.

description: This place has great xiao long bao and pan fried dumplings.  The skin of both dumpling was perfection. The decor/atmosphere is kinda sketch but it adds to the whole "you know their food is going to be legit" feel.
author: Sophia H.

description:
One day after work - as I was hungry and craving Chinese food, I thought to venture over to this place... The one woman... She was extremely RUDE! ((It takes a lot to upset me.)) I received no acknowledgement upon entering the restaurant. Still, I walked up to her and kindly asked for a menu. I conveyed that I was ordering for "HERE". She seemed rushed. Anyhow I sat myself down after ordering three items. By the way, she did not offer water or tea to me - though I wasn't worried as I happened to have a full bottle of water with me. Though it was slightly bothersome to watch her bring food to people who had entered the restaurant much AFTER me. I waited... Waited... Also, it was so hard to flag her down to inquire re: the status of my order - as she made no eye contact with me and rushed to/from the back. 

Anyway, 45+ minutes later - she brought out my order via packed containers in a plastic bag... WHAT?! Again I reported I had ordered for "HERE" - and this time she replied with something along the lines of "I thought you ordered to go". She did NOT apologize for the misunderstanding. Note - when I'm hungry, I get irritated... Internally, I was so frustrated! Anyway, as I just wanted to get out of there (!!!), I paid (no tip as unbeknown to me, it ended up being to go), grabbed the food, and left (w/o getting soy sauce). 

I'm giving one star as the food was edible... The green onion pancakes, vegetarian steamed dumplings, and vegetarian chow mein. 

I wish I went elsewhere... Sadly, this place has horrible service... 

As one of the other reviews mentioned, I wish I spoke Chinese. Note, I was the only Indian person in the restaurant at the time. Perhaps the woman thought I was a lost tourist?
author: Pina U.

description: Ordered 4 things to go today, pan fried Shanghai dumplings, pork dumplings, green onion pancakes and Shanghai noodles. Went in and 4:15 or so. There was a couple people eating in and 1 person ahead that ordered to go right before us. There was 1 lady taking orders. She was not very friendly. No smile, very to the point. Ok, I'm used to that at Chinese restaurants....We didn't have cash so my husband drove all the way to wells at the beach and back still no food, it was 4:30. The person who ordered togo before us just got her food. Waited and waited, 4:55 hits she started packing some food up in a bag. Thought that was ours, ready to pay, lady says "2 chicken wings?" We said "no". She's said "ok not ready yet". WTF! At this point the restaurant was almost full. We see people who sat way after us get their food..."hmm" we thought. My husband (and I) were getting frustrated esp the lady not acknowledging us at all and how long we have waited. We said ok 5 more minutes if we don't get anything we are leaving. 5 mins later still nothing so I go to her and say "how much longer? We've been here for almost an hour" she says "pan fried shang hai dumplings take a long time". 1hr???? So she goes to the back and asks where it is, she comes out with it, basiclaly immediately, and starts taking a couple dishes out of the previously packed to go order and hands it to us. Hmmm so she packed our food mistakenly in another order?! She didn't apologize for the wait or anything (not sure why I even expected it). Already annoyed, while driving home, my husband thought how much we paid and thought it was overpriced. I checked the menu and recalculated and per my own calc after tax should have been $33 at most, we paid $36 and change! Add to our frustration. Got home and took the food out, the dumplings were packed in those compostable to go containers that when wet/moist, will warp. They put these dumplings right on top with no wax paper or anything so the bottom of the dumplings got stuck to the container. We basically had to rip off the bottom of each dumpling and if it did come off, we still needed to take the bottom off because there would be paper from the container stuck on the bottom. Smh! As for the noodles, the texture was too soft, all the ingredients kind of just mixed together like a pile of mush with tons of cabbage on top. The green onion pancake was not layered like what we r used to, it was doughy. As for the pan fried dumplings those were the best of the bunch but sadly still mediocre. Safe to say we will not be back. Usually if food is good, it can make up for horrible customer service (sometimes) but in this case, not even close, granted I know to-go can be vastly different vs when eaten fresh at the restaurant. In this case I just don't think eating there would have made a difference. Customer service: 0 stars. Food: 0 stars
author: Bevo T.

description:
I came to check this place out because I've been hearing my friends talk about how this place got better dry fried chicken wings than San tungs! I was skeptical, so I came to try it myself. 

The place is really small and there aren't that many tables. Me and my friends didn't get seated until 30 mins later because people were taking their precious time eating. When we finally got seated, we weren't really greeted so warmly. I just went straight on to order the chicken wings. It took a fairly long time to get what we order, but once it got to the table, I thought it was well worth the wait.

Their dry fried chicken wings are better than san tungs, but by just a little bit! I love the crunchiness of it and the heavenly sauce with a kick to it. It felt like I had an orgasm in the mouth when I took the first bite of that chicken wing bruh.
author: Kristoffer R.

description:
Regarding Shanghai House on 3641 Balboa Street (Outer Richmond District in S.F., CA):

First off, the ingredients in the Seafood Chow Mein, are not listed in the menu. On top of that, I went over it with the waitress twice, even repeating what she said once... She told me that it consists of prawns, scallops and oysters. She failed to mention squid - which I loathe! And, to make the mess (as I think of it) - even worse - the noodles or Chow Mein portion of it was so plentiful - it was packed in the small/medium box like dirt hard-packed! So, long story - short, a ton of starchy noodles, pan-pried, about two prawns, one oyster, a shriveled scallop or two and a long repulsive piece of squid.
author: Carol J.

description:
My partner and I got there around 7:15pm to find the place quite packed. But after 10 minutes of wait, we were already sitting down. We ordered Pan Fried Pork Dumplings, Dry Fried Wings, Red Bean Bun, and Dry Fried Fillet. Since the place was quite busy, we ended up waiting for our food longer than we had expected. But it was definitely worth the wait! 
The dry fried wings and fillet were extremely crunchy with sweet syrup all over it. If you've ever had San Tung's chicken, this will be a bit sweeter for you. The pan fried pork bun was steamed and fried perfectly. Though I was looking for more flavor of the meat, I found it in the fried bun instead. The red bean bun was a delicious desert. I've never been too big of a fan of red bean but this was not bad at all. Everything looked and tasted delicious! 
The atmosphere is quiet and cozy. We were there for an hour and the place never had an empty seat. The service was pleasant even with just one person taking orders. They were moving around constantly with the busy flow of the restaurant. I would definitely go back to try more options from their lunch menu and entrees.
author: Sudha S.

description:
The service is hilariously bad. I mean straight up stone faced ignoring of any request from any table. Lots of confused people in here waiting to order, waiting for food, waiting to pay. Waiting, waiting, waiting... and all you get when you ask is a scowl.

But the food is delicious! We really enjoyed their soup dumplings. We also tried pan fried dumplings but these looked better than they tasted. Too much dough.
author: Johnny H.

description: Tried their version of dried fried chicken wings and actually felt it was delicious. Not over drenched in sauce as other places might prepare them and the chicken meat was juicy. My group also ordered some XLB's and sad to say that the broth lacked flavor even after trying my fair share of them. The string beans were a good compliment to the wings as was the beef and noodle dish we had also ordered. I would go back to this place to have others try the wings here since they were savory.
author: Roje D.

description: This was my first Dim Sum and it was DELICIOUS! It's a quaint, small restaurant very authentic Chinese style. Some things weren't clear on the menu, and the service isn't always friendly, but the atmosphere is great! Locals wait out the door to get a seat. I hope to visit again soon. Oh, they DO NOT ACCEPT CARDS, cash only! No signs posted for that and that was a little surprising.
author: McKel M.

description:
dumplings a bit over-cooked such that skin soft and watery.
Wonton soup not great. The meat in the wontons seemed to be "mystery meat."
Green onion pancakes were very good, but no hot mustard to dip them in ("they were out.")
Combo fried rice had a weird flavor.

Lot's of better Chinese restaurants around. I don't understand why this one is generally very busy with Gringos who come from other areas of SF just for this restaurant.
author: Adam G.

description:
The food is great but when I went there today and waited for one hour outside in the wind with my cane because I was asking for a table of one.  They had many tables for two. So I waited and waited and waited, while two people went in and took a table for four. Seriously, after an hour I finally got in and was shocked to see one man at a table for four.  

I wish I were Chinese, I really do, but I wasn't blessed that way.  At this place, I recommend taking an Asian friend with you to get a table sooner. Maybe take a man.
author: Pat P.

description: Tiny restaurant, the tables and chairs were sticky to touch. But the food is great. We ordered fried chicken and the potstickers. They were both delicious. The fried chicken is crispy with the sticky sweet sauce. The potstickers had perfect skin and the meat was juicy. I will come back.
author: Melissa C.

description:
Do not be fooled by anyone waiting outside for a table. It's absolutely not worth the wait. I'm convinced this is due to Shanghai Dumpling King being temporarily closed down the block and people trying to fulfill their xiao long bao fix. It's also a hole in the wall with minimal seating available. 

The dishes are affordable but each was more disappointing than the next. The xiao long bao leave much to be desired. My wrapper was a bit tough to chew through and the pork needs flavor. I did not receive the usual vinegar to dip in and It wasn't until after we finished our dumplings that i saw another table receive dipping sauce. Thought they didn't have any! The chicken wings and the majority of their spicy dishes are as spicy as Mission Chinese, yet no where as good. Go to San Tung for chicken wings.

The service was almost offensive! It makes me laugh now but i actually cancelled my last dish because i couldn't justify eating there any longer. It didn't matter since it seemed like she never put in my order anyways. I go to a lot of small, asian restaurants and do not expect stellar service. This place though - ridiculous. Someone help this poor woman out of whatever rut she is in that causes her to drift through the restaurant with not a care in the world.

If you're considering eating at Shanghai House then you're somewhere near the Richmond district and have plenty of other options for dinner.
author: Samantha L.

description:
I will get on a bus, sit for 45 minutes, get the Dry Fried Wings and get back on the bus. That's how sticky, delicious and addictive they are. After sampling wings from all over the city and thumbing my nose at San Tung and hearting the ones in Soma's SO ... these are worth traveling for.

But and it's a big BUT ... I just can't shake how lame Shanghai House's service is. The same grumpy lady is here every time I walk in. She's brusque and has never come close to a resemblance of a smile. I knew the wings took sweet sweet time so I called in an order in advance as I made my way over. When I got there, she acknowledged that I had placed the order. Then I got the sinking feeling she didn't relay it to the kitchen until I got there which defeats the whole purpose of ordering it ahead of time. So I awkwardly stood there in the narrow space by the cash register for nearly another half hour waiting for a single order of wings as others' came out to their tables over and over again. Waste. Of. Time.
author: Faith Y.

description:
if dumpling empire in ssf and shanghai house had a baby it would be the best looking chinese carb baby EVER.  

shanghai house on the other hand is SO good at their xlb and even better at their panfried dumplings.  they came out SO perfectly crispy on the sides and each one of them are perfectly shaped and juicy. 

my friend and i got the soup dumpling, green onion pancake, and panfried dumplings to share and i was disappointed with the green onion pancake because i like mine more  flaky and less dense, and the flavor was just off, the soup dumplings were good, and the grand finale was definitely the panfried dumplings.  

wouldn't mind coming back to give other items on the menu a try :)
author: Alice C.

description:
I usually come here once a month and order the same items: chicken wings, soup dumpling, and the soup noodle with snow peas and pork.

The service: don't expect excellent service from this Chinese restaurant. The restaurant is usually run by the lady and on a rare occasions with another young man who appears to her son. Service can be slow when the lady is taking orders for another table, handling the transaction, handling calls for to go orders. You need to take the initiative to get her attention. She's generally nice without any sign of attitude. 

The chicken wings may be the most popular items here. The wings have a crunch crust from frying. The wings marinated and salted well enough, sometimes a bit too much. The wings are then glazed with caramelized sugar sprinkled with chilli pepper and basil flakes that you can dip the wings in over and over again. These bone-in chicken wings are generous in size.

The flavor of steamed soup dumpling is great but the wrap is not. These soup dumplings sometimes do not survive the pick up test and break at the bottom. I use a spoon and chopstick to pick them up.

Overall it's decent enough that people are willing to wait in line for 30 minutes to get in. Give it a try.
author: Ivan L.

description: The place is quite small and there is only one path in the middle and tables are placed to the side. Service is a bit slow because there is only one waiter. The shanghai dumplings are amazing almost as good as din tai fung. Food 4.5 stars. Service 3 stars. Cleanliness 5 stars.
author: Brian C.

description:
Delicious. One of my favorite Chinese restaurants in the city. Everything we ordered was delicious, so I don't think you can go wrong. 

Family friendly- they even have a high chair. Phew!
author: Karla R.

description: I come here for the dry fried chicken wings. They're good but the menu prices here are incorrect. It's actually about double. On top of that I just ordered pork chow mein and they gave me chicken. WTF! I don't want to eat chicken with chicken
author: Timur P.

description:
My friend suggested Shanghai House because I had a craving for Shanghai Dumplings. This place did not disappoint. 

Shanghai Dumplings (XLB) -- lots of soup and meat, great balance of warm soup and gingered vinegar dipping sauce.

Green Onion Pancakes -- thin and slightly crunchy pancake, great with hot sauce. 

Pork&Veggie Potstickers -- savory pork, moist dumpling skin fried to crunchy perfection.

Shanghai Noodles -- udon sized noodles stir fried with veggies. Good but not my favorite.
author: Elaine N.

description:
So the xiao long bao up the street is slightly better, but seriously, who's counting when both these places are MILES ahead of anything else this side of the Pacific. go to whichever one has a shorter line.

Yes, long wait, but worth it, and nice not to be rushed out when you're done (especially when there's good tea).

Order the dumplings and the fried chicken wings, and split (one is big enough for four people) "the doughnut".
author: Mike V.

description:
I came here tonight because I had a craving for XLB (Shanghai dumplings). Buy, did I find the ones here very disappointing. Each dumpling had noticeably way more skin than meat inside. I dare say the amount of meat inside each is minimal compared to those I had elsewhere.

On top of that, the lady server was far from what I would call congenial in her service demeanour.

Definitely need to remember not to come back (or at least not for their XLB'S).
author: H K.

description: Don't get me wrong, but the dry-fried chicken is amazing, but the service is eh...There's only 1 person serving all of the tables and also managing the take-outs. The place is pretty small and crowded, if you want to come here to eat with a large party, do come early!
author: Lynda Z.

description:
Three words! Dry Fried Flounder. Don't go in here trying to play games... They don't play games... They fry flounder to crispy perfection and lace it with chillies cut with sweet sauce.. Service was with a smile. A must try for flounder lovers such as my self. 
3/10 on the spice wrack.
author: Nathan B.

description:
Came here with the bf on a Saturday at 12pm and there was already a wait! 

We got a order of XLB, tan tan noodles and dried fried chicken wings. The dried fried chicken wings taste very similar to San Tung. BUT the wings and drunksticks are HUGE. You're definitely getting that bang for the buck.The tan tan noodles are average. Nothing special. It lacked flavor. XLB are juicy and delicious! I'd definitely consider going to Shanghai House instead of that crazy wait at Shanghai Dumpling King down the street. The XLB definitely are comparable in taste and quality. 

The place is very small. They literally squeezed in as many tables as they could. I was seated in the awkward table in the back. I had to get up a few times in order for the person sitting in the table next to me to get seated/leave. 

Service is meh. There's only one waitress, so it's definitely hard flagging her down. Food took about 15 minutes to arrive. 

I'm definitely coming back for the XLB and wanggggs!
author: Fanny H.

description: Rude workers. We walked in and asked for two, didn't even acknowledge us and told us to order before she even gave us menus.
author: Thanh T.

description:
Officially tried this place when Shanghai Dumpling King closed and we decided to come here for food.

We grabbed Shanghai Dumplings, Dry Fried Chicken Wings and this Vegetarian dish that consists of clear flat noodles (don't remember the exact name of this dish).

Shanghai Dumplings was a disappointment, it was pretty flavorless and doesn't come close to the ones from Shanghai Dumpling King.

Clear Noodles - This was also okay. I remember trying this dish before (a long while ago when I just popped in on friends eating.) and it was much better. 

Dry Fried Chicken Wings - A must have for any chicken wings lover. Hands down this itself deserves 5 STARS (just the other dishes weren't convincing haha).  Forget the lines at San Tung and come here for some amazing chicken wings.
author: Harriet W.

description:
Put simply, stale food with terrible service.

Upon walking into Shanghai House, we observed that they only provide single-use, wooden chopsticks for even dine-in customers. That wasn't a good sign. A decent restaurant should never provide those single-use chopsticks to dine-in customers. 

The overall quality was just mediocre, definitely not authentic "Shanghainese" food. We ordered:
1. XLB - the dough was a bit sticky to your teeth.

2. Meatballs ("Lion Heads") - tenderizer overused.

3. Fish fillet with wine sauce - mushy fish with too much wine and sugar.

4. Salty pork soup with bamboo shoots (Yan Du Xian) - upon serving, we noticed some fatty bits on the surface of the soup, which looked a bit gross. Worse, the pork tasted somewhat stale. The soup itself tasted like diluted sauce, not soup. After both of us had a couple bowls of soup, I decided to complain to the waiter (owner?) of the restaurant, because the soup wasn't cheap (in the $13-$16 range). I'd expect better.

What offended me the most is their service/attitude. Initially, not to make it a big deal in front of other customers, I just calmly suggested to the waiter/owner that the pork tasted a bit funny,  He did not say much, either reluctant to admit it or not understanding what I said. He simply walked away. 

Then I made my complaint to a waitress by plainly saying the pork isn't fresh.

"I don't want the soup. Or, at least, can you replace it?" I asked.

To my surprise, they said "we serve this everyday and no one has complained about it. And you have finished some of it already..." What? You made me to have unfresh meat, because you serve this everyday and no one has complained? Then again, they ignored my complaint and just walked away. 

A bad dish can be forgiven, but bad attitude is unacceptable. Using bad ingredients for a dish can be just an accident, which I can understand; but the attitude is their choice.
author: Gil W.

description:
But why the low ratings?

This place is small so seating is limited.  Make sure you get here I'd say before 7pm or after 8:15pm.

DO get the bean curd vegetarian dish- something people don't usually order but try it, it's a must.

DO get the meathballs-  these are big juicy balls.  If you like big juicy balls in your mouf, get this.  You won't regret it.

DON'T get the house special noodles- unless it's what you really want.  My bf thought these were the crispy pan fried noodles but nope.  What a fail.

DO get the dry fried chicken wings- better than San Tung.  BETTER THAN SAN TUNG. enough said.

DON'T get the sparerib-  Big slabs of unflavored meat. 

DO get the green onion pancake- nice and crispy, beautifully plated, decent taste.

DO get the mushu pork with wraps- it's like a pork wrap.  Stuff the wrap with the amount of meat your desire and eat!
author: Linda N.

description: Shanghai house is one of the Shanghainese restaurants where even my Shanghainese friends would say yes to. The have very good XLB and other authentic shanghainese food. It is pretty packed during the weekend lunch and dinner time though, so pick a time before or after rush hour if you don't want a long wait.
author: Vincy C.

description: The food here is good, but it's not so good that I'm willing to overlook the exceptionally poor service. Given that the restaurant is the size of a largish walk-in closet you'd think that everything would be attended to quickly and attentively but you'd be disappointed. In a small place you expect to wait for a table but you don't expect to wait ten minutes for menus, much longer for food and another twenty minutes for a check. If you enjoy good Chinese with a large side of irritation then by all means eat here but don't pretend there's not fifty other places in SF that are of comparable quality without the annoyances.
author: Ted S.

description:
Passable xiao long bao.

Duck was much more dry than expected, could be a style difference, but not at all what we were hoping.

Red bean crepe was an interesting concept marred by decidedly uninteresting execution.

Other than the decidedly average food at best, service was decent (hey this is a Chinese place we're talking about) and the restaurant, while a little small, was clean and otherwise well-run.
author: Brian W.

description:
Food was very substandard and awful. The waitress was mean and had a bad attitude and she literally threw the plate of food on our table twice!!!!

I saw them on "Check Please" on KQED and thought wow, nice local hole in the wall!

But man, it's small, the food sucks, and the service is suckier than the food.
author: Gangsta G.

description:
This place is tiny and hardly had a wait. There's not much space here so not that good if you're with a party of more than 4.

Reason why I only gave it three stars is that even though there weren't that many people here the service was still pretty slow. We could tell that our waitress was a little tired since it was almost the end of the day but I felt like we were waiting most of the time. We would get one entree of food and then finish it and then be waiting for the next dish. 

The XLB were my favorite but they weren't as good as the XLB of the other dumpling place down the street. It was tasty but didn't have that much soup inside. They also didn't give that much vinegar in our little sauce dish. 

The regular noodles were also pretty tasty. It wasn't super salty and had good flavor. I recommend it! 

Overall, this is a nice little restaurant if you want to sit down right away but you'll be waiting for your food to come out. It's also a little cheaper than other dumpling places I've been to around the area. Good alternative of you don't want to wait really long at the other dumpling place down the street. 

Pros:
-Not much wait to sit down 
-Tasty XLB 
-Good noodles 

Cons:
-Slow service 
-Cash only
author: Paul U.

description: The chicken wings here rivals those of San Tung. They're perfectly fried with a delicious sweet and sticky sauce. The average wait time for a table is around 15-20 minutes, unlike the hour waits at San Tung. The xlbs are delicious and the noodle dishes taste fantastic. This place serves hearty chinese meals leaving you full and satisfied after a visit.
author: Derrick W.

description: I had a really nice, and honestly better than expected meal at Shanghai House recently.  My first visit was for a late, 2pm lunch on a weekday- and the place was jam-packed even at this time.  I waited for maybe 5 minutes, and took a seat and decided on the general Tsao chicken lunch special and a plate of potstickers.  The portions were large and in charge and everything had great flavor.  Great value for the price.  Cash only.  I will return....
author: Andy S.

description: It was a great meal in a home style setting. It was satisfying and I was pleased with the selection and quality. The price was fair, too. So why am I not giving it 4 stars? First, the wait time. It is a popular place so I can understand a wait, but it is very disorganized; more like a line outside you have to stay in or lose your place. And standing on the curb in a line for 45 minutes is not fun; half star lost. At least set up some chairs for patrons to sit. Second, I did say the food is great but it is a tad oily, so if you are not used to that, your guts may complain later. If they reduced the grease factor 10% it would be perfect; half star because my guts have a vote.
author: Michael B.

description:
I couldn't decide between 2 stars or 3 stars; and don't know where to start! Lets start with the lines and work our way in.. 

First off, the food is good, overpriced, the service is poop, and the place is small with little walking space. This place is recommended for parties of 2-4, 5 max! If the restaurant is full, the first group will have to stand outside and wait in line. Though, there is no designated area to wait. If you're standing outside with your group, it looks like you're loitering. We came during dinner, just in time to beat the crowd. From what I witnessed by the windows, it was cold out. The second group of people that came in ended up coming into the restaurant to wait in the walkway and it seemed like they were also trying to cut the big group of people outside. 

My party of 5 was seated next to the door. For our table that seats 4, my cousin had to sit on the side where the walkway of the door is. The customers at the restaurant would be rude and pull the door in, hitting him instead of pushing. The restaurant should have a push/pull sign so customers know what to do without hitting others who are dining. When we first came, there were 2 tables often. The one next to the doorway and the table next to that one. We wanted the one inside because we knew someone had to be seated in the walkway, but she put us by the doorway which was very inconvenient. There seemed to only be 1 waitress and she was rude. She would see us waving her down then disappear into the back for a few mins. Come back out and talk to other customers who came in. Took us 5-10 mins to wave her down for the check and we were close to dine and dashing because it took so long. Took her 5 mins to come take our orders as well. 

 As for the food, it was delicious. My party and I did something similar to family-style, but it was little food for the 5 of us, I think. We ordered the Shanghai Dumplings, fried chicken wings, spicy noodles, and green onion pancakes from what I remember. All were great choices, delicious, but not enough for the party of 5 (but didn't want to order more because overpriced for it's portions). I ended up having to go next door to buy a sandwich. Surprisingly, located next to my favorite smoked salmon sandwich cafe (La Promenade). Popular for the Shanghai dumplings aka Xiao Long bao, I think the quality of it was average. Did not taste any different to other ones I've had. 

For the portion size, I felt that the food was overpriced. Service was crap, but food was good. Not worth it, and wouldn't recommend coming back here unless there is no wait and you want to spend your money on small portion sized food but good. Haha.
author: Mandy G.

description: Went across the street for purple cow. Cause my Korean bestfriend from mt. View wanted to try it out so bad. We were hungry. I end up calling my brother from San Francisco to see what is good to eat around. He told me to try this place out cause the dumpling is amazing. Went in there I think the place was going to close. But the server was so nice and told us we can still dine in. Sit down order the steam soup dumpling, and ask her what else is popular here. She told us to the their chicken wing. I told her ok. The. I order the combination frie rice. The frie rice was ok. Typical Chinese frie rice, the steam soup dumpling on the other hand was so juicy so good. Remind me of the steam dumpling I has when I visit Taiwan in march. So I Just has to order another one. As for the chicken is was too sweet for my taste but my kimchi friend love it so much she end up Togo the chicken wing.
author: Linda T.

description:
Finally had a chance to come here.  To be honest, I wasn't expecting much as King of Noodle and Dumpling Kitchen are my favorite places for hand cut noodles and Shanghai dumplings respectively and I've been to both places numerous times with zero failures.  

First off, our table almost got stolen by a chinaman lady that came after us.  She sat down without asking the servers and pretended nothing happened.  The wife had to say WTF biotch for her to move out the way.

Ordered Shanghai dumplings, pork&veggie dumplings and vegetable dumplings.  They brought this out without any vinegar and ginger.  Really?  This is a "dumpling house"???  Veggie dumplings, bland.  Shanghai dumplings didn't have the soupy flavor ask I've known it for.  Texture of the skin is a bit, just a bit on the thicker side, don't like.

Onion pancakes kinda burnt and dry.  Definitely not oily and yummy greasiness of other places.

No hot sauce or chili oil on the table.  Service on the sucky side.  Never refilled our tea, extra napkins, cared?

Sweet soy milk wasn't so sweet and had a bit of salt.  At the bottom was a bunch of regular sugar not dissolved.  Glass had some sugar all over it too.

Ok now for the good part...meaning bad.  The hand cut soup noodles (vegetable) included sauteed vegetables that were pretty greasy like wok fried.  The broth was brown and quite oily.  Didn't look healthy and wasn't tasty.  Sad.  Noodles were overdone, no chewy elastic texture, weak.  Dan Dan noodles had no flavor at all.  Just hints of the red chili peppers everywhere.  Seems like no love in these broths and noodles.  Seriously.  The cook came out and dropped off the noodles without saying anything.  I think he knew he didn't have the passion for putting love into his food.  Sad again.

Maybe I should of ordered fried chicken wings like every M**thaF**ker was but hey that ain't Shanghai?

My favorite place on this block is Kim Son.  And Balboa Green Garden Florist.

I'm glad real chinamans like me know where the dumplings are.  Oh no, non-chinamans reading my review might blow up my secret spots.  Shit, hey guys I'm just kidding.  This place has the BEST DUMPLINGS, don't go to King of Noodles or Dumpling Kitchen!!!

LOL!!!!  I"m such an asshole!!!
author: Kevin L.

description: Came in for lunch. Got the steamed pork dumplings. Very good. Also had greeon onion pancakes which were crispy and chewy. Also good quality. The Dry Fried Chicken wings though. I love chicken wings. These were delicious. Crispy and flavorful with a sweet and slightly slicy sauce. The chicken was juicey and tender.  Awesome. Only problem was the service. Askes for water at the start of the meal. Got it at the end. Eh.
author: Zachary H.

description:
Delicious Chinese food and not quite as hole in the wall as Kingdom of Dumplings :)

Fried chicken wings -- portions were large and fried chicken was super hot and juicy.  What else can you ask for?

Hand cut noodles -- delicious and chewy the way it's supposed to be!

String beans were unusually sweet.
author: Kathryn C.

description:
Torn between sub-four star reviews and rave reviews from friends who frequent the place, Shanghai House was one of those restaurants I was never sure about visiting. But, being in the area several months back, and in the mood for Chinese, I decided to give things a shot, ordering their [ Photo: http://instagram.com/p/Xjm5IUwfuB/ ]:

* Handcut Dandan Noodles - To this day, I'm still think they gave me the wrong dish, because my noodles were covered in a sweet and spicy sauce full of prawns, rather than a peanut sauce with, well, pork. So, whatever they did give me was not bad, but not great either.

* XLB - Not bad, and still sweeter than I'd prefer, but not as sweet, as, say, the ones at Shanghai Dumpling Shop or Dumpling House.

* Chicken Wings - There are so, so many places that do this in SF, and it's hard to properly compare them all when they're not actually eaten side by side. Time does unfortunate things with one's memories! That said, these were actually quite tasty, and on par, if not better than, what I remember of San Tung's and SO's.

In the end, at $28 for good amount of food, nothing really wowed me, making Shanghai House another one of the many okay Chinese restaurants I've been to in the Bay.

***Accessibility Info***

Venue - For a Chinese restaurant, they're actually pretty small, with seating arranged in such a way that only the seats down the middle aisle are really accessible. If they're packed (as is usually the case), you'll be better off closer to the door, rather than having to pardon your way into the back.

Bathroom - Didn't check them out, so I can't comment.
author: Johnny W.

description:
Shanghai House is the most authentic Shanghai-style Chinese restaurant I've been to since moving to America. The dumplings are good, the mushroom and winter-melon hot pot was great, and the rice is nice and fluffy. 

Most of the bad reviews are from people who were put off by the service. If you want someone to pat you on the back and tell you how special you are, go to PF Changs. If you want a real Shanghai dining experience, go to Shanghai House.
author: Brooke F.

description:
OOH WEE! XLB
(3.25  stars)

While walking around this neighborhood, I've discovered a great place while exploring in city suburbia. Who knew they'd be a great hidden treasure in city suburbia!!!!! And especially a place that servers some great XLB. The place was packed and there was no room to sit so an order to-go was ideal. 

- taste, delicious
- price, affordable
- service, semi-okay
- ambiance, small space (its as big as my livingroom/kitchen)

Shanghai Dumplings aka XLB ($5.95) - comes in 10 pieces. that's great price for such a delicious dumpling. definately not stingy! 

Mongolian Beef ($9.95) - way too spicy for my palate. i can barely eat a few bites before my palate goes on fire. they'll need to tone the heat down. OH YES, MINUS ONE STAR for the extreme spice. Did you know that they cook their mongolian beef with red chilli flakes AND jalapeno? jalapeno?!?!?!?! i found chopped pieces in my dish. absolutely, dislike.  Entrees do not come with rice so you might need to order a side of rice. 

I'd love to come here again for some dimsum. This time eating there at a table and trying other dimsum dishes. I'd prefer dimsum here over the entree dishes. When my friends want dimsum, i'll definately know a great place to take them.

Will i be back? OF COURSE

Until the next review...
author: Jane A.

description:
The food here is delish! The chicken wings are comparable to San Tung. I love this place because it's within walking distance from my apartment and I don't have to wait hours to get a table. 

If I keep raving about this place, then why did I only give it 3 stars? 

#1 My biggest pet peeve is the waitress. She is the only waitress and she has the biggest attitude problem. She looks like she hates her job, her life, the world! Every time I come in she starts speaking to me in Chinese. I politely say something in English (ex: "Table for 3 please.") which should be an indicator that I don't speak or understand Chinese. But she continues to talk in her native tongue. ARGH! Just for that, 90% of the time I end up ordering take out rather than deal with her. 

#2 The service is pretty slow. It can take 20+ minutes for food to arrive. You don't want to deal with me when I'm hungry!!!

#3 Cash only! Really?! It's the 21st century! Food trucks accept cards, why can't this place!?

Yet I still subject myself to this. That's how good the food is.
author: Nichole P.

description: Ordered dry chicken wings, tea duck, XLB, Seafood soup, and wine/sesame balls for dessert.  Came out to be about $60 for 2 people.  We definitely ordered too much.  The wings were yummy, super crunchy and tasty.   XLB was ok, a bit small.  The tea duck was really salty, it needed the steamed bun or rice to bring down the saltiness.  The wine/sesame ball soup was a bit weird so I only ate the sesame balls.  The soup, it was loaded with rice wine, enough for a quick buzz.
author: S F.

description:
Came here for lunch since we planned on going across the street to Purple Kow for drinks after wards.

Upon entering the restaurant, the female waitress/hostess was on her cell phone and ignored us. We stood there like idiots not sure if we were supposed to seat ourselves or to continue to wait. After what seems like an eternity (which is probably more like 5 minutes) with the already seated patrons looking at us... the chef (male worker) came out and noticed us. He motioned us to a table and started getting the attention the the female waitress to get off her phone. She looked irritated that he was telling her to get off her cellphone. 

Anyways... we ordered Shanghai Dumplings (xiao long bao), Hand Cut noodle and Potstickers.

The Shanghai Dumplings were ok. I prefer Shanghai Dumpling Kings a few blocks away more.

The Hand Cut Noodle was ok. Had a lot of cabbage and not enough noodle. 

The Potstickers were average.

They also accidentally gave us the vegetarian goose and when we pointed out that we did not order it... the lady kept asking us if we wanted to keep it. Which we did not want or we would've ordered it to begin with. At least she didn't charge us for it. 

All in all... I will not go back since Shanghai Dumpling King is only a few blocks away and taste much better and cheaper.
author: Mei C.

description:
Shanghai House is my GO TO place for Chinese food (especially the Xiao Long Bao). The food is cheap, tasty, and portions are good! I think the restaurant is a family business and during school breaks, her son and daughter come back to help wait tables. I always tip them well because I have never been dissatisfied with the service or the food.

My personal favorites include the green onion pancake, xiao long bao, beef and vermicelli in clay pot, and the savory rice rolls (only served on weekends for brunch/lunch)

My only complaint is the small square footage. The restaurant can only seat a little more than 20 people at a time, and it gets very busy on the weekends around the lunch hour. You may be left to wait for up to 45 minutes for a table of 3 or more.

I love, love, love this place and always be sure to get the hot sweet soy milk. Ahhh. It tastes so good on a cold and foggy day. This is my TOP CHOICE FOR SHANGHAI FOOD IN SF!! Highly recommend going at least 3 times with a friend or or two or three to explore the entire menu.
author: Gabriel C.

description:
My boyfriend and I always come here whenever we feel too lazy to cook or travel elsewhere to eat.  Don't let the waitress intimdates you.  Yes, she could be rude, she could be unattentive, she could be appear to be cold, but who cares, as long as the food is good, I am okay with her service.

My all time favorite here is Pan-Fried Buns.  They are so juice inside and crispy outside! It is a must order.  People also rave about the chicken wings, they are good but it is not something I usually order.  In my opinion, the chicken wings here are better than the San Tung place on Irving.

Try this place solely for the food, you won't regret!
author: Avril C.

description:
Ordered the dry fried chicken wings, it IS much more flavorful than San Tung.
It's better. 
XLB, I've had better, the skin was thick yet fragile. Be careful when picking up. 
Vegetarian Goose. Delicious! Similar to a dim sum, rolled tofu skin dish, except this is crispy and vegetarian. 
Pig Knuckle, we opted for the salt & pepper variant. Really good. Had enough to take home. 
We'll come back, try more dishes. Will not order the XLB again.
author: Geordie E.

description: Love this place! Their dried fried chicken is so tasty and addictive...so much better than San Tung! We also ordered the dried fried green beans (awesome), drunken chicken (good but Little Shanghai Restaurant in San Mateo makes the best), and steamed dumplings, aka shao laong bao (good but King of Dumplings down several blocks is slightly better). There were so many other dishes we'd like to try but there was only the two of us and all their dishes look pleasing. We were staring at our neighbor's dishes and they look delish! They were having the hand cut noodles, onion pancakes, tea duck with buns, and a few more I couldn't remember. Will most definitely be back to try some other dishes! Don't expect superior service from this place because they have a slight language barrier but they were nice and the food was delicious! :-) Cash Only!
author: Mimi C.

description: Yes, service may be lacking but that is almost a norm for places serving authentic (non-fusion) regional Chinese food. This place has all the regional specialties of Shamghai, Jiangsu and Zhejiang province. The soup dumplings are righteous. The dishes on the CHINESE menu are really amazing and authentic. The bamboo shoot and pork casserole are the best I have had (and yes, I am Chinese from Shanghai). The soup is made from pork meat and bones which is full of umami. And the meat the stewed in the casserole are then added and slow cooked in the stew so they are not "cooked-out", but still have a lot of texture and flavor. I rarely see a soup made with this labor-intense old way in any restaurant any more. And talking about price -- a big casserole for only $11, what more can you ask?! Hipsters please keep out and don't ruin it for me!!!
author: Fiona S.

description:
Poor customer service, a new low even for a Chinese restaurant. let me put it in context, 1) had to ask for menu 2) the owner/waitress took our extra chair without asking/saying a word, 3) then she took our white pepper shaker without asking 4) we had no conversation except in the end when she handed us the check, she said "thanks," or something to that effect

the food was alright, i've had better dumplings and XLBs, what makes this place stick out is the hand cut noodles, i havent had those state side yet
author: Long C.

description:
One unfortunate Saturday involving an older woman who can't drive resulted in a house with no water for 8 hours.  EIGHT hours, that's how long it takes the city of San Francisco to fix a pipe that provides water to dozens of families.

No water = no toilet use, showers, washing hands, etc.. and no cooking.  No cooking = a good reason to dine out.

The bf had been wanting shanghai dumplings for awhile, and my visit to Shanghai Dumpling King six blocks up from this place wasn't too great.  My friend said Shanghai House is her FAVORITE place for the dumplings so I decided to try it.

The place is definitely cleaner and more spacious than Shanghai Dumpling King.  The service was poor.. it took awhile to get menus and tea and for the waitress to even notice that we were ready to order.

The Shanghai dumplings were a little better than Shanghai Dumpling King.  The wrapper is thicker and none of them popped.  Every single drop of the soup went into my mouth.  Mmmm.

The tea smoked duck was good and as fatty as ducks come, and came with four plain buns.  I don't like fat, but I do love crispy skin, so I patiently removed the fat and savored the rest.  A little salty, but tasty.

The handcut noodles were a big no.  EXTREMELY greasy and tasted like chow fun.  It didn't look appetizing, and it wasn't.

Overall OK, but not good enough for me to come back.
author: Vivian H.

description: Stopped in with my guy RIGHT before closing on saturday night. Unfortunately they were only taking to-go orders but that didn't stop us (we had driven ALL the way out there... no way we were gonna leave empty-xiao-long-bao-handed). We placed two orders of the pork xiao long bao and an order of onion pancakes and proceeded to enjoy these right next door - la promenade cafe (which is super cute btw). I enjoyed their xiao long bao, but the filling could have been more flavorful. At 10 pieces for $6, this is a great deal. The onion pancakes were not good IMO (too gooey and thick, not like how I enjoy my onion pancakes, which is flaky and more crispy). I would definitely go back to see if a different batch tastes different. I'm also curious to try Shanghai Dumpling King next.
author: Corrina S.

description: We visited Shanghai house after seeing an episode of Check please! Bay Area... the soup dumplings the dry fried chicken wings and the fried dumplings were most recommended so we ordered those - they were all very very good! Actually, they were delicious! and I will definitely go back for those. We also tried a Shanghai fried noodle which was similar to a chow mein, it was very bland and needed lots of soy sauce... the restaurant seems to be known for 10 main dishes, some being the fried pancakes, the soup dumplings the fried wings, the wine steamed fish and pork knuckle. The service was terrible which was expected, so I did not complain or expect any different. There is only one server in the restaurant who does not speak much English and is very curt and short there was an hour wait for seating when we got there and the server had other patrons get up from their table and move to allow others to sit down. While we were dining a few new customers came in and our server shouted out "to go only" not even allowing the customers to ask how long the wait was or if they could have a table. The bad service did not upset nor disappoint me because I expected it already based on the TV show and going into it I knew the food would be good. I absolutely plan to go back for the delicious soup dumplings the fried chicken wings, the pork knuckle and the fried dumplings! However, I do not expect the service to change.
author: Jennifer S.

description:
Awful service and to be frank it seems like they aren't much concerned with serving customers who aren't Chinese.
