To start we had a (quiet, calm) kid with us and were about to be passed over in the wait for another family (who was Chinese) who had been waiting 15 minutes less. The other family very kindly insisted they seat us first as we were already there. They DID seat us first but then didn't come over. When said family did get seated 10-15 min later, the staff went to take their order before taking ours!
We has to catch them on their way from that table and ask to order.All of the other table's food came out before we had gotten anything as well. Then when our little guy spilled his water all over my aunt's plate and the table, they never even brought us a rag or replaced the plate and just let us dine in the pool.

The soup dumplings were good enough, but the rice cake dish, though it had a nice texture, was nothing to write home about. The sweet rice ball soup was interesting but also not phenomenal. Wanted to try the pan fried dumplings but our experience had been so lackluster we decided not to push our luck further.

Had better dim sum several places in laurel heights anyway. Just moved to the neighborhood but won't be coming back- which they clearly won't mind considering they didn't seem to want our business anyway.
author: Therese H.

description:
#13 on the 7x7 List: soup dumplings

Shanghai House has a few different menus that they drop on your table, so make sure to consult with your fellow tablemates.  

I didn't see "soup dumplings" on the list but that'sXLB's (xiao long bao / siu long baos) for the non-Chinese.

-Tasty? So juicy that my friend, who was a first-timer, bit right in the middle and caused an explosion of soup.  I teared up at the casualty...precious soup!!  

-Service:  Even with my broken high-school Mandarin and somehow broken English, the waitress understood and gave us good, friendly service.  We sat around a half hour after closing and she didn't ask us to leave

-Ambiance:  Tiny place.   Our table of 5 was considered the big table

-Worth the trip/try?  The bill was $12 a head after all our food (see below).  One more reason to love Chinese food. 

I can do 2 orders of XLB's all by myself and so can J.  We love XLBs. 

The Geen Onion Pancake was a crowd pleaser.  Not greasy, thick enough, and had a good crunch and chew.  

The Salt and Pepper Pig Knuckle was a "happy happenstance."  I had read the newspaper article posted at the restaurant's door and forgot about it as soon as I sat down, but when the waitress recommended it, I gave her the "gwai lo" test since we had two at the table .  She told me in Mandarin that Caucasians love this stuff!  

Pleasantly, it came out as a huge pork leg with tender shred-able meat and a highly crispy skin that you'd expect on roast pork (siu yook)
but it's one continuous crunchy piece!  Awesome.

Skip the Shanghai Fried Rice Cake.  Nothing special - just some glorified carbs with shreds of pork.

Chinese crepe with red bean - It was a good not-too-sweet finish to the meal but I think I have had better hong dau wor bang.

$12 per person for all that after a generous tip, everyone full to the gills...good times
author: Winnie L.

description: Great place for XLB and dry fried chicken wings.  The wings aren't quite as good as San Tung's, in my opinion, but if you're in the Richmond and don't want to cross the park and wait over an hour to get your dry fried chicken wings, this place has got you covered.  The XLBs are well spaced so that they dont stick together and tear while picking them up and taste great.  Green onion pancake was good too as well as sesame chicken and stir fried noodles shanghai style
author: Max K.

description:
Small, clean, tasty, and cheap. What a great combo. The Dry fried chicken was excellent. Nice juicy large chicken wings and drummet's. Sauce is a little on the sweet side but had nice flavor. the Soup Dumplings and the Pork knuckles are just pure perfection. The deep and succulent flavors of the Pork is just out of this world. 

Tip if you want a beer grab one from the market next door and just bring it inside.
author: Travis T.

description:
This small restaurant offers reasonable good Shanghai food. Xiao Lung Bao is usually good. Other dishes are OK. Noodle dishes are relatively limited in variety. I would give the food a 3.5 or even a 4 star on a good day.
The service, however, is pretty bad. The waitress (owner?) probably has not smiled in over a quarter of a century, at least not at the restaurant. She usually exhibits a "I don't give a damn" attitude while serving, taking orders etc. It makes you feel that the customers are intruding on her. Last time I went there, two days ago, there was many people waiting on the outside. While  I was waiting, a couple of tables finished their meals. But the waitress didn't bother to get them the check, clear the table and let the people waiting outside seated. She just didn't care about the people waiting. Finally the people who finished eating for about 15 minutes just left leaving the money on the table. That caused us to wait for an additional 10 minutes unnecessarily. If this woman is still the (only) waitress there, I will NOT go back.
Overall rating 1 star because of the poor service.
author: Tuck W.

description:
This place is like San Tung, but with more to offer than just Dry Fried Chicken Wings.

The xiaolong bao have good flavor but are slightly lacking in broth. The vegetarian goose is excellent. The tofu is crisp, the mushrooms are perfectly soft and chewy and the sauce is a good mixture of sweet and salty. Also tried the green onion pancake which was flaky and crispy without being dry at all. And finally the dry fried chicken wings are on par with San Tung with a good combination of crunch, sweet, salty, and spicy.
author: Tim W.

description:
Mayflower is gone, so I'm looking to fill the dim sum hole in my life.  Went here tonight. Ok, not really a dim sum place, BUT:

Pork and vegetable dumplings: good
XLB: Yay. No leakage, good flavor, I'm a fan.
Potstickers: Husband's all 'Potstickers? Really?' I did it anyway, sorry dude, and Oh My God GET the potstickers! They were wow!!  Small, delicious, perfectly pan fried morsels of goodness. 
Tan Tan noodles: Uhm, no.  Looked beautiful, taste...not so much. But you know, anything we had after the potstickers was not gonna be that good. 

Ok, not Mayflower. But I have a new potsticker place. 
Price? Ridiculously cheap.
Bonus: Purple Kow is across the street. Perfect meal? Potstickers at Shanghai House with boba from Purple Kow for dessert. Grin.
author: El B.

description:
I hate waiting for food, and we WAITED so long. 

There was only one lady working, and all the tables had customers with a few people waiting outside. She obviously does not have a sense of urgency because she moves like a turtle. She took forever to take our order, fill up our tea, bring our food, and everything else. What was supposed to be a 40 minute dinner turned into 1 1/2 hours. And I know why they're slow... it's because they want to give their "to-go" customers their food first (so they can make more money selling food through the phone and keep the actual people here waiting). 

So now the food.. the Xiao Lun Bao is pretty good, the skin was not too thick and the soup inside was good. We also ordered the Lion's Head, which is a meatball with bamboo inside a claypot. This dish was impressive. And we also had an appetizer, some kind of fish, i forgot the name. 

Tip: This place is CASH ONLY, and don't come here if you are hungry, because you'll starve. And you might get irritated like me..
author: Cara N.

description:
Wow, long ass motha fuggin' wait! First time stopping here and it was really awkward. We weren't greeted at the door and the lady left us standing there for a good ten minutes until she sat us at the open table were we could clearly see. 

Would have left a long time ago, but a friend's recommendation kept us there. 

Hmmm... What can I say... Everything was on point! We ordered probably the best Shanghai dumplings and their special house dressing dry chicken rubs and it was probably hands down one of the best I've had. The sauce was definitely the decision factor ! 

I guess it was "worth the wait."
author: David M.

description: Chicken wangs is a must try.  And their shanghai dumplings...mmmmm
author: Mary B.

description:
This place pales compared to Shanghai Dumpling King which is only 2 blocks over.

This place is a lot cleaner than Shanghai Dumpling King but you don't come to these places for the decor, you come for the food, right?

Their XLB is not bad but the skin is a bit thicker and the filling is less flavorful compared to Shanghai Dumpling King. I also had their chow mein. It was bland as hell.

Skip this place and head over two blocks for the real thing.
author: Andy W.

description:
Chicken wings were delicious...spicier than San Tung's without drowning in the sticky, heavy, sweetish sauce.  (They still have plenty of sauce, it's just not so difficult and messy!)  This will satisfy my craving for good chicken wings, without the ridiculous San Tung wait.  Service for lunch was pretty slow - it took about an hour from start to finish...only one waitress.  My two lunch partners in crime enjoyed their food as well (although the waitress gave one of them the wrong dish - but he ate it anyway and said it was really good).  They don't skimp on the portions.

I'll be back to order take-out when I'm craving those wings (and maybe I'll add some veggies next time..).
author: Caroline K.

description:
Great place to go for brunch. It's reasonably priced an is very filing. The dumplings are my favorite here, and so is the soy based soup. 

This place gets pretty packed, and seating can take anywhere from 10-20 minutes. They are extremely under staffed with only one or two people taking orders ect. and can be hard to get a hold of them on a busy day. You literally have to walk up to them and tell them how many people are with you waiting to be seated. Once you get seated, choose quickly and get your order going! 

For me, the wait is totally worth it. Even with a crowd waiting outside, they aren't the type of that rushes you the check. 
If you have some time, go!
author: Momoe K.

description:
Shanghai House packs a whole lot of yummy into a tiny little place! I came here with my girlfriends on a day where we were basically eating up all of San Francisco. Even after a day of packing ourselves with food, we still had an appetite for this place! 

XLB was great here, I do like the ones from Kingdom of Dumpling better but these were a good start to our meal. Now, potstickers are probably the last thing I would order at a Chinese restaurant for fear of frozen/not-good sides. However, the potstickers here were surprisingly delectable, with the right amount of crisp and a yummy inside. Hand Cut Noodles were VERY good here. I am a big fan of Mandarin/Taiwanese style noodles and these were a great filler to the whole meal. 

Now the big question might be in question of their chicken and if it beats the almighty San Tung. Not having tried San Tung myself I am not sure, however this chicken did make me a believer. I'm usually not a big fan of fried chicken wings however the spicy, sweet, crispy goodness definitely converted me. I'll just have to try San Tung and put it to the test! Caution to the wings is that these are SPICY so be ready fill up on your tea and ask for some water. 

My group was actually lucky that we didn't have to wait. It does get a little awkward with people standing around waiting for a table, so try to come early to beat the traffic. 
I would definitely recommend this little place to anyone looking for good Chinese eats!
author: Tracy Joy K.

description:
I've learned to be cautious while reading yelp reviews. That being said, feel free to be cautious reading mine. Here goes:

I've read on Yelp that this place has bad service and are very rude. Not true. Though there was only one waitress and many others that run food, it is sufficient. Sure you need to ask for your check or ask to order, but I don't think it was anywhere close. Perhaps they fired the mean person others have referred to.

Since I rate on food only, I would say this place is a "yay! i'm a fan." because their xiao long bao is actually pretty good. My friend said that it was better than Shanghai Dumpling King, which left me aghast. But, when examined objectively, she may be right on some level. I felt the skin was better at SDK (chewier? my friend said it was thinner at SH but... I don't know if I'd agree on that) but the soup and ratio of meat (less here) was better. 4/5

Had these two other dishes that were not so great. One was the rice cake with veggies and meat. The rice cake wasn't as chewy as other places I have eaten at. The other was some noodle dish with greens which was actually pretty good but a bit oily. Rice cake was a 2/5; noodle dish 4/5. 

Regrets: totally forgot about the chicken wings. :(
author: Vicki T.

description:
This place is usually the first thing that comes to my mind when I'm hungry or starving in class. I live down the street with my two other roommates who love this place as much as I do. The favorites: The pork dumplings (duh- 5$ for 10!), the onion pancakes, chicken wings, and the spicy chicken with shrimp (big and juicy too!) and eggplant. Plus RICE. I think I've been here more than 4 times already so I can say they're consistently all yummy. Their one soy milk drink is pretty good too.

Remember its Cash only!

Love this place and is perfect for poor college students. Definitely makes my day and is so conveniently next to the Bank of America atm machines!

Enjoy!
author: Lisa L.

description: This place never disappoints.  Ordering the Soup Dumplings is a must.  Best green onion pancake and really loved the string beans.  Tons of flavor and great value.  BYOB is nice too.
author: Hollie A.

description:
Another update: Been back several times since my last update and it's become a favorite for me in the city. We got lucky on this cold Saturday night, but we got front row parking. Whaaaaaaaaat. Food tasted really good, but unfortunately, everything wasn't piping hot like it usually is. 

Service was a little slow so I wouldn't come here if you were in a time crunch. There's only one lady that takes your order and understands English.

The dry chicken wings are still better than San Tung's IMO along with the friends I was with :) So definitely get those!
author: Ling H.

description: Terrible customer service the asian lady basically threw the menus at us and when we ordered our food (which was too dry) we asked for water when she brought the food we reminded her about the water she didn't bring the water until we had finished our meal and not like it was packed there was only about one other table in use she scowled at us when we asked for the check , would not recommend save your money and go elsewhere
author: Leslie V.

description:
Love this place. I can't believe I haven't reviewed it yet. 

Definitely my dumpling spot back home. It's super small, but clean ... and that's always a plus in a Chinese restaurant ... The only negative I can think of is the long wait sometimes. Good thing Purple Kow is right across the street! :)

My favorite dishes are the small dumplings (xiao long baos) and the Shanghai Noodle dish. 

Can't wait to go back!
author: Chrisy Y.

description:
Man I really dont know what happened to this place. I used to come here about 2-3 times a month and the food was pretty consistently good. Fast forward almost a year and I went to try it on a Friday night. There was no more wait which was what drove me away before. Got seated right away with my girlfriend and ordered 3 items we've ordered many times before.

Shanghai Dumpling, Saute String Beans, and Dry Fry Chicken

The shanghai dumplings were juicy, yes, but the meat was also not solid at all. For those of you who've had a good shanghai dumpling, you get a you get a nice flavorful somewhat firm meat and some soup. This one was basically all soup and very liquid like meat. Okay thats fine move onto the string beans.
The string beans were really salty. I usually dont even eat too much rice but i had to order 2 bowls to share with my girlfriend because it was just that salty. 
The last and what made me the most disappointed was the dry fry chicken wings. This place used to have huge and amazing chicken wings to the point that i liked it better than san tung chicken wings but this time it didnt even come close. It tasted as if they used sugar twice instead of sugar and salt. It was a very sweet sauce almost inedible. Luckily i had the very salty string beans to counterbalance the sweet. If i was eating with my mother or my brother i know they would have complained and asked for another plate or a refund but i dont have enough courage to do that so my girlfriend and i just finished our meal in disappointment. 

Will likely be my last trip there after being one of my favorite places. Dont forget the usual mediocre service where the server lady just gives you the same stone faced look no matter what you say.
author: Galen W.

description: Really really cheap XLB here which is why I love it! Their regular dumplings are also delicious, so I'd definitely come here to get these two dishes. One of my other favorites is the spicy meat/tendon appetizer. The restaurant is small so you might have to wait... good thing Purple Cow (boba) is right across the street so you can go get boba and then you're table should be ready.
author: Jessica X.

description: I would give one star if possible. I called for a take out order and asked what was in the Shanghai style noodles and if I could get chicken instead of pork....can u believe she hung up on me upon my second question?! Talk about horrible customer service. I've been here before and although they are literally own the street I'll NEVER patronize that establishment again. Don't bother with this place. Go to Shanghai Dumpling King a two blocks east on balboa.
author: Vanessa R.

description:
Ordered a bunch of stuff but notably, the sweet and sour spareribs and xiao long baos were in the spotlight for me. THE SPARERIBS. It's exactly what I've been looking for, and what I'm craving now! It's the perfect combo of vinegar-y and sweetness with neither being overwhelming.

Also got the xiao long bao which is where the party's at since each table dining there that night had an order. It was legit :) Succulent juicy xiao long baos, just as it should be. I'll be back B)
author: C. C.

description:
There's a word called 'consistency' and Shanghai House doth not has it. 

I've been here now on several occasions, and up until my visit yesterday, my overall verdict is that SH is enjoyable and a good alternative to Shanghai Dumpling King a few blocks down the street. I even brought my parents here from the South Bay, and the XLB was judged to be so tasty that we added to our order.

But yesterday... I don't know what happened. First off, zero greeting whatsoever by the only lady holding it down solo. She just tossed the menus on our table. I know it's a Chinese place so had no expectations of superior service, but really? Not even a 'hi'? Dislike. Also, the place was not busy whatsoever. There were 3 tables occupied. Yet she preferred to take hiding behind a huge indoor plant that's been conveniently placed on the cash register counter, thus blocking her from overseeing the dining floor. It was difficult to get her attention when we wanted our check, and I could see behind the plant she was wolfing down a bowl of soup or something.

Moving on..The XLB was the real disappointment, however. They were tiny and flat instead of round and plumpy. It was almost an art to peel off the baos without tearing the bottom off of the steamer that's only been lined with parchment paper. Plus the ones that did succeed in landing in my soup spoon in one piece had such little juice, it almost didn't matter how meticulously you removed the baos.

The Green Onion Pancakes and the Green Beans with Veggies and Tofu dishes were just average. It's not like they're easy to mess up anyways. Tofu Seafood Soup was just okay too. 

This was really a 2-star experience. Added one star due to nostalgia of good past experiences. Get your act together! But for now, I'm going to Shanghai Dumpling King going forward.
author: Jing D.

description:
I've been here a couple of times for dinner and the food and service have usually been great. The convenient location across the street from Purple Kow (and the fact that they don't care if you bring the drinks in to enjoy with your dinner) make it a nice spot to just hangout and grub when there's no seating left at PKow.

Today must have been an off day though because the wait time for food from ordering to table delivery was 30+ minutes. Other tables who came in after us were served promptly, but my table and another in front of us seemed to be forgotten by the lone server and the seemingly overstaffed kitchen (didn't see much cooking going on as I passed by on the way to the bathroom). 

The food was good as always once it got to our table (Dry Fried Chicken Wings that rival San Tung's) but the wait left a bitter taste in my mouth. As much as I want to like Shanghai House, this experience made me reconsider ever going back again.
author: Greg C.

description:
I love this place.  Their shanghai dumplings are so good, full of soup and so tasty.  all their cold appetizers are awesome.  one star off for their bland noodles.  no matter what kind of noodle you order, shanghai noodes, rice cake, or their noodle soups, its just not salty enough.   but i guess that means they dont put msg?  a lot of people seem to like the chicken wings, but i think san tung makes them better.
i dont mind the service, its a chinese restaurant, what do people expect?
author: Karen L.

description: This small restaurant has good Shanghainese food. Had some noodles, pork knuckle, spinach, rice, XLB's, and soy bean soup. I really enjoy this kind of food.
author: Denise C.

description: I called in to order to go. like 30 mins later, I went there to pick up but the order was not done yet. Plus the service was horrible right when I went in. The waitress and l made eye contact, I greet & she ignored me and go on with serving other people. I told her I ordered some XLB, but she barely respond. Maybe she have bad service for take-out customers because she won't get a tip (and she deserve none). If those darn XLB isn't that good I won't be coming back.
author: Lily C.

description:
Dumplings are DELISH. Green beans were also really great - huge serving too so more than enough to share amongst a table of friends.

Do yourself a favor and get the house-made soy milk, you won't regret it! The egg-puffs are  a yummy & light desert option.

Note: They are cash ONLY, make sure everyone in your party brings enough dollars.
author: Grace M.

description:
We were driving back home from Point Reyes when dinner time hit. I did a quick search on yelp for "knife cut noodles" and found this place. We found parking after circling a few times and then waited for a table. 

Good things first: knife cut noodles were effing awesome. DELICIOUS!!!

Bad things next: everything else was horrendous. We ordered the XLB and the skins were soggy... and the dumplings didn't contain any soup. UGH!!! The service was excruciating slow. No sign up sheet so everyone had to figure out who was in what order in line. The owner-lady had a bad attitude and wouldn't even smile. We ordered this extremely Shanghai-nese dish called "kou fu" and it was inedible. It had a funky herby smell and it was served soupy and warm when traditionally its chilled and dry. YECHE!!

Whole experience summed up to: order only the knife cut noodles.
author: Vicky L.

description:
I am going to say two things, shanghai dumplings and chicken wings.  5 stars! they have got my vote.

If I factor in their noodle dishes, it drops to a 4 because nothing special about their noodle dishes.  I will do them the service of rating their specialties and keep it 5 stars
author: Will I A m.

description: Great food! The service isn't quite there but they take your order and bring your food soooo at least they cover the basics.
author: Divina M.

description: Me and my boyfriend come here all the time!! Yes it's one server that works really hard and does have the same expression, but she always knows my order and i feel we have a rapport. We always order dry fried chicken wings, chicken fried rice with no eggs (i'm allergic) and the vegetarian spring rolls. I love it with our favorite boba place across the street. It is a small place if you choose to dine in, but if you can try the food during the lunch specials m-f 11-3, its worth it. Best $7-$9 you'll spend per person!
author: Oluyemi O.

description:
We walked in for an early dinner at 5 and caught the kitchen by complete surprise.  The boss/ waitress wasn't even there yet...had to place our order in my super funky broken mandarin, with the lady in the kitchen...funny.

Food...tooook...foreveeeeeeeer...and just one dish at a time...but wait was TOTALLY worth it!  

Dry Fry Chicken Wings...bomb!  Covered in a sweet sugary, spicy coating.  Pretty spicy and so so addicting!  Since Yelpers rave about their sliced noodles, we had to try...oh so comforting on a cold night like today...makes you feel like you were alone so that you could really slurp it up!  Shanghai Chow Mein was good too- not the boring noodles like most chinese restaurants- shanghai noodles are thicker and slightly chewier.

Will be back for more!
author: Judy K.

description:
Came here on a Sunday afternoon. The review posted on the window says in block letters-Worth the WAIT. The suckers in us 
waited 20 min.

DanDan noodles - when it came, my bf asked, what is it supposed to be? After tasting it is still a mystery.

Bean curd puff - it's piping hot...not sure why, and it's so sweet we were guzzling tea.

Salty sticky rice ball - puny and the rice too soggy,

Xiao long bao - not bad, but have tasted better.

No wonder the reviews on the window all date before 2008...
author: daphne w.

description: food was just ok, I must be there on their one-off type of a day.
author: P C.

description: We were happy to find a place that offers Pan fried dumplings. We ordered rice cakes, shanghai noodles and salty soy milk. Food was decent and somewhat tasty when it was hot. We were thinking that we would come back. Well... when I left to use the restroom which was upstairs. On my way I passed the kitchen... let's just say that I immediately changed my mind about the place. I passed rotten food and a sink filled with food scraps and dirty water... then there was the waiter scooping steam rice onto a plate next to the garbage bag with I don't know why it was placed on the counter. When I got upstairs, two older men with cigarettes in their mouth were talking and making dumplings right outside the restroom. The tray of dumplings was placed next to an open door to the balcony?.. we paid, we left, we deleted the address of the restaurant. Thank god I have not had any serious stomach issue since.
author: Suzanne Y.

description:
Went here with my wife after catching a movie at the Balboa Twin across the street.  Got takeout since it was about 9pm and they were closing at 9:30pm.  Ordered kung pao chicken, combo chow mein, and some shanghai soup dumplings (xiao long bao).

The food didn't taste that great...and tasted even worse coming up.  I was up all night with food poisoning vomiting.  The kung pao was one of the worst I've ever had, and the filling on the soup dumplings was all mushy.  Threw all the leftovers away immediately in the morning.

Needless to say, we won't be going back...
author: Kevin B.

description:
I feel like I was robbed coming to this place.  The self acclaimed restaurant reviews in the windows are no indication of the inferno of rage I felt inside the place.  I'm a 6th generation San Franciscan and I've eaten at my fair share of restaurants. I understand that places like this don't usually have the best service, but this place just made me incredibly angry thinking that I had to pay for the meal after we were done.  No acknowledgement when we walked in, just a stare with and undesirable scowl which really set the mood for the rest of the meal.  

       Lets talk about the reviews plastered all over the restaurant.  I've seen this at other places, trying to mentally trick you into thinking their food was sent down from the heavens and you should feel so lucky to taste the dishes that are so blessed.  The problem was that there wasn't any taste and it didn't come from the heavens, it came from Shanghai House and it sucked.  The food was bland, came out in a strange order of entrees to appetizers to entrees and for good measure back to appetizers.  The spicy eggplant was over cooked and the sauce had a gelatin consistency.  I'm getting angry just writing this, I'll just wrap it up.  Stay away from this bait and switch restaurant.  The service and food is awful and the whole place feels unwelcoming.
author: Vincent P.

description:
I was in the area and chose this place over Shanghai Dumpling King since I didn't feel like walking down a few more blocks.

It was lunchtime and the place was fairly busy but not packed so I was able to sit down right away. I ordered the xiao long bao and a plate of mapo tofu.

The xiao long bao tore rather easily. When I picked some of them up, they would partially stick to the sheet underneath, causing them to rip and spill out a bit. To be fair, the ones which didn't rip were pretty flavorful so at least they have that working for them. The mapo tofu was decent, but I felt like it was mostly sauce and less tofu. At least it was a lunch special so it was fairly cheap.

The service could be better. The woman working here during lunch provides you everything you need at the beginning but she seems rather apathetic about you for the rest of your meal.

Overall, a decent meal, but I probably should've walked a few more blocks for a more enjoyable experience.
author: Allen C.

description:
I've been here five or six times already and love it every time. Good, authentic Chinese food in a clean, well-lit restaurant at a reasonable price. Who could ask for more? 

The noodles dishes really shine here. Get the beef noodle soup with the hand-cut noodles. Really tasty, generous portions of meat, and the broth is thick and flavorful.

If you're there in the morning, enjoy a glass of their sweet soymilk. They have Chinese doughnut on order (you tiao) which goes great! 

They have great xiao long bao and green onion pancake. 

One small note that if you want regular dumplings, I'd probably go somewhere else. I found them to be somewhat bland and average.
author: Ada C.

description: RUDE. RUDE. RUDE. I picked up a to go order these evening and the lady working there was probably the rudest woman I have ever encountered. No hello, please or thank you. If looks could kill -  I would be 6 ft under tonight. The only thing she grunted at me was '$34 dolla' and sneakily placed my change out of my reach. While I was waiting, I observed her serve the table's  - she basically thru the menu's at people, slammed the tableware down and communicated in a 'you're an inconvenience' tone to people. I then saw her move a table of 2 who were mid-dinner to a smaller table so she could seat a larger party  - wow, money over manners I guess!! The food sucked too - Shanghai Dumpling King a couple of blocks up the street is superior!
author: A O.

description:
Ain't no thang like their [super crunchy] fried chicken wangs ;))) mhmmm

The chicken wings are huge pieces & the portion size for an order is a full large plate, so it's great for sharing between 2-3 people. The sauce has a lot of flavor- savory, sweet & spicy [with whole peppers] that is more of a syrup consistency. It's delicious & ameowzing all around! 

The chicken wings are made to order so don't come on an empty stomach. Expect the order to take between 20mins+, but it's worth the wait. I promise.
author: Lisas N.

description:
Racists mofos.  My mom, boyfriend (who happens to be Haitian), and I came here to eat and it took FOREVER for us to get all our food.  My boyfriend's dish was the last to arrive and it wasn't even what he ordered!  He wanted to ADD broccoli to his dish and after waiting almost 30 min, when his dish arrived, they said it doesn't come the way he requested.  DUH!  Which is why he wanted to add it at an extra cost.

Being mandarin, I grew up on this type of food and it is definitely not as good as Shanghai Dumpling King.  The dumplings were ok and the "Chinese Donut" was too oily.  Fried Tofu was really bland.

Horrible service, ok food, metered parking even on holidays, and racists mofos.  NEVER AGAIN!
author: Helen S.

description:
Overall, good food! Soup dumplings weren't the best, but I liked everything else. Their vegetarian goose and their rice roll (fan tuan) are two of my favorites when it comes to breakfast items/small eats.

JONASAPPROVED!
author: Jonas T.

description:
Definitely a good place to get some good soup dumplings.  I'm not sure if I like these soup dumplings better or the one over at Shanghai Dumpling House.  But these were definitely flavorful.  We had all sorts of other dishes, but the dishes that I thought were good was the fried chicken wings, beef noodle dish and spareribs.  

The place is small but its clean.  And it definitely wasn't busy right away at 6pm on a Wednesday night.
author: Kevin W.

description:
I love this place,

i usually get the dry fried chicken wings, get ready to have your mouth explode with flavor. I used to always goto San Tung, loved their wings, but i prefer Shangai, tastes better and theres never a crazy wait.

I tried the fish and veggie dish today, and i had to stop one of the cooks on his way handing plates to other customers, had to give him proper respect.

The food here tastes very fresh, flavorful, and has good prices and filling portions. 

Ive seen some reviews saying that the waitress is rude. I would have to disagree. Sometimes when your food is bomb you dont have to stroke someones ego like a housecat. She always smiles and says thank you, show respect to a boss tho, she has 8 arms, and doesnt really make mistakes.

Lastly id say, why are you still reading this, if your hungry, or wanna impress somebody, go to Shanghai House.
author: Pete F.

description:
First time here with my cousin. It is a small hole in the wall but the food is pretty good

Got here around 7 pm and got seated at the last table and just missed the crowd.

Dry fried chicken wings were crispy and yes almost as good as the ones at San Tung across the park.

Sting beans with shrimp was yummy.

Vegetarian goose was better than expected.  Warm and crispy.

The lion head in the claypot was delicious.

Highly recommend you to give this place a try .
author: Jennifer T.

description:
Crappy food, crappier service. Dumplings are shitty here. If you want dumpling close to the real thing in shanghai, get the frozen ones at ranch 99 and steam them yourself .. The dumpling brand is from the famous NanXiang place in Shanghai.

Did I mention crappy food? Don't know what the fuss is about.
author: Catalina C.

description: The service was real bad, we ask for water for our tea, she took it never brought is back, look like the waitress don't care that much, we went there around 8 pm today, January 29, 2015, food was ok
author: John L.

description:
A lot of other people praise the dried fried chicken wings from other restaurants, but I will stand by Shanghai House.  Whenever I go, there are at least two staple items: chicken wings and xlb.

Xiao long bao: flavorful, a bit sweet, and the skin is just the right texture and thickness.

Dried fried chicken wings: very crunchy, not to be confused with crispy.  There's a physical feeling to it, not just a small wimpy sound.  The sauce (syrup really), unlike other restaurants, uses a lot of the chilis that are quite flavorful on their own.  The wings stay crunchy throughout the whole meal.  My favorite part is when the syrup cools and thickens up.  I slather it all over the wings and eat it last.

Also recommended...
Cucumber bean curd: I don't remember if this is the actual name, but it's cool and refreshing.

Hand-cut noodles: Any of the preparation styles are fine.  The noodles are nice and chewy.
author: Andrew Y.

description:
I've been here twice now, the first time because it was just across the street from Purple Kow, and the second because the bf and I loved their hand cut noodles so much we had to have it again. 

The first time we came, we ordered the hand cut noodles, green onion pancake and the xiao long bao. I've tried xlb at many places, and dare I say it, am a xlb snob. The xlb was OK, definitely not the greatest. The skin was a little on the thicker side and did not seem as flavorful as some others I've had. 

The green onion pancake was very crispy, and not too dough-y, exactly how a green onion pancake should be. The bf loved it and gobbled it down quickly. There are 8 slices of this, pretty generous I will say. 

The hand cut noodles are the star of the show. It comes steaming hot, and is just SOOO good. Thinking about it just makes my mouth water. Everything goes together so well in this dish. 

The second time we also ordered the bean curd salad - guess that was OK as well, just your average dish. I've heard the chicken wings are good, so that's something I'll have to try next time I'm up here. 

Service is pretty slow, even when the place isn't crowded, so be prepared to wait. I suggest getting some tea from Purple Kow beforehand and sipping your drink while you wait so you don't get hungry :)
author: Kimberly F.

description:
Keep in mind that my review is for very very particular items on the menu.  I'm a believer that no Chinese restaurant is ever good if you just randomly order shit that you think "looks good" - you need to know what they make really well and order that.

So I'm also going to say something blasphemous here: their chicken wings are crispier, tastier, and have a more complex flavor than San Tung.  These are definitely my new crack wangz.  

What you should get:
- Handcut noodles (the fried kind, not the ones in soup): they're like chow fun, but better because the noodles are fresh and very tender.  Great vegetable to noodle ratio too, not too starchy

- Dry fried chicken wings: the spicies just have more depth and the wings are cooked all the way through with care, while still maintaining tenderness.  The sauce isn't as sticky as San Tung, so be sure to scoop some of that sauce ALLLLL over your wangz

- XLB: dude, so juicy.  not too much meat.  all about the soup inside.  I know I know Shanghai Dumpling King up the block is more famous, but I think this place makes it with so much more care even though you'll notice that there's a lot less meat in each XLB

Other reviews mentioned that the service here is not very good, but have you EVER been to a Chinese restaurant where there was good service AND cheap AND authentic AND delicious?  No, I definitely have not experienced that in the United States... maybe only in Taipei.  You'll get acceptable service from the lady if you just smile and act very polite to her as you would your grandma.  

You know what?  I'm gonna go back there tonight for dinner... just because I'm salivating while I write this review.  Shiet
author: Anna T.

description:
If I can give half a star this place would get 3.5 stars.  I should have posted this years ago. I felt like eating some Xiao Long Baos and decided to come to this place since Shanghai Dumpling King had a line out the door.  I'm glad that we decided to on this place because I feel the food to be better. This place is small and had about 10 tables.

FOOD
I really like the food here. The xiao long baos tasted really fresh. I also had green onion pancake and a sweet and savory rice roll. IWe also had the wonton soup and that was good too. Just slightly on the salty side but good none the less. 

SERVICE
Although we were seated pretty quickly the place got packed pretty fast. Service here isn't something I would write home about. It's actually pretty bad but I come for the food.

Similar to most Chinese places I've eaten at, the service could have been a lot better.  Food was good so I'll be back.
author: kevin l.

description:
Came here for my sisters birthday. The place is pretty small-about 8 tables max. Service was so-so. There was a couple that sat down after us but there order was taken before ours-the lady taking the order made eye contact with me, knowing that we were ready. We ordered 5 dishes:

Shanghai pan fried noodles: no taste. Very bland

Green onion pancakes: decent 

Meatball pot: had 4 big meatballs but very bland. Looked better than it tasted.

Chicken wings: passable, but definitely had better.

Xiao long bao: best dish here. 

One thing I noticed and didn't like: the waitress took bowls from our table , didn't even bother to wash/wipe them and put them back on the dish rack. Even though we didn't use the bowls, it would have been nice to see her at least wiping them. Probably going to put them on other tables. 

Would I come back? Probably not. I rather go to the other shanghai place up the block.
author: L Q.

description:
FOOD:
1.) XLB = you know... was excited bc thot we were going to shanghai dumpling king! but yea their xlb's aren't really that good. I didn't get the slposion of hot soupy goodness in my mouth
2.) had an assortment of dishes like fried rice, noodles, rice cake, meatballs... none of it was to my liking. meh. 


SERVICE:
Good.

ATMOSPHERE:
Small little restaurant
author: Angela L.

description: Omgg! I love this place! The food is soooo good! Like omg. I really recommend this shrimp dish . I forgot wats it called but it has shrimp and i love the shanghai dumpling! ANDD i love the dry fried chicken wings! Soo gooooddd.(:  its hot ans sweet yummmyyy. Andd I LOVE LOVE LOVE THE DESSERT , EIGHT TREASURE SWEET STICKY RICE. They dont have these anywhere at all. They ony have it heree! This is somethibg u must try here! Its so goood. Overall this place is awesome . U must go here !
author: N S.

description:
Almost missed this place...it was smaller than I expected. Right across from Balboa Theatre.

We ordered: 

Dry Spicy Chicken Wings- crispy, crunchy, not too spicy, delicious...amazing...
Shanghai Dumplings- Scoop them into your spoon carefully then consume. There's soup inside! 
Green Onion Pancake- crispy 

Be careful...
- Food was really HOT (temperature wise)...might want to wait a little bit before consuming. 
- Service was...well no service...unless you ask for it

I want to try the other items on their menu. I also think this might be a good "to go" place...you may feel more comfortable eating at home than at the establishment (so you don't have to beg for more tea or your check). 

Overall the food makes up for the service. I will be back.
author: Erin C.

description: Some of the best Dumplings I've had in a while. Cash only. I'm lucky I went with my Chinese girlfriend because I would not be able to talk to them haha.
author: Jeromy G.

description: This is my go to place for shanghai food in the city. Everything here is authentic and delicious. The place seats about 15 people at most. I normally order the shanghai noodles, ja ja meen, XLB, soy milk, oily bread, and onion pan cake all in that order. family style! I would dock one star for the slow service but I won't since it's a local joint and been coming year for years. The food really makes up for the wait.
author: Kelly C.

description:
thanks to our real estate agent for introducing this place to us last nite.

our favorite dishes:
- vegetarian goose (served warm and with mushrooms)
- green onion pancake (the thin variety and not too greasy)
- shanghai dumplings (the hubby enjoyed them but we've had better)
- stir fried shrimp
- 5 spice beef (appetizer)
- bean thread noodles with cucumber (i loved this dish)

for dessert, enjoy the rice wine soup with black sesame balls.
author: Helen Y.

description:
My favorite foodie friend from SoCal suggested we go to Shanghai house since there are no great places you can get dim sum in LA.. She's been craving dumplings and needed to satisfy her craving before she left town again. I was running a little late, so she went ahead and placed the order for the following:

Pan cut noodles - Must get these! So yummy! I wish I could have this after a drunken night on the town. 

Dry chicken wings - Doesn't look too appetizing.. But these chicken wings are probably just as good as San Tung's but crispier and spicier!

Shanghai dumplings - I can see why she wanted these. So delicious!!!

Pork & vegetables pot-stickers - These tasted good as well. But I would have liked another order of the Shanghai Dumplings!

Stir-fried eggplant - this dish was good. It wasn't a stand out but definitely a good side dish. 

Mongolian beef - This dish was extra spicy! The kick basically took me out for awhile!

Green beans - Wow. What a simple yet crispy, refreshingly crunchy! Not the usual overcooked green beans you get. I highly recommend getting this along with the noodles and dry chicken wings!

Enjoy!
author: Anne T.

description:
03.21.10

Still on the dumplings craving train.  Next stop, Shanghai House.  But only because the place down the street is closed for vacation.

Food was three stars.  Service is at most one.  I think the owner just has a permanent sour look on her face.  Wish there was an app for that.

Pork/lettuce dumplings [http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Q25GDNRvf4dKzgwWli2oCg?select=cy-Gm21xePNF5nAKMd0mhw], nian gao [http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Q25GDNRvf4dKzgwWli2oCg?select=qP87cqvBrIT2kfWcaWTo6A], xiao long bao [http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Q25GDNRvf4dKzgwWli2oCg?select=_NmMJHvfeojLwPvN4W9ogQ] and some noodle dish [http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Q25GDNRvf4dKzgwWli2oCg?select=tn-WwPwkRiismohkQe83Zg].

Please don't spit in my food next time because we left a less than stellar tip...or better yet, I shouldn't have a next time.
author: Jenny L.

description: This review is strictly just food the food.The food is delicious- possibly the best xiao long bao in the city. You can't make reservations and it's cash only. Also, service is kinda slow, but there's only want lady working.
author: Michelle H.

description: The chicken chow mein here is awesome! The noodles were perfect and the sauce is delicious! Kung pao chicken was good too but super spicy, the hot and sour soup is spot on!!!!!  Definitely coming back!
author: Christi M.

description: We stopped in here because everything else in the area seemed dead minus a bar full of smoke. I have no regrets! I got the beef brisket soup. It was good except it wasn't spicy at all which is what I'm used to and was expecting. Still the portion was large and thr brisket juicy and plentiful. My friend got the sesame chicken which I gladly helped myself to. It was delicious. Crunchy and flavorful and very spicy. I ended mixing some of the sauce with my soup which turned my soup into a great dish too. Finally we got the veggie dumplings which were decent on its own and with the vinegar but again the magical sesame chicken sauce turned it into a different dish. One negative is that the food takes forever to come out so make sure you're not hungry or in a hurry when you arrive.
author: David L.

description:
I preferred the Shanghai dumplings (xiao long bao) at this location compared to Shanghai Dumpling King.  The skins were thinner, but still were sturdy enough.  I also enjoyed the taste of the broth more.  

However, the other food was just ok:
-- salt and pepper pork knuckles (these were too dry)
-- dan dan noodles
-- shang hai fried rice cake
-- shang hai hand pulled noodles

This place DOES take reservations, which is useful because it does get busy during lunchtime.
author: Jeanne L.

description:
very disappointed. just finished our meal & still no water or tea altho everyone else around us has water or tea altho we were the 2nd party to be seated. the waitress/owner keeps looking at our table while giving other people tea, knowing very well we have nothing to drink. it is worth noting that when we arrived, we greeted her & she actually said nothing to us. not even a smile. she didn't check on us once during our meal & when other people arrived she was all smiles & doted on them frequently. i normally don't review based on poor service but i got a personal vibe from her. never coming back. tofu soup was also too salty & i've had better pork dumplings.

after requesting, she finally brought us tea, but still no smile or kind attitude. what gives?

she just approached us & reached over us to get the menu we were holding onto (thinking we might order more - ha!) very impolitely. so not fair that she is treating the chinese family who arrived waaay after us appropriately. zero stars, really.
author: K-Y    j i L L y.

description:
Shanghai house is a small and oddly quiet restaurant. (You seriously get weirded out by hearing your own thoughts in this silent and sometimes empty restaurant) Although it's mostly empty, the service here is quite slow. Prices are ok, not as cheap as it's competitors near by but nonetheless the food is pretty good.

I ordered their dried fried chicken wings, green beans, and shanghai dumplings (XLB). All of the above are good. Their dried fried chicken wings are different from san tung because they're in bigger pieces and the skin is reminiscent of KFC. It is more crunchy and battered and has a bit of spice/kick to it in contrast to it's sweet molasses flavor. 

The string beans aren't flash fried and just sautéed with onions and bell peppers. As for the XLB, from what I can remember, they are my favorite of all I've tried in the city. They are also the most soupy. Quality over quantity. For 10 soup dumplings, I believe it was $9+ in comparison to other dumpling houses where 10 XLB will only cost you $5.

Like a lot of restaurants around here, it's cash only so remember to visit an ATM beforehand.
author: Stine H.

description: Amazing fried chicken wings but terrible service. Took an hour from ordering to get the food with only a few tables.  I'd still go back for the food but be prepared to wait!
author: Martie A.

description: Giving one star only because I can't give zero stars. I live in this neighborhood and find it very convenient to go to Shanghai house. I personally love their dry fried chicken. But the service here is disgusting. I would say the worst service I ever had at any restaurant. First of all, when I went in and was seated, the lady server that's always there threw all our plates and chop sticks on our table, not a single smile on her face. That's ok. I don't expect her to. I ordered the fry fried chicken wings, chicken and vegetable egg rolls, and some Shanghai dumpling. I get the my egg rolls and bite into them, to only see vegetables. When I asked where the chicken in my egg rolls were, she said that they ran out. why did you let me order them if it was out? I told her I didn't want the eggs rolls and she still proceeded to charge me for the egg rolls. No matter how much I like the chicken wings or dumplings; I can not longer stand the horrible service. Will never eat here again. Shanghai dumpling king few blocks down has better dumpling and better service.
author: Ariunaa B.

description: One of the worst Chinese food meals we've ever had.  Sullen waitress, dirty tables, a twenty-five minute wait for food...where to start?  The food smelled and tasted "off," with a greasy shanghai beef noodle with about a teaspoon's worth of beef in it.  We ate some noodles (super greasy, no spice to them, and cold in the center) and pushed it aside, just unpalatable.  The five-spice cold fish, which is a dish we love elsewhere, was almost rancid-tasting; sweet, cloying, and full of bones.  We couldn't even identify the type of fish.  We will never go back, seriously, despite it being across the street from our favourite theater.  I can't believe some of the better reviews, when our meal was just plain dreadful.
author: Rina W.

description:
Let me start by saying, and if it's not already obvious, I'm Asian American and more specifically, Chinese American.  I grew up eating very traditional Chinese food BUT at the same time love the taste of "americanized" chinese food like "general's chicken" kung pao, sweet and sour, etc.

This place is suits BOTH palates.  It's a little far from everything but if you have extra time and a car, this place is WORTH IT. Small but pleasant, you will be greeted by a chinese lady who doesn't speak much.  While she may seem unfriendly at first, come back a few more times and she will recognize you and greet you with a smile.  

Here are your MUST ORDERS: 
1) Dried Fried Chicken Wings
2) Hot and Sour Soup
3) Xiao Long Bao (Pork Soup Dumplings)
4) hand cut noodles

The rest is up to you.  This place is CASH ONLY and a very good deal.  With 4-6 people, don't expect to pay more than $15-$20.
author: Allen K.

description:
I got a tip for some amazing Shanghai style dumplings from a fellow Yelper which is how I found myself out in the Outer Richmond, an area I usually don't venture out to. 

Every other post was about the xiao long bao so of course we had to get it. They were good and soupy, but hardly mind-blowingly awesome. They were tasty, and in all fairness our group of four ordered a second order of them. But I didn't really get any sort of wow versus the dim sum I'd get at Yank Sing or in Chinatown.

The other dishes were solid.
author: Cristofer P.

description:
Chicken wings or chicken CANDY??

Super crisp exterior as I would come to expect from a Chinese restaurant. Sauce had a bit of heat although too much sweet for my taste. Still, an indulgent treat. XLB were good, pan fried dumplings were greasy, crispy and green onion-y as expected. Shanghai noodle stir-fry needed a lot more seasoning- not sure if they were supposed to be this bland. Overall pretty yum. I'd come back to try that S&P knuck.
author: Anthony R.

description: Had an intense craving for xiao long boa and this place hit the spot. Also enjoyed their dry chicken wings, super crispy and covered in thick sweet and spicy sauce. Damn son.
author: Sajira A.

description: saturday dinner in the outer richmond...dinner for four and hungry!...requesting beers, but none...told to go next door to buy and bring back...six pack of modelo negro for $ten from the market...ready to order at shanghai house...xiao lung baos first...decent taste in filling...finding the wrapping little doughy and chewy...green onion pancakes pan fried thin, dense and dry....dried fried chicken battered extra thick and oversized, but spicy candy sweet tangy garlic saucing similar to korean wings...too much batter...dan dan noodles straying from the standard and shanghai house creating own version...having more items, but too full...dinner was just okay...
author: Hen A.

description:
Brusque and slow service combined with ordinary food, I don't think I'll be back here anytime soon.   

You know I'm here for a reason and it's to check off an item on my Big Eat SF list:

#13 soup dumplings at Shanghai House. 

10 pieces of hot Xiao Long Bao brought out in a bamboo steamer.  The soft texture of the steamed wrapping paper, well-seasoned pork, and tasty soup in these one-bite dumplings make you thankful that these only cost $5.50.  (which would cost you $10 at Yank Sing)  

The other items we ordered were okay,  a little too heavy on the oyster sauce on our stir-fry Buddha's Delight which has broccoli, fried tofu, bok choy and carrots.   Our shrimp fried rice had a weird burnt taste although the shrimp itself was plump and tender.   The walnut prawns? a skip. 

This place is small but can probably accommodate around 30 people.  Be prepared to wait if they get busy.  

BTW, cash only.
author: Janice C.

description:
I have been going here for a few years.  I have never been disappointed with their House Special Eggplant and Sesame Chicken which are staples of our meals here.  

The dining room is small and plain.  The service is ok, borderline slow.
author: Thomas L.

description:
This place is a-ok. Service can use some help. Food is good, at least what we ordered. 

Let's start with the service. They don't really check on you. Well never mind, they don't check on you at all. Only time they 'check' on you is if you ASK for something like napkins, water, or the check. 

Oh yeah. I don't know about you, but I thought the waitress wearing flip flops while serving food was really nasty and unsanitary. Think they might want to review ServSafe again.
author: Jessica C.

description:
Came here off a comment that said the chicken wings at Shanghai House was BETTER than San Tung's. Does that even exist? Well that's what we were trying to figure out. 

The restaurant always seems to be a little empty, and at a glance can probably fit ~30 people. 

From their menu, these are the things I have tried before: 

Green Onion Pancake: Both times someone in my group ordered this, and both times the dish disappointed. When it comes out of the kitchen, it's warm and not hot - which makes me think they kept it in the freezer and just heated it up when customers order it. While I know most restaurants do that, it'd be nice if at least they FOOL me into thinking it was freshly made by coming out hot.... 

XLB: not bad, but not great either. If I was really craving XLBs, I'd just walk down the block and visit Dumpling King, sorry. 

Savory Rice Roll: The interior was cold!!!!! Need I say more?

Dry Sauteed String Beans: The flavor was a little bland, but we mixed this with the sauce that came with our chicken wings and it was MUCH better. Perhaps they should make a dish with the string beans solely in the chicken wings sauce (where is the suggestion box when you need it?)

Dry Fried Chicken Wings: Now this is perhaps the ONLY thing I really liked. Some people thought the chicken wings were too battered up or that it was too spicy, but I thought it was PERFECT. And what is also great is that their chicken wings are HUGE! If i were to come back, I'd only order the wings.
author: Gelene V.

description:
I inadvertently made a trip back out to Shanghai House almost exactly two years after my first and only time out to this stretch of the Outer Richmond, and I feel that they've redeemed themselves because when you eat something that you continually crave for weeks afterwards, you KNOW it's good.

My friend and I came out here late one weeknight and ordered the XLB (not the best, but good anyway) and split the spicy 8-combination noodle soup with the hand-cut noodles.  Best. Thing. Ever.  The broth was spicy but not overly so, and there were tons of things in the bowl: shrimp, chicken, beef, peanuts, bean curd.. yes, delicious.  The noodles were really tender and had the wonderful homemade taste to them.

If I'd known it was that good, I would've ordered one for myself and not shared.  BUT that just gives me another excuse to come back out here so I CAN order one to myself.
author: Tori S.

description: Food is great other than their fortune cookies. Star taken for having the worst fortune cookie because it's stale and the service.
author: lilpandagirl P.

description: We ordered take-out from Shanghai House, so perhaps that is why this review is less positive than others. We came to this place due to its convenient location in regards to Purple Kow (very popular boba store) to grab an accompanying lunch. My friend ordered what he thought was "dimsum" -- 10 dumplings and 4 small pork buns. By the time we brought it back to the house and sat down to eat, the dumplings were cold and sticking to the paper box. The buns also looked like those you can buy from the supermarket, defrost, and microwave to eat. Definitely nothing special. One positive note about this place is the reasonable price -- at least I was full from the lunch. I probably won't be ordering take out from here again, but maybe will try dine in to see if the experience is different!
author: Hurnan V.

description:
New dishes to update on

dry spicy chicken wings (~$8)
san tung style but cheaper, more chrispy, and bigger wings. Similar spicy, sweet honey flavor. My family thinks its better than san tung although I still give the nod to san tung. 5/5

twice spicy pork (~$8)
Szechuan style stir fry with tons of veggies. The veggies included cabbage, mushrooms, cucumbers, and bean curd. The pork was ordinary but the combination of everything made it overall a very delicious dish. 4/5

CASH ONLY but I would recommend getting the soup dumplings and the dry fried spicy chicken wings. Walk across the street to purple kow for dessert.
author: Robert Y.

description:
I'm really picky when it comes to Chinese food...can't stand greasy stuff. I may not be Asian, but this place was really good. Service sucks, so be prepared to go here for the food and not the experience.

I had the chicken wings thx to reviews from fellow Yelper-s which are comprable to San Tung's, maybe a little spicier which I love. Also had the dumplings (bomb!! and way better at the restaurant than to-go, but if you order to-go be sure to ask for the sauce) and beef broccoli. 

Parking is easy too.
author: Melissa C.

description: Not so good. Tofu in Vermillion soup is sour. Dumpling skin is mushy. Find a better place than this.
author: TL S.

description:
Another 3.5 stars but I can't give it that; plus it's better than most of the other 3.5 stars restaurants that I've tried recently.

As other Yelpers have expressed, the service is SLOW and the restaurant is pretty small.  I think I counted five workers including the waitress/hostess.  There is an older gent washing the dishes, another older woman who brings the food out, her younger friend and then one person COOKING all the dishes in the small kitchen.  Wow.  Thankfully we weren't in a rush today.

We ordered the following:

- dry fried chicken - Yes, very similiar to San Tung's, but I think the drummettes were a little bigger (and I still think ST's is tastier.  Dammit.)
- dry fried green beans - I prefer the one at San Tung's b/c there were too many other fillers at SH:  peppers and onions
- Shanghainese noodles - it reminded me of stir fried Japanese udon, but I liked it
- beef tendon - YUM.  My favorite appetizer.

I could see myself coming back here if I was craving this food during off peak hours, say, 2:00 to 3:00.  Oops,  I'm looking at the take-out menu and they close everyday (but Tuesday) at 3:30 and reopen at 5:00.
author: Christie X.

description:
In the Outer Richmond, this spot is great. On the weekends, there is usually a line outside the restaurant (not TOO long of a wait though), as the place is pretty tiny (only 8 or 9 tables inside? That sit 2-6 people each?) 

Yummy xiao long baos. They hit the spot every time. All of the other dishes I've tried here have also been equally delicious.

Service is meh, but it won't deter me from coming back :) (after all, we're talking about a Chinese restaurant here...oh, which also means: CASH ONLY!)
author: Joanna M.

description: Service is slow. Food is so-so. Cash only. But the fried chicken wings are pretty fantastical.
author: Ernesto C.

description:
This is a good place to go if you are not in a rush (like, really, not in a rush).  As many people have mentioned before me, the service is really, really slow.  When we first walked in, there were only a few people in there, but tables hadn't been cleared and it didn't look like the server was in a hurry to clean them up either.

The XiaoLongBao was great.  Lots of juice in the middle.  One Long was 5.95.  I was also a fan of the ChaoNianGao..  Hadn't eaten that in a while!
author: Alison L.

description:
Food was good.  I would give it a 4.

But boy the service is just really slow.  

I'm guessing the waitress/cashier must be the wife (common in small chinese restaurants).  I think her bulb is on a dimmer.

Takes a long time to get menus, tea, order, bill.  Difficult to get her attention.

Hey but the food is good and that's what matters.  I just have to have at least a couple of hours for a nice simple lunch.

Would go back but just not to often.  Time is precious.
author: David L.

description:
After seeing the Shanghai House featured in a San Francisco magazine, my boyfriend and I decided to check it out.  They are known for their dumplings, so be sure to try those!

There's no reservations and the store itself is very small, so make sure you get there early for dinner or super later in order to get a seat! There's no wait list and the only place to wait for a table is outside.  

The service was only okay, we were rarely checked up on for simple things such as water.  The food also took some time to get to us, but was somewhat worth the wait.  It was very authentic and the fried rice was delicious.  We didn't branch out and stuck with basic sesame chicken and the sweet & sour chicken, both of which were good.  The portion size was very large, so you won't leave hungry.  

Note: Cash only!
author: Katie L.

description:
We only came here because shanghai dumpling king was closed.  

Named Shanghai House we though we could easily get some Shanghai dumplings especially since it's the first item on the menu.  When we tried to order some the waitress told us not too because they didn't have any ready and it would take at least 30 minutes to get some.  Ok that sucks......but I guess we'll just order some other stuff....we ordered some regular potstickers, soup, chicken, etc.  Then started the waiting game......after about 20 minutes we see the first dish we order come out...but they take it to a different table.  About 5 minutes later the waitress grabs it off of their table and puts it on ours.  Not cool to either of us.  The food trickles in on our table at an extremely odd pace.  It pretty much ended up being something like...here is a dish, we finish it, here is another dish, rinse and repeat.

The real problem I had with the place is that I realized that we might as well have ordered the Shanghai dumplings since it pretty much took us 45 minutes to get all of our meal items and we saw other tables getting the dumplings.
author: Daniel K.

description: Authentic Xiao Long Bao.  My family loves it. Chinese donuts is excellent too.  I agree service is not the best, but this does not deter us to come back.
author: Charles C.

description: honestly the Xiaolongbao here is amazing.  the best we have ever had, and we are Xiaolongbao snobs who despise Yank Sing.   It is also very cheap, and the service is good too.   we also ordered pork and vege wonton, still good but not as good as Xiaolongbao.   delicious rice cakes too.
author: Shuting Z.

description:
Skip it. One of my worst dining experiences in SF. I was extremely disappointed given that I had driven across town to outer Richmond. Food is just ok - maybe 3 stars. XLB was not bad but I did not experience any in-my-mouth broth explosion, indispensable for any stellar XLB.

What really downgraded this place to 1 star is the service. I do not mind if the waiter forgets my water, forgets my setting, brings me my check mid-way eating, bumps into me, drops a dirty rag on my table, is impatient that I take too long to look at menu, etc. As you can see, I have a super high tolerance for the typical bad service in a Chinese restaurant. What is indispensable is that the restaurant is eager to make the sale and is eager to take my money after I get my food. This place lacks this quality and makes this whole transaction extremely painful.
author: pH R.

description: This is a decent place for grabbing some Asian food, but nothing too special. Service was super slow and inattentive. We ordered the string beans, chicken wings, and XLB. I don't like string beans that much (my bf does) so I can't say much about this dish, but it is pretty spicy. My bf seemed to like it, since it had a type of pickled vegetable that he said his mom uses to cook (what kind of vegetable it is, I have no idea, but it is less translucent than the onions in the dish). I was looking forward to the chicken wings since they were compared to the famous San Tung's, but was a little disappointed. The wings were too breaded and large. I did like the XLBs, though! I still have yet to find XLBs as amazing as Din Tai Fung's in the bay area, but these were pretty good and will do for now.
author: Jacqueline K.

description:
Shanghai House is an interesting restaurant with their front wall made entirely of glass. It looks pretty cool looking from outside into the store. 

The Shanghai dumplings were pretty good here. It's cooked really well that the outside dumpling stays firm when picked up. The inside was soupy and hot! That's pretty good compared to other places where it's warm or cold on the inside. I can see why people like this place. The dumplings were well worth a trip.

The price is pretty cheap and the food tastes good. Definitely a great Chinese restaurant to head back to!
author: Steven B.

description: My absolute favorite Chinese restaurant in the city!  We come here at least once a month but usually more.  Our staples are Mongolian beef, dry fry wings, and xiao long boa, and you can't beat the price either.  You can eat like a king for 30 bucks(cash only).  Their Mongolian beef is amazing, its not that typical beef in brown sauce, theirs is so fresh with onions, jalapeño, chilis, and other good stuff.  But this pales in comparison to the dry fry wings.  I have no idea what they do to these wings but they are amazingly delicious, perfectly balanced between spicy and sweet always crunchy and incredibly moist inside.  Also they are huge for wings.  Their xiao long bao or soup dumplings are also amazing and worth the sometimes wait.  Large delicious dumplings filled with flavorful soup and meat...mmmm
author: P N.

description:
The only reason for me to visit the outer sunset has historically been Shanghai Dumpling King.  Last time I went, the Dumpling King was closed for a month.  Since we were already out in the neighborhood we used the Yelp Android App and found Shanghai House.  I'm glad that we found a new place to eat, as Shanghai House is a good alternative to Dumpling King if you're looking to switch things up. 

The Good: 
- Food overall was pretty good
- Shanghai dumplings (xiao long bao), long beans, and the noodle dish (name I forget) were all quite good
- Across the street from an independent theater, so possibly a good place to stop before or after a movie.

The Not so Good: 
- Drunken chicken was a little too drunken for my tastes
- The door had some serious gaps in it, so cold air kept coming into the restaurant
- It's a pretty small space, so may be hard to seat larger groups
author: Wayne L.

description:
Get your Xiao Long Bao!!

One of my favorite places for Shanghai dumplings in San Francisco. It's a continual challenge to find the perfect xiao long bao: delicate skin, perfect balance of meat to skin, acceptable amount of soup inside, and perfect serving temperature. There seem to be a lot of restaurants that take on this challenge but many tend to disappoint.

Shanghai House does a very good shanghai dumpling which is even recommended by one of my friends who has been to multiple Din Tai Fung locations even the original one in Taiwan. I've tried other dishes on the menu including the noodle dishes, vegetable and meat dishes, and appetizers here but the standout for me is the xiao long bao which are about $6.00 per serving. Make sure to order more than one steamer basket because you can't just stop at a couple :)
author: Lisa M.

description: I don't really care about the atmosphere of restaurants as a rule, but this is truly dreary.  That said, the wings and dumplings are really great so we will keep going back.  Yum.
author: Courtney C.

description: It actually is called home home happy in the chinese text. Excellent chicken wings and dumplings. Tai how!
author: J D.

description:
Don't understand the hype about this place. Yes, the dry fried chicken wings are terrific. A Must Order.
The green onion pancake was doughy and bland. The Shanghai dumplings were OK, but there are better ones up the street. The Shanghai noodles were inedible! Maybe they are an acquired taste that I have not yet acquired. But I saw other tables leaving a full dish of it when they departed, also. 
The guy behind us ordered Mongolian Beef and that looked pretty good. Maybe there are other dishes that are better at this place.
"Pelican Dreams" across the street at the Balboa Theatre was a terrific movie and quite convenient to this restaurant.
author: franny s.

description:
Love Shanghai House!
Dry chicken wings are so delicious!
Bean curd puff-outstanding.
Shanghai dumplings-mmmmmmmmm
We moved away last year, our first & last stop (with many visits in between) when we are in town!
author: Emily D.

description: I give five stars to this Shanghai Restaurant is base on the foods. Steam pork dumplings, Chicken Wings and Pan Fried Pork Dumplings are rock! I also order another two Shanghai Cold dishes Kaofu and Smoke Fish, and they are excellent as well. I prefer to order takeout at there cause the restaurant is pretty small and I don't fell uncomfortable to stand there to wait for a table. Actually, there is no extra space to let you wait there. I will definitely take it as my to-go restaurant for takeout!
author: Wendy W.

description:
Shanghai dumplings is my most recent discovery.  There is something magical about these nearly transparent skinned XLB (code for these dumplings I have picked up from reading fellow yelpers); when I wash up in the shower and gingerly soap the sacs, I sometimes picture twin XLB's hanging.   Eating these dumplings take years and years of experience and practice.  The science of it is it is delicately picking it up by its foreskin cleanly, as to not let any juices leak, plopping it into soy sauce, then laying it on your tongue and sliding it into your mouth.  I have had Shanghai Dumpling King nearby which was pretty good, however KDer told me that Shanghai House had dumplings that were renown and comparable if not better.  I could eat 3-4 treys of XLB's at Shanghai Dumpling King so I was hesitant if anything else could compare.  

This place is always crowded.  Unlike Shanghai Dumpling King which is a dump, this place is somewhat modern.  There is even a glass door.  However, beware of this aesthetic beauty.  It does not close completely, and any gust of wind will jar it open, letting in a cold draft of pneumonia.  Because there is so much ingoing and outgoing traffic, my teeth would have been chattering if not for the dry chicken wings.  As of all Chinese restaurants, waitresses do not engage you in banter.  They jot down your order, bring it to you and try to get you to leave as soon as possible.  There is not even the slightest hint of a smile.  We ordered:  

1.  xiao long bao: 4/5  These shanghai dumplings were good, however, inferior to that of Shanghai Dumpling King.  First off, the outside dough was a little too thick as opposed to the nearly translucent skin of Dumpling King.  As a result, it was a little heavier to eat and fills you up faster.  A plus is that because of a thicker outer skin, they are less apt to break, spilling out succulent juices.  These dumplings are also very small, so while there are 10 mini bundles of joy, you can chow through them pretty fast.

2.  pork dumplings: 3/5  These pork dumplings were shaped differently from the original baos.  These were decent.  Again, the dough exterior was thicker than I would have liked.  The pork was tasty inside, however, nothing was truly outstanding.  It was an average dish.

3.  shanghai panfry noodles: 3/5  This was a KDer dish and she made sure to get it vegetarian, stripping the order of its meat.  Curse her.  The noodles were very greasy.  In addition, I am not a fan of those really thick noodles.  I prefer the thin chow mein type noodles.  We ordered too much so I really didn't eat eat much of this until the next day.  It was good as a instant lunch, however, I believe it was more a product of my hunger than to the testament of the noodles.  A pile of oil and grease rested on my plate after the noodles were gone.

4.  dry chicken wings: 5/5  I've had the original dry chicken wings at San Tungs and I will say these are delicious and just a small notch below the original innovators.  These dry chicken wings were spicy.  In addition, they arrived piping hot, and because I was too hungry to wait for them to cool, I alternated between blowing the chicken, taking a bite, and blowing my fingers to alleviate the minor 3rd degree burns being afflicted upon them.  While an order of San Tung's wings are more in quantity, Shanghai House's wings are much bigger.  There is more meat on these wings.  The caramelized sauce is too money and this dish made the meal.  

Shanghai House is affordable like 99.9% of Chinese restaurants, however, they do jack their price an extra dollar or two due to all the media hoopla they have received.  They proudly paste their accolades on the glass window.  I am not the biggest fan of Chinese food.  As I have said countless times, I believe their food to be overly sauced and greasy.  In addition, service is non-existant but you cannot hold a Chinese restaurant to that standard.  If you are tired of waiting in line for San Tungs tho, come here.  To be honest, I can't say San Tung is a clear cut favorite.  These wings can hold San Tung wings' jock.
author: Brian V.

description:
Danced myself back to this restaurant because I was down for some vegetarian food. If you follow me here in the wonderful world of Yelp, you'll know by now that I love me some vegetables (and fruits!). So with that said, I've read many reviews about Shanghai House's vegetarian friendly dishes.

So I came in, sat by the window and ordered:

1. Vegetarian Goose
2. Vegetarian dumplings
3. Bean curd salad

And let me tell you... I use to not enjoy Chinese restaurants for the mere fact that almost every dish I know of is swimming in canola oil. It still holds true to this day, and believe me, this place is no exception. But what I realize is that I love food that originates from Asia, mostly because I love that their dishes tend to incorporate lots of vegetables.

Shanghai House deserves a four star rating for this reason.

Sure, I had their sinful fried chicken not too long ago, but let's not think about that now. I am well aware of my cravings and I know when to stop.

What I do know is that 3 vegetarian dishes all to myself fills me up. Who says vegetarians and vegans are hungry all the time??? I am not one, but hey, I know for a fact that if i wanted vegetables for dinner, I know I have to eat at least a pound before I feel completely satisfied.

Back to the food, which is the main reason for this review. If you haven't figured it out by now, I LOVE it. The vegetarian goose was sweet and salty, dumplings were warm and delicious, and the bean curd salad was refreshing. I'm glad I only live a few blocks away, because I am all for trying out more of their dishes! To tell you the truth, service is not all that great and it's cash only, but hey, the food's what gets me so I'm good!
author: Liz V.
