description: This is my favorite Shanghai food in sf. Their dumpling is juicy n meat inside is very smooth. Price is cheap but service is very slow around 10 min wait after u order a dumpling. I love there ck wing with special sauce taste a little spicy but so yummy! Crunchy n honey ! Ku-pao ck taste so different here spicy dried tofu with nuts r so good! If u come lunch special deals with spicy n sour soup come with ! Good deals !! Love it!
author: Linh D.

description:
My sweetie & I came here before 1:30 yesterday afternoon after we saw a few people sticking out of the door waiting at Shanghai Dumpling King and told me he just wanted to eat something and stop driving.  I read some of the reviews while we were looking for parking but was expecting a little more.  I had order the xiao long baos for us, and he ordered garlic chicken for us to share.  The XLBs were sooo tiny & flat looking.  The very few of them that had hot juice in them we accidentally broke & the others didn't have any in it.  Some of them even looked like they already were punctured in the basket before we even touched them.  The garlic chicken was okay, garlicky with some salty brown sauce with some yummy veggies mixed with them.  

The place is tiny and there was only one waitress, so service was slow, in fact she sometimes had some people from the kitchen helping her bring dishes to customers. Eww, nasty..I saw her a few times rubbing her nose with the top of her hand, at least it wasn't with her palms or fingers though but still!  For every table that left there were more customers waiting to sit there...and she'd quickly set up their table settings.  Maybe they originally wanted SDK too.     

The 10 teeny XLBs were $5.50, in addition to the garlic chicken, & 3 rice bowls our bill was $17 and change..not cheap!  So far, the best XLBs I've had are from Shanghai Dumpling Shop in Millbrae.  I give it a 2 because the place was clean & I felt bad for the lone waitress having to do pretty much everything in the front.
author: Cat C.

description: I like this place , and noticed via ChefsFeed that it got a recommend for their Pickled vegetable & shredded pork soup , going to try it next time :)
author: Joseph A.

description:
I go to this area in the outer richmond a lot and after seeing all the great reviews for this place, I decided to give it a try.  It's a very small place with only a few tables so I would NOT go in large groups of more than 4.  I went around 330pm on Friday and it's best to go at this time or earlier since there is NO waiting line.  In fact, there were only 2 other tables that were being served.  (Also, it's best to go when they open since they have lunch specials at cheaper prices available from 11am-3pm.)  I ordered:

- Shanghai Soup Dumplings from their Appetizer menu
- Combination Fried Rice 
- Dry Chicken Wings
- 2 coke sodas

and if you fill up your tummy real fast like me, that's ALL you should be ordering.  They give you a generous plate of each.  I have to back up what others say about the service -  you have to be aggressive about wanting to order from your menu, paying, wanting sodas or water, spoons/forks/extra napkins, etc. This is an asian place in a mainly asian neighborhood (as can be seen by the MANY asian restaurants and asian bank on balboa street) so service will naturally not be the best out there. If you want 5 star service, this would NOT be a place I would recommend.

However, the food was pretty good.  I had never tried xlb, or Shanghai Soup Dumplings, but they were to die for!  They gave me about 10 dumplings in a bamboo steam pot tray.  I just totally ignored their hard-to-eat with chopsticks and used their soup spoon to bring the dumplings from the bamboo pot tray  to my mouth and I was pleasantly surprised to see the soup INSIDE the pork dumplings (even though mentally I had already read about this in the reviews).  They ARE hot so you have to be careful (I'm glad I had my ice-cold coke sodas handy nearby which I quickly gulped right after swallowing the dumplings), but they are SOOOOOO good and filling with their light medium dumpling skins.  I think I could have gotten another order or two of dumplings, been full  and called it a day!    

But I ordered the other dishes earlier and decided to finish those off too.  After all, I'm always in the area and could go back to dine here at one of those other times.  And I'll DEFINITELY remember to bring a lot of napkins/paper towels to handle those soup dumpling spills! :-)  I loved the large chicken wings which were sweet and VERY hot - there were about 8-10 large pieces.  The combination fried rice was a surprise - it had LETTUCE in it which I've never seen before in the usual chinese fried rice but they give you a lot of big large shrimp as well as  a few large other items in it.  What I noticed about the fried rice was there were clumps of white rice because the rice had not been mixed thoroughly with the meat, but it was still a tasty accompaniment to the wings.  I WAS able to use my credit card and my order was only about $30.  I was able to bring home leftovers of 4 wings.  I definitely liked the food and would definitely come back for more.
author: Frugal C.

description:
I love this place. I have literally been here 3 times in the last 3 days. The food is good, the prices are cheap, and it's right around the corner from my place.

+the chicken wings are AMAZING!  better than the ones at san tung!
+xiao lung bao are juicy and flavorful! better than the ones at shanghai dumpling king
+pan fried dumplings are another favorite but NOT on the menu, just ask for it
+tan tan noodles taste even better cold the next day, seriously
+my parents always order the eight combination noodle soup and its spicy but just the right amount, great for a rainy day!

-the only negative is their service is slow, they only have one waitress and she also runs the cashier but other than that...4 solid stars
author: Jennifer C.

description:
Do you LOVE SDK? Does your mouth water at the mere mention of soup dumplings or dry sauteed string beans? Do you enjoy decent service in clean environment? If so, then this is the place for you.

Since SDK (Shanghai Dumpling King) is closed, I needed an alternative dumpling place after my hour long walk with close friend. Luckily, I yelped dumplings, and this place popped up.

The two of us shared an order of XLB, the dry sauteed string beans (#51), and the shanghai noddles. The first two were exceptionally delicious. I did note how the noodle of the dumpling was a bit thicker/firmer than Dumpling King's, which was enjoyable. The sting beans are TDF (to die for)...seriously, that garlicky sauce and delicious peppers...and the beans weren't over cooked. The low-note were the noodles...they look a lot better than they actually taste (bland-ish). Mix the noodles up in the green bean sauce and add some dollops of srichichcahchcha sauce to save them. 

Anyway...we enjoyed our meal for $26 (inc tip).
author: Misha F.

description: Excellent dim sum....I have had dumplings this good since I visited china.  I also recommend the fried tofu.  We got here early before the lunch rush...it is a small place so be prepared to wait in busy times...but it will be well worth the wait
author: Chris H.

description:
So after a long time since my last visit (not so great), I decided to give this place another shot. Mostly because I was craving hand cut noodles and didn't want to drive all the way to Fatima in Cupertino.

What can I say, they've improved a lot since my last visit. The xiao long bao was REALLY soupy (and also really meaty), and the skin was nice and chewy, the way I like it.

The hand cut noodle soup was also good. The noodles are thinner than what I'm used to, but considerably chewy. The soup base is tasty.

And they do rotations of different kinds of veggie plates which I like. The service was also much better this time. Glad I gave it another try!
author: Diana C.

description: I was craving chicken wings and I was going toward Balboa. I quickly yelped Chicken Wings in that area and found this place. On the bus I called to order Dry Fried Chicken Wings togo. I got there within 15 minutes, order still not ready. Waited another 20 minutes to half an hour! What the! What was the point of calling in my order?? I don't think they started my order until I got to the restaurant. The Chicken wings had ALOT of hard crunchy batter on it, the batter is so thick, it seperates from the chicken and you can eat the batter on its own. The chicken wings and drums were huge! They aren't the small wings, they are the big ones! Overall the taste was good but if you don't like thick batter, forget about it. Also this is artery clogging for sure! The sauce is SO Thick it looked like tar, I wonder what's in that sauce, kinda creeped me out after I scarfed it down.
author: Karen T.

description: Love their fried chicken.  I always order to go, so their slow service doesn't bother me.
author: Matt C.

description:
I came here for the savory rice rolls and xiao long bao but left a fan of the savory soy bean milk & stir fried shanghai rice cake.  After hearing one of my friends rave about the savory rice rolls at this place for weeks, we finally made it here one sunday morning.

xiao long bao (2 stars): skin a little too thin and soggy for my liking.  perhaps steamed too long but the filling was good.

savory rice roll (3.5 stars): good proportion of rice to filling but i like my chinese doughnut a little less smushed, not so much rou song, and a little bit more pickled veggie.  was a little bit too salty for my liking. 

savory soy bean milk (4 stars): yum and filling.  would have given it five stars had there been chinese doughnut pieces floating arount.

stir fried shanghai rice cake (4 stars): delicious. rice cake was cooked to the proper consistency and there was just the right about of flavoring in the stir fry to not drown out the flavor of the rice cake.

service here is possibly a little slow, it took a long time to get the check, you would think they'd be a little faster when there is a line of people waiting at the door for a table.  lots of other yummy sounding dishes on the menu, i'll be back to try out the hand cut noodles in the beef brisket noodle soup.
author: Catherine A.

description:
People in SF are too spoil.  Every street is brimming with authentic eateries that makes your heart melt.

I've always been a fiend for Xiao Long Bao.  There is such a nice balance between the warm soup and the acidity of the gingered vinegar.  My heart smiles a little every single time I bite into one.  Shanghai House does is absolutely right.  The dumpling skin is moist but not rubbery and and pork filling is flavored to perfection.  

I also discovered something new.  Hand cut noodles.  Think fat Japanese Ramen.  So delicious.  We got the pickled vegetables and pork with the noodles and it was magnificent.

Best of all, it's so cheap.  All of that for under $20 with tax and tip.
author: Thuyvi T.

description:
Things that make me go mmmm mmm.

-XLB! One order gets your 10 succulent soup dumplings. 
-Green Onion Pancake (not greasy at all)
-Dry Fried Chicken Wings ( UBER CRUNCHY with savory spicy sauce on the outside and spiced well in the inside.
-TAN TAN Noodles ( think spicy noodles with meat sauce and a nice hint of sesame oil)

Let's just face it...I come here for dumplings. I brought a friend and my bf here after sutdying and they were so happy. My bf lives near clement and felt he knew all places that did dim sum right but he had never been to Shanghai House.

Remember: Cash Only and even though the one waitress that works there never smiles give her a break and be patient.
author: Leslie L.

description: Food was good service was HORRIBLE!! The lady serving us was beyond rude with no kind of customer service skills. My group of 6 was neglected and when we tried to pay at the end it took at least 20min for her to take our payment. After we payed with card she brought a takeout menu and circled cash only. There were no signs that said cash only and they had a card machine so I don't see what the problem was. Will never go back because of the deplorable service.
author: Shantel G.

description:
Love this place. I've tried Kingdom Dumpling and Shanghai Dumpling King, but prefer Shanghai House. The Shanghai dumplings here are great and the rest of the menu is awesome too.

We usually get the dry sautéed string beans, dry fried fish, and shanghai dumplings. One of my favorite meals.

It can get a bit crowded, but not nearly as bad as Shanghai Dumpling King.
author: Spencer H.

description:
Pretty good shanghainese food according to a shanghainese person :)

Don't order their rice cake or salt meat fried rice (xian cai rou fan), a very typical shanghainese dish because they are not that good

We ordered 3 seafood dish and they r all pretty good...on the salty side so prepare to drink plenty of water after ur meal...hehe
author: XYZ Q.

description:
The chicken wings are good as advertised.  

The onion pancakes were fabulous as well. 

The only minor downside was service.  They are friendly but there's usually only one person handling all the tables.  Also, if it matters, no alcohol here.  

One of our "go to" places.
author: David L.

description:
Along the quiet neighborhood of outer Richmond, a small packet of restaurants sits firmly on Balboa Street. Despite a cult following at Shanghai Dumpling King just a few blocks away, Shanghai House surprised customers with amazing food and clean décor. Formerly the chef at Wu Kong, chef/owner Kam Yuen Lu successfully translates a few banquet style dishes in his neighborhood restaurant.

Ambiance. 
In the twenty six seat restaurant, the ambiance is fit for a cozy dinner with friends. An all glass front allows customer a clear view of Richmond neighborhood. Clean white walls and bright ceiling lights create a minimalist décor allowing the food dishes play center stage. Dishes are served handsomely over a table filled with a scenic nature background.

Food.
Shanghainess cooking showcases a tad sweet in taste compared to their regional counterparts. I start off the meal with a few orders of cold plate dishes. Neatly assembled, the vegetarian goose ($4.25) appetizer is a great starter. Tender cake make from many thin layers of tofu skin, with a pan fried crispy top, wraps in a meaty shitake mushroom filling. A slight drizzle of red vinegar provide a tang enhancer. Neatly fanned across the plate, the five spice beef ($4.95) was a disappointment.

The beef lacked flavor and was dry. Served in a bamboo steamer, the pork dumpling (minced pork filling wrapped in a soft house made wonton like skin) revived my taste buds with a burst of soup and tender filling. Braised fish with white wine sauce ($9.95) feature tender flounder. Giving the dish character, crunchy wood ear fungus compliments the soft fish. My least favorite dish was the rice cake - $5.95. Seemingly presented without care, chewy rice cakes are work-tossed with shredded pork and Napa cabbage.

The stew pork ($7.25) stole the show. Each thinly pork slice flaunts the dual textures of savory meat with a fatty cap. Hiding under the buttery pork, dried vegetables provide a slight savory note. The dark maple sauce brings the entire dish together. An order of fluffy white rich diffused the sweetness.
Having been here previously for brunch, the savory rice roll ($2.50) warms up the stomach. Resembling a sushi roll, sticky rice wraps around dried shredded pork and vegetables. The sweet soy bean milk ($1.25) makes a great breakfast drink. The savory soy bean milk is an acquired taste.

Dried vegetables, friend Chinese doughnut, along with a drizzle of chilli oil swim in the silky milk. Cut into triangular pizza slices and fried till golden brown, onion pancakes ($3.95) highlights the aroma of fried onion. Enriched in a dark sweet sauce, Shanghai style pan fried noodle (noodles stir fried with cabbage and shredded prok-$5.50) gives patrons a taste of chewy noodles that rounds out a dish.

While chef/owner Kam Yuen Lu is busy in the kitchen, wife Teresa Hai serves patrons in the front of the house. Hai said, "the most challenging part of owning a restaurant is finding local fresh ingredients." Another dish I have yet to try but recommend is the pig's knuckle which must be ordered one day in advance.
author: Rayfil W.

description: We spent the day at Baker Beach and originally was on the way to Purple Kow ,when we go hungry, so we walked around and found this place. Looked good from the outside, so we went in.  Upon entering no one greeted us. Elm E. made a comment like that here also. The only reason I think they didn't greet us was because the manager was training a new employee, but she failed at training her. Not greeting the customer, big mistake. We had the Shanghai steamed baby dumplings, vegetarian steamed dumplings,Salted pork with vegetables rice clay pot & the Tender chicken in Shanghai style noodle soup. The food was mediocre at best.   The restroom is upstairs, but I had to ask because there is no sign for the restroom. They need to have a sign up saying that it is upstairs.
author: Jerry C.

description:
The shanghai dumplings are very flavorful and more than half your dumplings will have soup still in it. The dry fried chicken is a lot like San Tung's, it's super crispy and really yummy but I prefer the dry fried flounder because it doesn't feel as greasy. Their hand cut noodles are really chewy and the kiddos enjoy the noodle soup with the soy beans and pickled veggies. 

My only gripe, well there's two. One,
The service is non existent. The waitress is not friendly, comes across rather rude but I think she just can't help it? If you visit the restroom, don't look at the kitchen on the way there or you will be totally turned off by their dish washing and the bad smell of the stair area. You might lose your appetite. 

Prices are reasonable however.
author: Ravenous T.

description: This is a great family run Shanghainese place. Most things are handmade and very fresh. They serve savory soy milk that is fantastic and their xiao long bao (steamed soup dumplings) are always bursting with pork broth. The green onion pancake is always cooked to perfection. Other favorites: stir fried rice cake with pork and noodle soups. The restaurant is small, so plan on going during non-rush hours on weekends or expect a wait.
author: Carmen L.

description:
LOVE LOVE LOVE this place!!! I came here a couple of times and the food has been  consistently delicious. I usually order the dry fried chicken wings and green onion pancake. I tried the bean curd vegetarian dish as well and everything is just yum yum. 
It is definitely worth the wait, but they should do something about the glass window/wall/door in front of the place, because when we have to wait outside for a table, we can see everyone in the store, eating happily. It is kind of awkward for us to stare at the customers insides and for the customers to see us standing in front of the place.
author: Annie X.

description:
This review is purely for the amazingly delicious fried chicken wings. Chinese people have fried chicken? Yes, they do and it's one of the best kinds of fried chicken I've had in a long time. Covered in a garlicy sweet spicy sauce, the chicken is extra crispy on the outside yet moist and flavorful on the inside. I love the extra kick you get from the spiciness as well. Even the bf, who has a high spicy tolerance, thought the wings had a nice spiciness to it. I think these wings are even better than the ones at san tung. 

We also tried the hand made noodles which were okay, but kind of bland and didn't look all that pretty either. They were better after you mixed it with the sauce from the chicken wings however haha. 

Minus one star though for the lack of a bathroom (isn't that illegal for a restaurant?). You can go next door and use the cafe's restroom if you buy something though. Otherwise I would bring wipes or something cause you'll need them for your hands after the eating the wings.
author: Kim J.

description:
Shanghai House just opened this past Thursday.  It replaced the awful Ming Gu Hawaiian restaurant.  Went here for an early lunch this weekend.  At first, I was a little leery because we were the only ones in the restaurant.  A lot of people would walk by and look but they won't come in.  Bad sign right?

Anyhoo, we ordered the following:
Shao Lung Bao (little pork dumplings) - 10 pieces
Green Onion Pancake - 8 pieces
Shanghai Thick Noodle
Shanghai Chow Fun (a nice gummy oval pasta--Taiwan Restaurant makes this!)
Pork Noodle Soup
Chicken Handcut Noodle

OMG!  The food was delicious!  I loved everything we ordered.  The dumplings were very good w/o being greasy (unlike the Shanghai Dumpling King up the block).  I especially liked the Shanghai chow fun and the hand cut noodle.  The handcut noodle is actually shaved noodle. They take a block of pasta and they shaved it w/ a cheese cutter.  I've never seen anything like this in the City.

Most dishes were about $5-$6 tops.  If you're on a budget, I suggest you get the noodle soup.  It came in a BIG bowl and could be shared by 2-3 people.

The onion pancake was good.  On par w/ Taiwan Restaurant's in Clement.

Warning:  If you are in a rush, don't come here because the food came slowly (we suspect it's cuz everything is fresh).  Our lunch took about an 1 hour to finish.  Hopefully they will improve the service --they are new.

This place beats the horrible, dirty Shanghai Dumpling King (I don't get the hype) up the block.  They serve authentic Shanghainese food.  Try it, you won't regret it!
author: Wendy H.

description: This place was highly recommended to me by my boss for 2 dishes: dry chicken wings and xiao long bao. Let's be frank, service is a bit lacking. We were here 15 minutes before anyone gave us the time of day. The food on the other hand is actually pretty good. I've had a lot of xiao long bao in my day and their XLB's are definitely above average. The dry chicken wings are also pretty good; the chicken is very juicy and the skin is so crispy. In terms of the sauce I think it's subjective to the person's palate. After two pieces, the sauce started getting too sweet for me. I still like San Tung's chicken better but this place is definitely a hit!
author: Doris Y.

description:
When I hear about a new place that purports to be Shanghainese, I've got to check it out as soon as the opportunity arises.  When my SIL wanted to meet me for lunch and asked me for suggestions, it gave me an early opportunity to check out the newly opened Shanghai House (Jia JIa Fu) restaurant on Balboa with a couple of representatives from my Shanghai contingent in tow.

There was no doubt about Shanghai House's truly Shanghainese identity, with the server, the other parties there at early lunchtime, and two-thirds of my own party speaking Shanghainese (and me with my usual Yangjingbang). The menu, too, was rock-ribbed Shanghainese cuisine in its offerings, even if some of the "rice" dishes turned out to be somewhat eccentric home-style renditions. Unfortunately, some of the Shanghai "dim sum" items are only offered on weekends (which isn't made clear in the menu).

We ordered xiaolong bao; one cold dish (salted duck); a couple of "rice" dishes, Shanghai classic "meicai kourou" (steamed pork belly with pickled vegetables) and a tofu and seafood clay pot; and one soup, also a Shanghai classic, fried tofu with bean thread noodles.

I was able to approach the xiaolong bao with freshly calibrated taste receptors, having returned from Shanghai just two days before, and am happy to report that they were very good. Only an artlessness in the wrapping (they looked slightly misshapen) and a slight lack of flavor depth in the broth kept them from being the equal of Shanghai Dumpling King's and Oakland's Shanghai Xiao Chi's versions, but at $4.95 for 10 I'm willing to cut them a little slack. I made do with worse at several venues in Shanghai. They also made me vow to return on the weekend to try some of the other Shanghainese brunch items.

The other dishes were a mixed bag. The salty duck was tasty and lean, but had the appearance of being either too old or suffering from refrigerator burn, showing some discoloration and dryness. The pork belly/mei cai was marred by a too-sweet red sauce, but otherwise good. The tofu and seafood hot pot had fried tofu instead of the expected fresh tofu, and also suffered from a confusion of too many ingredients in it. It was almost as if all the ingredients one might toss into seafood hot-pot in the course of a leisurely hot pot dinner were crammed into a modest clay pot. This is not to say that there was anything leftover-ish about the contents; most of the ingredients appeared to be fresh and cooked just the right amount. If you are a seafood nut, this is the Chinese Cioppino for you.

The xifen/you doufu soup was the most peculiar of all. It came with an opaque brown broth, though neither I nor the two Shanghainese have ever seen this soup before with anything but a clear broth. It was savory enough, but a bit jarring visually.

I went return ed the following Saturday for lunch, intending to try some of the Shanghainese brunchie stuff only available on weekends. Nonetheless, I couldn't resist another shot at the xiaolong bao. To accompany it I ordered a couple more of my favorites, savory soy milk (available only on weekends) and green onion pancakes (available daily).

If anything, the xiaolong bao tasted even better than on my initial visit, probably because I brought more of a hunger with me, and were prettier, wrapped more carefully.

The savory soy milk (yan doujiang) turne about to be as good as I've had in SF since the early days of Fountain Court, better than Shanghai Dumpling King's version (good in its own right). It was properly sassy, and properly constructed, down to the inclusion of brine shrimp, which are often omitted. (Do they think those teeny little eyes are going to scare anybody?)

The green onion pancakes (cong you bing) made it three for three. I alsway cross my fingers when ordering this, because there are so many approaches to making it and with many different results, but Shanghai House's version was much to my liking: thick, well-browned and crunchy on the outside and soft and well-seeded with spring onion tops inside.

I talked to the server, who happened to be the daughter of the proprietor. Although she spoke English like an ABC, she had no problem understanding my little Shanghainese. She confirmed that it was a family operation, and said that it was dad who did all the cooking. The other server may have been the mom.

I'll reserve judgement on the regular lunch and dinner fare; our limited sampling of cold apps and rice dishes on our first visit found them to be a hit and miss proposition. But thanks to today's "hat trick" (sorry for that, but the Hockey Haven bar is only three doors up the street from SH) I have a new go-to place for Shanghainese eye-openers. 

[Update 11/10/07] - I downgraded my rating from 5 stars to a still-generous 4 because I finally got there for dinner.  I had my "Gang of Four" (Shanghainese inlaws in tow) and we found the main dishes to be eccentric and overly sweet, even for Shanghainese cuisine.
author: GarySoup I.

description:
I stopped here after reading the newspaper article posted in the window, the title caught my attention: "Shanghai House is worth the wait," and so I waited. 

I ordered green onion pancakes, wonton soup and pork dumplings. I really enjoyed the pancakes and the soup, while the dumpling skin was a bit too thick for me. 

The service was a bit slow, but the wait gave me opportunity to observe other customers, which was nice.

I would definitely recommend the place to my friends and come back for the things recommended by other Yelpers that I didn't get a chance to try yet.
author: Lina P.

description:
I dont know what some people are saying about how this place serves bad Xiao Lung Bao...

yes it had the soup and if you notice, these things are smaller so that it fits your tiny mouth...and when you bite into it, there wont be a spray taht hits everyone across the room...

the chicken wings are incredible...they are spicy but when you first bite into them it gives u a zing but after taht....its gone and tastes sooo good. Last time i had chicken wings this good were at marnee thai and thats a whole different taste. The skin on that chicken was crispy and juicy omg...*drooooooooool*

then the sweet and sour pork...this isnt your neon pink red pork that you find at any chinese restaurant. This pork is cooked differently...a deliciously good different..the sauce is dark and thick and has a somehwat sticky conistency..i have a hunch its honey..but anyhow that pork kicks ass...

and then there is the fried bread(man tao)..so crunchy on the outside nice and soft on the inside..

the only downfall about this place is that there is only one person working the front so that it might take some time...but its worth the wait~
author: phillip w.

description: This place is definitely getting spillover from when SDK recently closed. The food is not NEARLY as good and they don't offer many dumpling options. What's with the rude servers? They never ever smile? And don't speak English..anyway. very odd place. Nothing good going on here at all. Will not be coming back. Whyyy SDK did you have to leave me??
author: Natasha F.

description:
Soo GOOD, yet SOOO SLOW! 

3 people in the kitchen, 1 person at the front. 
It takes forever to order, and it take another forever for the food to come. If you drove, find a non-meter parking spot, becuase this is NOT the place for quickies. 

Their Xiao Long Bao is so juicy, so much better than Shanghai Dumpling King. 
For noodle, try the pan-fried "hand cut" noodle, it's very chewy & yummy. 
Oh, last but not least, order to chicken. you will NOt regret! 

ONE more thing, CASH ONLY!
author: Zee Z.

description: One star for service.. Worst service I have ever experienced. Food was alright but not the best.
author: Amy Y.

description:
Shanghai House is just alright. Came here for dinner with E.G. and Edgar G. one evening. Here's what we ordered:

-Vegetarian Goose: Mushroom wrapped in bean curd with a saue over it-- it was okay. I've had better. The sauce had a bit of a tangy taste to it

-Shanghai dumpling: Soup filled but very deflated as a dumpling when it came out... does that make any sense? I've had better as well.

-Chicken wings: Sweet from the honey and spicy from the red peppers. Probably my most favorite dish of the night

-I don't remember the name of the last dish we got but it was a noodle soup. The noodles are definitely hand pulled and reminded me of Xian Famous Foods in New York City but didn't compare. 

There is only one worker who works in the front. I would have to agree with other yelpers that she looks really tired with her panda eyes. Though it wasn't busy the night I went, the worker was really slow. Even cleaning up tables took her a good 30 minutes or so. Unless I become desperate, I don't think I will be returning. There are other places in SF with much better food.
author: Eugenia G.

description: The food is mediocre. But the service has to be one of the worst ever. We ordered for take out and it still took over an hour to get our food. The two stars is strictly just for the food.
author: c h.

description:
Green Onion Pancakes
Xiao Lung bao
soy been drink 
jelly fish salad
pickled vegetable and pork noodle soup
dry fried chicken wings
dry fried green beans
and most importantly, their salt and pepper pig knuckles....

yum, yum, good.....   

there are limited tables, and service is not really great.   
We go there early as we have a toddler who loves noodles.  

good place, just be sure to bring cash.
author: Regi K.

description: My fav local restaurant. Get the fried chicken and the hand cut noodles. Service is slow since it's family run and not staffed up. Surprisingly the fish head soup is pretty good. Love the clear flat noodles
author: Musetta S.

description:
Came here with family for shanghai dumplings and drunken chicken. The place sure looked family run with the daughter taking care of business and the parents running in the back. The place is kind of small and everything was good, but not to die for. Kind of pricey though so it's a pass for me.

*old review*
author: Diana L.

description:
This is such a welcome addition to the hood. We checked it out last week for an early dinner before a movie at the Balboa. A hint: You should order an item for each person since the portions are fairly large. 

First, we had the chicken soup with thin noodles. It was real comfort food and savory. This was followed by the shanghai dumplings which were delicate and flavorful. Last, we had the mushroom and winter melon clay pot which was probably my favorite. The mushrooms packed a punch full of flavor and the winter melon added the perfect note to mushrooms. Fresh peas were also added which to the dish which only served to accent the other ingredients.

The prices are *very* reasonable and the service wasn't as bad as others had hinted at. At first, the server seemed a bit off-putting but she soon warmed up to us and was quite attentive.

I'll be hitting this place up on a regular basis!
author: Art O.

description:
So after a two-year hiatus, I actually got a chance to return. Came here with my roommate while strolling through the Outer Richmond and didn't even realize I'd written a review here. Since this is my first dine-in experience, I figured it's worth another take.

We ordered three items, xiu long bow, scallion pancakes, and Shanghai noodles. I'd say the highlight were the xiu long bow. Nice and soupy inside, though they could have been a couple degrees hotter. The scallion pancakes were OK, though I've had better, and the same goes for the Shanghai noodles; they were cut a bit short, and little heavy on the white pepper and veggies.

I'd recommend Shanghai House for a quick bite in the hood, but not necessarily worth going out of your way for. 21 bucks and change for three dishes isn't that bad either.
author: Tony L.

description: Came here because the line over at Purple Kow was too ridiculous. I should have walked the few blocks up to Shanghai Dumpling King instead of going over here. The shanghai dumplings were very thick (big no no for me) and had almost not meat or soup in them. (seriously, why didnt I walk the 2 blocks to get the ones at Shanghai Dumpling King). The wait/service was really slow as well. The one good part of the meal was their fried chicken. They were really well fried (crispy) and the sauce was more sweet and spicy compared to San Tung's (sweet and a little bit of ginger). If they had a little less breading, they'd probably be better.
author: James T.

description:
This place is depressing. Its small, its quiet and the music they play sometimes makes you want to cry. But the food makes you forget about life and say to yourself, it is going to be okay ;)

Shanghai House popped my shanghai dumpling cherry, and for that reason, it will always have a special place in my heart. I have searched high and low for another Shanghai restaurant for things equally as good as the menu here and I always come home to the outter richmond. Never mind the fact no freeway exits take you there or that you need to travel 20 minutes within the city to make it there. This is where my heart lies.

The claypot vermicelli and the tea smoked duck are a must have for any visit as I have not seen it on any other Shanghai menu. Do not order from the sucker menu (you'll spot it fast - its the one with sweet and sour pork and broccoli beef). You're in a Shanghai restaurant. Order Shanghai food.
author: Candy C.

description: If I could give a negative review I would. I rarely write up reviews but my dad and I walk into this restaurant thinking we would get some nice dumplings after Christmas. We were the second table seated in the restaurant. We sit we wait they give us tea we order half an hour later the restaurant is full and the waitress comes by and asked us if we ordered. I said yes we ordered 2 Xiao long baos she writes down the order walks away. Fast forward another 20 minutes and everyone else has food and is eating except me and my dad. My dad waves at the waitress and says hello we are still here. She looks over at us and turns away. We walk out. I am never ever coming back here again! Do yourself a favor walk a few blocks up to shanghai dumpling king.
author: erica c.

description:
Dry chicken wings... Gooooodddd!! Crispy skin.. Sweet spicy sauce.. Excellent..

Xiao long bao.. Thick chewy skin.. Not so filled filling but yummy nonetheless.. Broth is good but not as creamy as shanghai dumpling king's..

Pork and vegetable dumplings have very thick skin too..

I DO need to try that pork knuckle that needs to be reserved! But until then, 3 stars it is.
author: My C.

description:
My boyfriend and I were hungry and found parking right in front. So we decided to try it out. We saw two parties sitting already so we walked in.

The waitress wasnt around so we sat ourselves. When she finally appeared she tossed the menus on the table. Let me say that it was NOT busy. So I don't know why she gave attitude...

Fast forward 20 minutes later, we were ready to order and the waitress was no where to be found again. When she came out of hiding we tried to flag her down 4 times before she slowly wobbled over to take our order at the exact same time my boyfriend got up to check on the meter. 

We ordered the chow mien, shanghai dumplings, green onion pancakes and one hot sweet soy bean milk. 

Chow mien: filled with hard cabbage and drenched in oil. Did I mention all you can taste is oil. Gross.

Hot sweet soy milk: it comes in a cup, with soy skin still in it. I don't think they freshly make it themselves since before stirring the glass it tasted likable water.

Shanghai dumplings: had better elsewhere. Half way into the meal the lady brings the vinegar. Thanks lady. The skins to thick for my liking.

Green onion pancakes: two small circles cut into pieces.

For me, nothing here was good. I'd rather drive another 30 minutes to new mandarin garden in south city.
author: Jessica T.

description: yuck. how did this place become so bad??? please skip. it's so gnarly in here.
author: Libra J.

description: Like them better when they were on 19th Avenue and Balboa. Now the only thing good are the dim sum. And very commonly the orders are brought to the wrong table. Several times we got stuff that another table ordered, good for us at the time because we were hungry. Of course we had to pay for it but I could just imagine the table that were waiting and had to wait again..
author: M C.

description:
A quaint and cozy place that delivers relatively good food at reasonable prices. The owner and the Chef themselves are actually Shanghai-nese (I myself come from Shanghai, China) so that brought my expectations even higher. 

The first thing I ordered was the Shanghai pork dumplings. You can't come to a Shanghai-nese restaurant without first trying the dumplings. The dumplings were Good. Juices were flowing inside the skin and the skin itself was not hard - which tells you that they are using the right kind of skin. The meatball inside was also cooked perfectly. So for the dumplings, it has my vote. ::thumbs up:: 

I then ordered the Sour and spicy soup - which to my surprise was kind of disappointing. Way too sour for my taste and not spicy at all. Unbalanced and very one-sided. The amount of veggies included in the soup was pretty good, but I couldnt taste any of it due to the overwhelming sour-ness. There was also a slight bitterness that I didn't like. Maybe they derived from the traditional way of making this soup in order to make it more original? I do not know. 

Following the soup I ordered Fried Tofu. Very nice. Was not deep fried like the other Fried Tofu's out there. The fried skin is very thin - covering the tofu just barely. The tofu was also soft - not firm which is the right way to make fried tofu. This I give my ::thumbs up:: 

The Mongolian Beef and the Kung Pao Chicken was pretty good. The Kung Pao was definitely spicier than the Mongolian Beef however and the peanuts compliments it very very well. The Mongolian Beef was nice and tender, but I had preferred it to be just as spicy or spicier than the Kung Pao. 

Overall, the experience was a good one. The service was okay considering that there's only one waiter there. It would've been nice if they had accepted major credit cards, but I guess it is to keep costs low. A little inconvenient, but bearable. Bank of America is literally a block away on the corner. 


Bottom Line: More or less authentic with some deviation from traditional depending what you get. Overall good experience. It was good, but not fantastic. I do support local businesses so I would go here again.
author: Killah K.

description: We came here after seeing the review on "Check please, Bay Area."  The person who picked this 'hole in the wall' doesn't really know what good food is I guess.  First there was the wait to get in, about 40 minutes.  When we did, we were one of the last before they close for lunch.  We ordered the onion cakes, crispy but bland.  Where or where were the onions?  Then came the vegetarian chow mein.  Bland as the service.  The dried fried chicken was good but I could get that at San Tung.  I think I'll look elsewhere for good Shanghai food-like Bund in Chinatown.  This place actually warrants zero stars but can't put that on here.
author: David P.

description: So you are waiting outside, ravenous to order. But, you get handed a menu and your order is taken while you wait on the street corner. The moment you sit down, your table is loaded with delicious food. All of it will be consumed. All of it.
author: Lisa K.

description:
Hubby's friend suggested this restaurant to us and we tried it with the kids hoping to find a new place for our girl's birthday party. Parking was not easy as there was a concert 2 blocks away in Gold Gate Park.

We have ordered the following items for 5 people, 3 adults and 2 kids: -
1) Shanghai dumplings (siu lung bao) 10 small pieces
2) Green onion pancakes
3) Shanghai rice cakes with pickles and shredded porks
4) Spicy beef tendons
5) Wonton and vegetable noodle soup
6) Sweet soy milk

Overall, the food were tasty but portions were small as compared to Shanghai Dumping King a few blocks away. The kids loved soy milk the most and $1.65 for a big glass of kids-approved was really worth for us. The spicy beef tendons were quite hot and the cucumber was a good side of the dish. One thing that I really like is the ginger in the vinegar dipping sauce was cut thin enough and was plentiful to come with the shanghai dumplings.

Total amount of $36 including tax was a good deal and we have finished all the food.

The food would worth a 4-4.5 stars but at least 1 star has been deducted because of the service. The waitress has major attitude problem. She did not give us the menu (I went to take it myself) and kept ignoring us even when we tried to get the bill. I would rather go to Shanghai Dumpling King for my girl's birthday again. At least, we got pretty good services there all the times. For a restaurant, food is important but service should not be ignored. My hubby's friend said that the waitress always acts like that. When you go back several times and she recognizes you, her service would be totally different. Well, if you don't treat new customers good, how would they come back as returned customers? Fair enough?
author: Roserrele W.

description: First and last time here. Service is awful, food is awful. Somebody woke up on the wrong foot this year.
author: Nikola M.

description: I knew it was a mistake when I walked in, service is just bad, I feel like they don't want my business. Anyway, my girl really want to eat here, we sat down. We ordered 3 item, 1 xiaoloong bow, 1 pan fried bun, and the dry fried wings. The xiaoloong bow is good, not exceptional, skin is thin but not that juicy, the xiaoloong bow is a 3.5 star. The wing is horrible, 10.50 for 7 wings, the skin is so hard, not crispy but hard, never had fried wings that bad. Then pan fried bun was ok. The tea they serve was taste like water, the tea leaves been in there all day, that's what it taste like, get water instead. There's no where that said they are cash only business, so I only know that when I pay, I don't mind paying cash, just don't try to hide it, be up front about it. I won't come back, for sure, the food quality is not worth for the crappy service. And I really have to warn about the chicken wings, don't try.
author: Kevin X.

description:
The bf and I order from here a lot because it's close and it's good. The XLB are juicy, and the shanghai specialties (like stir fried rice cake, the braised bean thread sheet, fresh noodles) are all delicious. We've tried the shanghai style dim sum for lunch before too, and it's also good! This place really hits the spot when I'm craving savoury soy milk, onion pancake, fried dumpling-y bun things, and sticky rice rolls. I just ordered from them right now and am waiting for my takeout order. I can't wait for the dry fried chicken wings and dry sauteed string beans! And the to-go orders are always so fast! The lady always forgets to tell me how long it'll take but I always assume 15 mins, and when I get there it's always ready for me!

But be warned, CASH only! (there's a B of A a block away, though, if that's your bank)
author: Jessie C.

description: Good place to order togo.
author: Byron L.

description:
This place is AMAZING. It never disappoints. I visit the Shanghai House at least once a month since I'll start missing it. As a Buddhist vegetarian, I dislike onions and garlic in my Chinese food (AND DUH...lots of Chinese food is seasoned with this), and the waitress-owner lady is always very accommodating and makes sure that my food is prepared the correct way. This is what I always get: 

1) Winter Melon Soup (veggie broth) 
2) Green Onion Pancakes 
3) Vegetarian Fan Tuan (sorry, I don't know the English for this) 
4) Veggie Goose 
5) Veggie Dumplings (these are OK....not amazing...but still) 
6) Sweet Soy Milk 
7) Vegetable of the day sauteed. 

yeh...I eat a lot.
author: Lillian S.

description:
Looking for Shanghainese eats?  Shanghai House is a solid choice!  Yes, the service is not great, but I feel like it mostly had to do with the language barrier.  The food totally makes up for it!

XLB: Quite soupy, but the skin is a little thick for me.  Still, solid.

Dry fried chicken wings: nice and crispy, large and juicy!

Hot soy milk: OMG!  fresh made sweet soy milk is so good!  just hits the spot!

Pan fried hand-cut noodles: so-so...the noodles are nice and chewy, but it felt like it was mostly cabbage
author: Fontane L.

description:
this review is for the XLB only. they're pretty good. n much cleaner than their competition down the street. :)

a little small, n not super friendly, but i dont expect much from a chinese restaurant...
author: Lisa N.

description: Don't bother making a reservation here.  Our group of four made a reservation for 6:30 last night and ended up freezing outside until well after 7:15.  Once seated we shared the xiao long bao, roasted pork knuckle, 8 treasures soup, fish head soup, and spicy chicken wings.  Everything was fantastic except for the fish head soup which lacked any meat and tasted a bit "off".  Also of note, this place is BYOB, so if you want beer go a couple doors down to the store and get a few to go with your meal.  Were it not for the screw up with our reservation, I'd happily give this place 4 stars.
author: Joshua W.

description:
I usually don't make trips into Outer Richmond for food. Shanghai House is one exception I'll make when I am craving delicious Dan Dan Noodles and Freshly Made Soy Milk (which by the way will sell out if you get there too late into the evening). 

The staff are friendly and courteous. They speak both Mandarin and a good amount of Cantonese. I am sure they speak Shanghainese too, but I wouldn't be able to tell you what they are saying. I've been told by Shanghainese friends that have gone with me to eat here that it's "authentic" and the food met their expectations.

I've tried quite a few items from their menu ranging from the xiao long bao, to multiple types of noodles, the drunken chicken (which by the way is quite good), and Chinese pancakes. 

Prices are reasonable and the portions are sized relatively well. 

I dropped 1 star because while the service is good, they only take cash AND the food takes FOREVER to get to your dining table. Please snack a little before coming here or drink lots of the hot tea they serve to you.

Place is tiny, but it's cozy. It's rather easy to find parking especially in the evening hours. During the day, there are tons of metered parking that never fills up.

Not necessarily related to the restaurant, but bring a jacket because it gets cold in the Outer Richmond.
author: Tina C.

description: Overhead at the table next to us: "This is the best Shanghai food outside of Shanghai."  Wow, you have to be kidding me.  This is average Shanghai food at best.  All of the prior posts about a slow kitchen are absolutely true and not an idea place for the impatient ones.  It be different if you were getting he best dumplings in the world but when you are waiting for average food, it is truly a tough swallow.  The waitress has no sense of urgency and clearly thinks she is working for one of the State-owned restaurants in China 10-years ago.  Still, apparently, the Cantonese peeps of Outer Richmond thinks this is good Shanghai cuisine...  For me, it's a no-go.
author: Laurence H.

description:
I never really knew what a Xiao Long Bao was. There are just too many types of 'baos' and I get em all mixed up. Now I know, and I'm a believer. 

So..its this Shanghai dumpling (duh) that's steamed in a way that all the porky meat juices are retained within the skin. That liquid right there, is the shit. It's worth the risk of burning your tongue. I could eat a whole order of them (10 for ~$6)

Also good: the dry fried chicken wings. I think they're better than San Tung and without the 1hr wait!

The place is super small..and the waitress there is kinda in her own world, and you're pretty much on your own, but whatever. It's a good spot to grab some dumplings and other 'dim sum' stuff and doesn't put a dent in your wallet.
author: Jessica h.

description:
I come here for their Xiao Long Bao. The best ever. It's a little dumpling with soup inside. I've tried the ones down the street at Shanghai Dumpling King and they were not good. In fact no one at my table could eat them because we were spoiled with the ones here. But.....I have ordered about 5 other dishes here and they were not very good. I usually go here for Xiao Long Bao and then walk to Shang Hai King for other dishes.
...........my mouth is watering right now.......so hungry and wish I could eat here, but I'm down south now.....   :(
author: LoveFood W.

description:
How do I express my love-hate relationship with Shanghai House?  I've loved their food since they opened, but the service drives me absolutely insane!!  There's only one woman working as the cashier/waitress/server/busboy; with all those responsibilities, you would think she's superwoman.......but she's not.  The service is ridiculously slow and the food takes ages to arrive.  That brings us to the sole reason why I continue to go to Shanghai House: the food is amazing.

1. Shanghai dumplings - 10 in each order, each perfectly plump and full of juices...soup I meant. (5/5)
2. Vegetarian goose - I honestly cannot tell you why it's called goose- I think it's made of some tofu skin.  I'm allergic but still order it anyway - that's how delicious it is, really. (5/5)
3. Dry fried chicken wings - amazingly sweet and spicy and flavorful.  Definitely up to par with the infamous San Tung chicken.  Sadly, it is a little inconsistent - It's sometimes better (spicier and sweeter) and sometimes worse (saltier) than San Tung's dry fried chicken. (4/5)
4. Hand-cut noodles - tasted like a chow mein type dish.  Noodles were thick and uneven.  I enjoyed it, but it was a little too greasy. (3/5)
4. Chinese donut - don't do it!  Really, it's not because it's disgustingly unhealthy and deep fried, but because it looks and tastes like it.  It looks kind of like a churro, minus the cinnamon and sugar and amazingness.  Imagine a long brick of dough, injected with butter and lard, and deep-fried.  (0/5)

Give yourself an extra 10 mins to find parking, and an additional 30 mins to wait for your food.
author: Betty W.

description:
It's all about the Xiaolongbao... Sometimes it's a long wait for a table, and then a long wait to order, and then even a longer time for the food to come out, but it's worth the wait. 

The Xiaolongbao is amazing, probably the best in San Francisco.  Almost as good as the Din Tai Fung in Taipei.   I also recommend the Lions Head, Pig Knuckle and chicken covered in a sticky and sweet/spicy sauce.

But be prepared for the wait....
author: Avan M.

description:
Usually busy at dinner. Service can be slow no matter what time of day, cash only. 

My usual order consists of shanghai dumplings, dry fried chicken wings or shrimp, both are amazing... and depending on how many others are there, buddha's delight, the fried rice, or pork with vegetables and rice clay pot. The chicken wings here are JUST as good as san tung, they are bigger and have a different flavor. More spicy, less sweet. 

If you don't feel like waiting, you can always order for take out.
author: Diana H.

description:
My favorite place for authentic Shanghai food! I love almost every single dish I had so far.  Even after I moved to south bay, I will try to go there whenever I'm in town.

It is not a big restaurant, with a capacity of ~25-30; therefore, I usually give up waiting if I'm not the first on in line.  I highly recommend the  Shanghai dim sum, especially the meat dumplings (Shiaolongbao).
author: D C.

description:
A very average but cheap place. For about 22 dollars, you will get about three generously sized dishes. We had the rice with salted pork clay pot and it was boring. It had shreds of bok choy and lots of white rice and a few thin ham slices on the top.  It tasted home-made.

We also had the hand-cut noodles which looked weird, like a kid made it from play dough. Akwardly cut noodles that came in different sizes.  It was wokked with onions and pork. All the dishes came with little meat. What I liked about these dishes were that they were low in oil and salt making them relatively healthy but tasted very average.  We also bought the Shanghai noodles to go and it came to 22.15. 

They also give you complimentary fruit as dessert which was quite nice. The bathroom was really hard to get to, it was up steep stairs behind the kitchen. The worse thing about this place was the service. The woman who I assumed was the wife of the owner looked really depressed and seemed like she didn't want to serve us. She hardly looked at us and just plopped plates on our tables loudly and left. She short-changed us by ten dollars, forgot to bring us a bag after we asked for it, and kept talking on the phone. 

I really wanted to love this place with all the positive reviews from other Yelpers but this place just didn't meet my expectations, I would rather go down the street to the Shanghai King Dumpling shop.
author: Lorissa W.

description:
I'll cut to the chase.  

1.Bad service - took our tea pot when it was empty....and it never came back.  Not to mention the 15 min wait until we got menus.  Vinegar 
2.Only ok dumplings - not that much soup, which kinda is the whole point...

It's a small place and you can tell they're under-staffed, but it doesn't make for a pleasant experience.  Average food gets 3 stars, minus 1 for service.
author: Phil L.

description: This restaurant is small and is cash only.  The food is great but be prepared to wait on a busy weekend lunch hour.  I'm a fan of the tofu noodles, rice rolls, and soups.  The shall long baos are savory and hot.  They also take to go orders which is convenient.  I also enjoy the savory or sweet soy milk served hot. My favorite dish here is the pork leg mmm mmm good!
author: Jennie W.

description:
Hitting up the Balboa theater? This is the spot to hit beforehand.

Hungover and it's too late to grab McDonald's breakfast? Soak up some stomach lovin' with Shanghai House's soup dumplings and then get the fried chinese donut for dessert.

You don't come for the service, but you do come to be completely satisfied with your food. Besides the dumplings, I recommend the green beans (spicy!) 

Remember, cash only!

Also, you have to walk through the kitchen to go to the bathroom, which is up a wierdo staircase. Odd, but you do get to glimpse the old chinese men making the dim sum.
author: Christina C.

description:
Shanghai dumpling king was a long wait and we were hungry. I noticed a new sign for Shanghai House when we were driving over so we decided to walk a few blocks down and check it out. 

The restaurant is small, but clean. The waitresses don't speak much english but pointing at the menu is sufficient. 

We ordered:
Salty Soy Milk  - my default order for shanghai and it was yummy.
Tea-smoked duck! -  the highlight, crispy and flavorful
Xiao Long Bao - just as good as SDK
Shanghai noodles

After we left I was bummed that we forgot to order the Green Onion Pancake. Will have to come back again.
author: vicki c.

description:
I went here for one thing. Many say soup dumplings, or shanghai dumplings, or even the abreviated XLB.  I finally looked up Xiao Long Bao and found this place. 

One word, disappointing. The skin was very thick on top and very thin on bottom. Obviously any "soup" that may or may not have been in them would leak out on the wax paper. The filling was good so not all was lost.

The quest still continues.
author: Eugene P.

description: I love this place. It has some great dumplings, some overly greasy other foods, which is to be expected, and some good soups and noodles. This is one of my favorites in the city. I recently took a trip down to LA where I visited Din Tai Fung - one of the best and most famous dumpling places  in the world. Yes, it was good, but I no longer felt it was super special because I had been eating here and at Koi Palace! This place might not be better, but I would say that it comes only a short distance behind. Service is slow, but expected because they're probably cooked to order.
author: Alton Y.

description:
It's possible the waitress was the also the person cooking the food because we arrived and waited quite a while before she showed up. 

Soup Dumplings: Average - There was very little soup, which is the only way I've found them so far in SF, most of mine broke and the meat was not as flavorful as others I've tried. 

Hand cut noodles: Average - noodles were good but meat quality and oily bland taste reminded me of mall fastfood.

Dry fried chicken wings: Good - has a great sweet spicy sauce, but the chicken is very high in fat because of being dipped in batter and deep fried. Don't get me wrong the wings taste great the batter is wonderfully crispy. Sometimes things in life that are good aren't good for you.
author: Alaina I.

description: Dry fried chicken wings is really good, but the service really have a big space to catch up.
author: Ricki Y.

description: Love the food here. Shanghai dumpling here is filled with soup! Onions pancakes is a must to try!
author: Patricia T.

description:
I love eating at Shanghai House! The dishes are delicious, and at a very good price. I love all their noodle dishes. I highly recommend ordering their noodle dishes.

It's a small place with a small staff. If you want service you have to ask for it.

HIGHLY RECOMMENDED
author: Chatree T.

description:
After a night out and a rainy morning my friend and I were in search for something warm and yummy.  We came to Shanghai house and ordered the xiao long bao!  And boy did it hit the spot. YUM!  I really liked it!  Service was a little slow but the food is great!

Come and try the xiao long bao!!!!
author: Joanne H.

description: Shanghai dumplings, pot stickers, wonton soup, all amazing.  Mongolian beef was soooooo spicy, but also very good.  It's BYOB - which is cool.  However, service I incredibly slow and fairly unfriendly - however according to my Chinese dining mate, he wouldn't expect it any other way.
author: Heather L.

description: Happened to be in the neighborhood, stopped in for lunch. Waitress recommended the Shanghai dumplings and the chicken wings. I went with the dumplings; ten for $5.95 and they were awesome.
author: Terry S.

description:
I went here for the first time and loved it.
I had the vegetarian goose. It was amazing.
Can't wait to go back for more!
author: Eva UnTiger S.

description: I'm a big fan of the restaurant.  I feel it is very authentic and the shaved noodles were out of this world.  We enjoyed 8 other dishes and loved them all.  The service was kind of slow and disorganized but the food was Fantastic!
author: Tomm J.

description:
I must admit, they have good dumplings in this restaurant.  The problem is the service.

First, there is only one waitress.  Sure it's a small restaurant, but it took 35 minutes for the waitress to get to my table.  She doesn't bother coming up to my friends and for drinks or nothing.  

Second, the only waitress is biased.  What I mean is that she will service older people and white customers first.  If you are a young Chinese student, she's going to service you last.  It's actually very frustrating.  

Third, dirty plates.  There was a hair in my tea cup.  What the hell.  AND it was not the first time.  The first time was a green substance stuck on my plate.  It was disgusting.

Personally, I will only go there to eat again if I AM NOT PAYING FOR IT.
author: Chih Chu Z.

description:
shanghai house looks very modern with a glass door and glass storefront. the walls are all white and immaculate. the tables have painted images of bamboo and koi fish with a plastic overlay

sampling:
-xiao lung bao(10/5.50) hot juicy soup inside, these small  morsels are the most tasty i've had in a while. there's just a little meat and it's not bland. came with nice red vinegar w/ginger dipping sauce.
-zazang mien (5.95) looked like spaghetti with ground beef, diced cucumber, diced tofu pieces,  chili pieces in a brown sauce. definitely not hand pull noodles. probably reconsitututed dry noodles from china

leftovers:
-on the steps up to the bathroom, one discovers this place used to be a house.
-teresa, the waitress, only takes the order. the kitchen help brings out the food. you won't see her again till she says "thank you" when you leave.
-unsure whether to repeat, only the xlb is excellent, the rest of the menu is problematic and/or pedestrian. (read the reviews)
-teresa was unsure where to sit me. finally she cleared the newspapers off one table and gave me her reading table.
-only about 10 coupled tables here, sits about 50 people at most
-cash only.
author: Victor G.

description:
So, it was Valentine's day and I did not have a date. Conveniently, I have a friend who actually avoids Valentine's day dates like the plague (he's messed up a little bit). In any case, this meant it was definitely the perfect night for a bromantic escapade to the Outer Richmond to eat Chinese food. Obviously.

Dinner at Shanghai House was about as perfect of a Chinese meal as I've ever had. Of course, we started with the shanghai soup dumplings (XLB for those in the know). I wouldn't say they were as amazing as the ones I had in NYC, but they were close. Really, really, great. We then got the Tan-Tan Noodles, which were super-garlicky, a little spicy, but still somehow light and refreshing. Then we ordered the killer dry-spice chicken wings. These are not to be messed with! HUGE fryolated wings in a spicy-sweet sauce that consists of so much sugar, it can only stay viscous for about 5 minutes before hardening. But it's an amazing 5 minutes. Finally, we had the "tea-smoked duck", which was tender, juicy, fatty, smokey, and all around awesome for $10. Seriously.

The two must-do tips here are: 1. Order off of the "shanghai" menu and stay clear of the "normal" menu. We saw some people eating the americanized dishes of that menu and I'm pretty pf changs would do it better. 2. No matter how full you are, get the sweet sesame seed dumplings in rice wine for dessert. It's on the dim sum menu but you MUST MUST try this. You get 4 simple dumplings swimming in rice wine (sake) stuffed with black ground sesame seed. The inside is so sweet, the dumpling so moist, and the rice wine so able to cut through the sweetness, that you leave almost forgetting you consumed enough to feed a family of five.

And all of this, for two people, with generous service, tax, tip included, was $42. Unbelievable.
author: Tolga E.

description:
This is one of the few reasons for me to go to the far Outer Richmond. It's a small place that may require a wait. Parking may be somewhat of a pain as well. But there are some great dishes here comparable to Sang Tung if you are a fan of that restaraunt.

The dried fried chicken wings are very similar to San Tung but it is less sweet and spicier. The chicken is still crispy and saucy at the same time, however they do look a lot darker. And probably what makes it spicy is the fact that the chicken is coated in chili pepper seeds as well.

I never had tea smoked duck before and thought it was pretty good here. There's a great smokiness to the dish you can smell and taste. Duck doesn't have a lot of meat to begin with so this isn't a huge meat dish but it's crispy, and the taste kind reminds me of ham. The duck also comes with some steamed buns and hoisin sauce to eat it like peiking duck during banquets if you wish.

The xiao long bao is not has soupy as I was expecting. There is no lettuce cooked with it as well. But given that, I think this was one of the better places I have had it in SF. Not too much wrap and the pork was cooked well.

The dried fried string beans are still firm and not over cooked till they're mushy. And there is a good wok flavor with it. The rice cake is also pretty good as well and worth a try.

I would  recommend a try here. It is not perfect but they do many dishes right. Definitely earned a spot in my rotation of SF Chinese restaraunts.
author: Daniel L.

description:
Very disappointing. Lots of MSG. Two of the four people in our party left with headaches and three of us feel queasy. We went for the Shanghai dumplings ("dragon balls") and found them fairly bland. Don't bother with the Dan Dan noodles either. 

The person who served us was also quite rude. They actually turned off the lights in the place while we were still eating. Overall, just a surly experience with very mediocre food.
author: Gideon R.

description:
Guys! I have been there five times and I consider this place one of the best Chinese around. Try their vegetarian goose or their homemade noodles (Shanghai or hand cut) or their sweet black sesame balls in rice wine.  What about their Shanghai dumplings? as good as Yank Sing's, but, ehi,  3X cheaper! 
Monstrously good ratio quality/price.  

It's a real shame that their average rating is only 3.5. They truly deserve much more.
author: Andrea L.

description:
I started going here after a bad experience with xiao lung bao at the Dumpling King (I've since gone back to the King and been a-ok) but I would never go back again.
The main waitress/owner was completely rude and provided horrible service the last time I was there. I had to wait 45 minutes for my XLB- aka long after the rest of my table had finished their meal and only after I flagged down the waitress and asked where my dumplings were.
The XLB are good and the shanghai fried rice cake is tasty but only if you want to deal with terrible service.
author: Virginia C.

description:
This should get 3 stars but I'm taking away one because of the terrible service. We waited 30 minutes for food. When we asked what was taking so long, the waitress casually said that they had made a mistake in the order. Now, it's understandable that mistakes happen but she was pretty rude about it and did not seem very apologetic. 

Foodwise, I'd say it was pretty typical. We had "fen pei" which was a bit more watery than I liked but the taste was not too bad. We also ordered some chow mein which again, was pretty standard. 

Overall, I don't recommend this place if I'm in this part of town. The food is so-so and the service was pretty bad. I'd rather head over to Shanghai Dumpling King for better food and service. 

FYI, CASH ONLY!
author: Jonathan L.

description: Ok, so after writing the initial review, I have been back to this place about 5 times. Each time I come back I never fail to order the dry fried chicken wings. Best wings in SF hands down. What about San Tung you say? OVERHYPED. Try these wings out, I promise you will not be disappointed ... unless you lack taste buds or something.
author: Colin H.

description:
I came here for dinner last night before flying back out to San Diego. Again, their Shanghai dumplings were so amazing. OK, now for the other stuff they make.
Honestly, their noodle dishes could REALLY use a lot more veggies/meat/something OTHER than noodles! They give you a LOT of noodles.. I'm kind of disappointed about that, but then again, maybe that's the way they like it in Shanghai? Parents and I ordered the usual Shanghai style noodles, which of course was good, but had way too many noodles. I don't particularly like their noodle:meat/veggie ratio.. it sucks. We also got this tan tan noodle ("dan dan mian") which was quite good because it was a little spicy, but not TOO spicy. Again, it had a lot of noodles in it compared to the chicken and shrimp, but the sauce was good. At this point, I really think that the taste overpowers the ratio, in my opinion at least.
We also ordered the fried chicken which was really good too. The chicken probably would've tasted a little better if it were more moist though.
Lastly, we ordered this vegetarian dish--mushrooms wrapped in bean curd. It was SO GOOD. I kid you not, I think it's one of my favorites now.
Last time, my mom, brother, and I ordered this rice cake thing which was really good too (my apologies for forgetting the name of it!).
Overall, I'm still a huge fan. No complaints here!
author: Leslie C.

description:
Not sure why the reviews aren't better for this place.  It was excellent.

The standard Yelp order:
Scallion Pancakes (perfection).
The Hot Dry Chicken Wings (Amazing).
The Pork Dumplings (outstanding, though the veggie ones looked just as good).

Would recommend and certainly return.
author: Andre C.

description: Food might be awesome, but service SUCKS, one person for the entire place. it's RIDICULOUS, you might die of a tape worm faster than you would get served here. they only way to eat here is take out.
author: SF Native M.

description:
Had lunch here.

I had the tan tan noodles. A lil watery than I've seen it, but the taste is good.

Dumplings: good. Short on the soup inside, but the pork is very good. 

The comments about the waitress on the other review is very true. She is not pleasant  and does not smile at all.
author: Mai H.

description: I have been here a couple of times. My family and I love the food. However, the waitress is so rude its almost funny. Customer service is completely thrown out the window. She yelled at us. Took more than 30 minutes to bring us the check. Didn't serve water until we were almost done with dinner. She includes the tip with the check but in my opinion she doesn't deserve a penny.
author: Lourdes P.

description: I came to this place hoping to get my xlb fix but was deeply disappointed. The xlb had a good amount of soup in it and was quite flavorful but the skin was very thick which in turn ruined the whole mouth feel. I also had the pot stickers, pork and veggie dumpling, and the fried chicken wings. The pot stickers were incredibly small and was ok...The pork and veggie dumplings were super small and tasteless. I think that was the worst of all the dishes we had. But what was surprisingly good was the fried chicken wings. The wings were HUGE and very crispy drenched in this sweet savory garlicy sauce. Very delicious, probably why I am giving this three stars and not two. Don't come here for the dumplings, come for the chicken wings!
author: Cindy C.

description:
NO NO NO NO NO NO!!!

I was totally looking forward to dinner with friends here, supposedly since I was told this was one of the "Top 100" places you have to try according to the Chronicle. It's okay, I still love you. But WHAT A MISS! You don't have to be an Shanghainese food expert to know that some of these dishes were just bad. It's freakin obvious. 

Pork Chop Noodles - The noodles were so bland! No flavorings whatsoever. Not even some salt! The texture was bad too, mushy and just plain dull. The pork chop portion came seperately and those tasted fine. We also got another noodle dish but I forgot what it was called. It tasted exactly the same, GROSS. 

Green Onion Pancakes - These pancakes were tough to eat. It was also very doughy and dry. It had none of the crisp and oily textures that I'm used to with ones that I like. The only flavors I tasted were salt and dough. 

Bok Choy, Mushrooms and Tofu - A veggie dish can't be that bad right? Well let me tell you, some of the bok choy was SOO bitter! Where the heck do these people get their produce? Mushrooms were whatevers. My friends said the tofu resembled balls...the ones guys have. Haha yes, we're very mature. This convo basically killed my appetite. 

The Soup Dumplings and the Fried Bread (served with condensed milk!) saved them from being a total downer.
author: Julia T.

description:
I'm not understanding why this place is packed on the weekend and why the reviews are good.  

It's a cute, small place, so definitely not good for large crowds, and very clean, which is more than i can say for a lot of small Chinese restaurants.  The hostess, however, looked like she was angry the whole time.  She didn't make any effort to seem interested and even looked annoyed that we would dare open our mouths to order food.  

My date and I ordered the Shanghai dumplings, Shanghai noodles, and crispy noodles.  Let me just say the dumplings were fine.  They were not as good as the Shanghai place just a few blocks down, but they weren't bad.   However, everything else was just WAY too salty.  I could taste the river of soy sauce (I can LITERALLY smell the soy sauce) that was doused into the food in lieu of real any real flavor.

Both my date and I agreed we will not come back.
author: S. D.

description:
Passable authentic Shanghai food.  Fairly clean. 
Service, well, like all other Chinese restaurants, cheap or expensive,  is non-existent.  If they put on a smile, it might crack their faces!
author: Henry L.

description:
My family was visiting me over the weekend and after a day at Land's End they were pretty hungry.  The thing is my dad will only eat Chinese food, ok my brothers and I have since convinced him Pho is good and he'll tolerate Korean food, but that's pretty much it.  With that in mind I've been craving some really good Shanghainese food and I heard about Shanghai House through Yelp at that 7x7 list.  

First of all the service was extremely slow.  We waited a good 25 minutes before we even received our Xiaolongbao and eventually the rest of our food started trickling out as well.  We thought no big deal, since I was hoping to finally find a Chinese restaurant that would get it right.  

The Xiaolongbao was alright, the flavor was good, but they were tiny, but at least soupy. We ordered off of the Shanghai specials and were disappointed by the twice cooked pork (they used the wrong type of pork) and the shrimp (it's supposed to come with a vinegar dipping sauce)...I know I'm being harsh, but I guess I had high hopes since it's been ages since my last trip to Shanghai...guess I'll just have to keep dreaming about really awesome Chinese food until my next trip, in the meantime the food isn't bad here, but there are plenty of other Chinese restaurants with the same quality that don't make you wait forever to eat.
author: T V.

description:
I was very curious to try a new shanghai dumpling place (just in case the wait for my beloved Shanghai Dumpling King is ever too long). 
We shared:
Vegetarian Goose: mushroom covered in tofu, fried and covered in sweet sauce. Delish
Shanghai Dumplings: Very similar to shanghai dumpling king except a little less flavorful and the sauce isn't as good. 
Vegetarian Dumplings: Pretty good, not great, mostly cabbage with a bit of mushroom & tofu
Pork Bao: stewed pork with veggies (as opposed to the BBQ variety). I really liked these because they had much better filling to dough ratio then any bao I've had before. 
Red Bean Bao: Soooo delicious. What a great dessert! 
The verdict: I think I'll always check Dumpling King first, but this joint is a great second choice.
author: Lauren T.

description: As another reviewer noted, the service is SLOW. I ordered pot stickers -- those were good. For my entree, I ordered the Broccoli Beef -- it was smothered in a "gloppy" brown sauce and was nothing special. I can't see myself going back.
author: Paul L.

description:
I don't get it. Why is this restaurant on 7x7's list of 100 places to eat in the city? Kingdom of Dumpling is way better!! There is only one type of soup dumpling... And the dumplings are small! One high note, they do give you a good portion of the vinegar and ginger sauce. I love to see my dumplings swimming in the sauce! 

Small establishment. Clean and bright. Decent service but not the most enthusiastic or lively hostess/waitress. I didn't have trouble getting a seat but I hear that it can get busy... Cash only too!

Sorry, but you should go to Kingdom of Dumpling if you want the best soup dumplings in the city.
author: Tina Y.

description: Good was really good but afterwards I was super thirsty and sleepy. MSG? Maybe? All the deep-fried greasy food didn't sit well with me. It's a shame I can't go back.
author: Annie P.

description: Small place. Really great food/dumplings obviously. The service was good too. Definitely recommend it.
author: Jimmy M.

description:
My fam took me here last weekend and we had a great time.  The service was prompt, we made reservations in advance and walked right in to our table which was already set for four.
The menu was pretty large so we started to order many dishes.  Ofcourse we had the Shanghai Dumps, Pork & Shrimp Dumps, Veggie Dumps, Spicy Eggplant (excellent), Dry Fried Chix (excellent), Salt Pepper Pork Ribs (aah- dry), Green Onion Pancakes (yum), Hand cut noodles (Chow Fun).  All was good and tasty, the food came hella fast, we chowed down and were very satisfied.  It was very fulfilling, we were all stuffed.  Gotta try it for yourself!
G'
author: gordon g.

description: Listen if you want good food, come here and get the wings, shrimp, pork knuckle, 8 previous noodle soup and pea shoots.  It's not about the service you ignorants who think you walk into a place like this expecting four star service.
