Mom and pop ship literally.You will wait, your food will come unevenly, but in the end it will be worth it. Stop whining, this place is a gem.
author: shar d.

description:
I brought a date here for a little Xiao Long Bao appetizer after a long afternoon of walking through GG Park's gardens. Thank you Yelpers and thanks Shanghai House for not disappointing. The dumplings were superb, pretty close to what I've eaten in Shanghai. Bonus points for putting ginger in the side vinegar! The other dish we ordered, "zhao pai" eggplant and shrimp, also very well done. The boss and even the cooks in back were very friendly. More bonus points for good restaurant/bathroom cleanliness. 

Overall great experience. I probably owe most of that to my date and the great conversation, but Shanghai House did a nice job "setting the stage".
author: Jonathan W.

description:
Walked by and skipped eating at this place many times (usually because it was either too crowded or closed when I passed by) for a LONG time after it opened and replaced the Hawaiian BBQ shop that occupied the same storefront before it.  I finally ate there about a year ago.  So, my comments are not timely, but from the recent reviews posted things haven't changed much. 

Went there mainly for the xao lung bao, which I thought were pretty good.  The rest of the food we had (forget exactly what) was ok  -- not memorable as being very good or bad.  The service was so-so, but the food was served reasonably promptly.  The space is small and the tables are crowded pretty close together.  So, you won't get any privacy here, but the food is decent and reasonably priced.  However, I haven't eaten here again since, which pretty much tells you what I think of it. 

If you're in the mood for xao lung bao and can find a table there when they are open, give it a try, but otherwise you can get a meal as good or better at one of the many other restaurants located within a block of the Shanghai House.
author: Martin C.

description:
5 stars for the shanghai "baby" soup dumplings. it's one of the few that are authentic like the ones at Shang Hai. I do wish the wrapping of the dumping to be a little be thinner....but it's really good. seriously.

originally, i did think this place is for those ABCs. i never ever thought this place has such great dumplings. but i was wrong. i can see why the baby soup dumplings at this place is listed in the 7x7 big eat listing @ SF.

the noodles are great too...esp the knife cut noodle soup! they were delicious. the noodles were perfect - they have the right bite to it :D

i don't mind about the dirty hole or the not-necessary-great-or-sometimes-even-poor service. but that's just me. if you are looking for a place with nice seating and personal service, this is a wrong place to be. but if you want to have some great dumplings, this is it! 

i tried other dishes in the restaurant. they were just ok. they weren't unforgettable/impressive as the dumplings and noodles. the menu, in my opinion, is slightly Americanized. it's a cash only place. i don't mind. i just wanna get my dumplings w/o flying back to China :P

so, 5 stars for the soup dumplings. ~3 stars for other dishes on the menu. 1.5 stars for the restroom (it's not easy to get to there - have to walk through part of the kitchen and the steep stairs).
author: Michelle L.

description:
well.. heres the deal... the pork belly... was fantastic!! OMGGGG... im drooling just thinking about it again. Unlike most places, the pork belly was cut pretty thinly.  and each slice practically melted in my mouth.  

The dry chicken wings... awesome.  crispy and very spicy.  well spicy enough.

However, the dumpling.. bleh.  I think i will stick with the dumpling king down the street for that.  I just dont think it was cooked long enough.  the skin was still a little hard and the meat i think was a little raw.  

But i will definitely come back for the pork belly and chicken wings... yummmm
author: Janet S.

description:
Authentic Shanghainese food.  Cash Only

There are 2 menu - be sure to ask for both.

Shanghainese Menu 
Pork Knuckle (Special - should call to order in advance since it takes a long time to cook) - A big chunk of slow roasted , flavorful and tender meat. 

XLB - As good as it gets.  On par with Shanghai Dumpling House 

Ricecake, sweet or savory soy bean  milk, vegetarian goose, wonton, and other dumplings are all authentic.   

Chinese Menu
Dry fried chicken wings, fish, and shrimp - all very good and on par with San Tung

Hand pulled Noodles with black bean sauce and spicy dan dan noodles reminds me of San Tung.  Large portion and decent price.

Service/Ambience - Small restaurant with 20-30 seats.  Service can be slow when it's a full house.  

Before this place opened, I use to go to the Shanghai Dumpling King.  Now I prefer this place because it is less crowded, cleaner, and has really good chicken wings.
author: Cin T.

description:
Go here for the entrees, though the dumplings are better a couple blocks up.

So if I'm feeling like Shanghai dishes and not just dumplings, this is the place!

Must order:
Hand-cut noodles, great flavor, textures, veggies...YUM
Green onion pancake, can never go wrong with this
Sting beans, get your fresh veggie fill

I usually stick to the tried and true, but there are plenty of dishes I'm looking forward to trying like the chicken wings!

Don't be in a hurry because there is ALWAYS only one waitress and she's not the quickest or friendliest, just a head up =)
author: Angel L.

description:
Have you ever eaten so much Chinese food that you wonder if Chinese people ever say to themselves, "Man, Chinese food AGAIN?" Well recently I had the pleasure of eating with Ed M. and let me tell you, the answer is no. That dude loooves Chinese food. 

Shanghai house is in a tiny, somewhat sterile place in the hot spot of the Outer Richmond. If you consider the two block strip of Balboa that is home to just about every kind of  Asian cuisine and the Balboa Theater a hot spot. Actually, I think the only reason he chose this place was because he knew I had a car and that I LOVE to drive...'cause this place is in the sticks.

We got there and I just let him order. I figured he knew what the deal was AND he could speak Chinese. Very impressive. It was like a date except he didn't pull my chair out for me when I sat...that's why he only got to second base. Oh, and the wife and kid were there. COCK BLOCKERS! The food was really nice and as I am unfamiliar with Shanghai cuisine I found it was a nice departure from typical fried, greasy, heavy sauced Chinese food. Although there's a time and place for that shit too sometimes. The green onion pancakes were delicious and the hand cut noodles were a treat.

The main reason I'd come back is for the Shanghai dumplings. Their skin was light with a flavorful filling and were SUPER juicy. It was like there was a party in my mouth and everybody was coming. What? Why are you snickering? Oh, grow up, you guys. Really.

So basically, get yourself a Chinese friend who loves to eat and preferably speaks the language, let him roll you out to one his favorite spots and come hungry. And seriously, grow up.
author: Josua P.

description:
This is my first one-star review... In an effort to maintain credibility I'm going to use the old tried and true Zagat framework to organize my thinking and response.

Decor:  When I first walked in I got a really weird feeling - the restaurant is a small, rectangular, beige-colored room with no decoration whatsoever.  Furthermore, there was no music on and oddly hushed conversation.  I felt like I had made a big mistake by even walking through the door.  Once we'd been seated the front door kept opening ON ITS OWN and letting the cold richmond air blow across my neck.  Not fun.


Food:  Started with a hot and sour soup - this was just plain bad.  I've had unremarkable H&S before but this was outright awful.  Extremely sour with no hot... lack of flavor, odd vegetables, disjointed, and simply wrong.  I had about 3 spoonfuls before putting it aside.  Zha Do Fu - Fried tofu appetizer - this was OK - I mean.. what could go wrong.  Tasted like decently good store-bought tofu that had been fried.  Accompanying sauce was uninteresting.  The main event: xiao long bao - these were only OK - too sweet and the skin was dry and a little crumbly - I've had better.  Main dish: Tofu Noodles with Edamame - this tasted like nothing - funky-ass texture, disgusting presentation, and no flavor.  Epic failure.

Service:  slow, inattentive, and had to be asked for everything.  They even forgot to serve the vinegar with the dumplings.  I raised a hand to ask one of the workers there for it, she saw me, and simply walked back into the kitchen.  How's that for service?

In summary, don't go here.
author: Austin L.

description:
You must try the vegan goose and Shanghai dumpling. They are very good. I had dried more than dozen different places. Their vegan goose is outstanding. Considering the fact I am heavy meat eater!!! 

They have some other exotic ( to most people) dishes you should try if you dare...tea smoked fish (semi jerky like dish...not sure if you were to eat the bones) 

Drunken chicken was also good. 

More to come when I try out the other dishes.
author: S.K. Y.

description:
My friends and I have these looooong drawn out Gmail threads and while I am usually okay with it (I love to read and I love getting emails), sometimes the aggro New Yorker in me rears her ugly, dirty, impatient mouth and I am forced to lay down the law. 

Such was the case when we were recently planning on taking in a movie at the Balboa and I wanted dumplings and had no interest in taking everyone else's needs into accord. So, I DEMANDED that we go to Shanghai House. At the end of the day, I kind of ended up winning, since I am fairly certain I am the only one who enjoyed the meal here. 

I thought the dumplings were just okay (prefer Dumpling King, to be honest but wtf do I know?) but the Pan Fried Hand Cut Noodles RULED.  So much, that I once again took charge and just took the entire order for myself. If you like more Americanized stuff, they have it, but I think the more traditional stuff was the clear winner. Be sure to ask for the "other" menu if all you see is your usual delivery favorites.
author: Maria D.

description:
Let me try to describe this restaurant to you.  If the contestants on Top Chef have to open a makeshift restaurant in 24hrs.............this is how it would look like.  They have roughly 10 tables, no ventilation system, no paintings on the wall, Their maximum capacity is probably 26.  There's only one lady that takes the order and one assistant.  You ever go to a restaurant and feel like it is going to be a great restaurant but the service is going to be really bad?  Bingo.............this is it!!! This is what we had. 

Fried tofu with vermicelli and pork soup
very salty and was not that good

shanghai gnen goh
very doughy and was probably the worst dish.  I was getting very disappointed.

Fatty Pork
was very lean..........fatty pork that is lean? hahahah  It was very good

2 orders of shanghai dumplings
was decent........I've had better........but things are starting to look up

Pot stickers
taste like the shanghai dumplings but fried on the bottom with a different skin.  The pot stickers are gyoza size.  Very unique to see something like this.  I was very happy with this order.  It's getting better.


maun tao
deep fried bread with condense milk.  This is bad ass.  Great way to end the meal.
author: jason g.

description:
shanghai house kicks shanghai dumpling king's ASS straight across the pacific ocean back to the motherland.

my friend and i ordered the following:

XLB (10 dumplings to a steamer)
cucumbers with bean thread salad
sweet and sour spareribs (tang cu pai gu)
knife cut stir-fried noodles with pork and vegetables

...yes, we were extremely hungry.

the trek to the outer richmond and the 15 minute wait was well worth it.  even though the restaurant is tiny--there couldn't have been more than 13 tables--it is extremely bright and clean with only the mouth-watering aromas of shanghainese dishes wafting through the dining room. every table had a steamer full of dumplings, and some had clay pot rice, lion's head meatballs or cold plates of stewed meats.

first, the XLB's were tender and had some nice soup when i bit into them. the skin was thin and had good mouth feel. at times, the skin would be rolled and formed a little too thick at the top, but it's a good indication that they're rolling their own dough. 

the knife cut noodles were great, with the handmade noodle texture perfected. 

the best part of our meal though was the sweet and sour spareribs. they use small riblets cut into small bite-sized pieces, and the sweet and sour sauce is as thick and dark as raw molasses. the brown gooey goodness would have gone perfectly with plain rice, but my dining companion and i had a grand ol' time gnawing on the bone and sucking the sauce dry.

simply delicious, well-made shanghainese cafe food at very decent prices. our meal came out about $14 each person.

cash only.
personable and warm service.
BYOB.

oh, and we ran into fellow yelper art o. as he was getting take out dumplings. hi art!
author: May T.

description:
Disappointing for ppl looking for Shanghai cuisine. The line was too long at Shanghai Dumpling House so I walked down 3 blocks to try this one. 

Place is clean, small and not crowded on Saturday night. I ordered 3 classics: XLB, bean curd puff and Shanghai thick fried noodle. XLB is 90% certain frozen ones from the supermarket. Pick one up and it stays in the same shape as opposed to been elongated by the soup inside. A measure of good XLB: you know not to put a whole one in your mouth. No worry here. 3 out of 10 had no soup and the rest had just warm soup. Bean curd puff was frozen and microwaved. Funny thing is I actually prefer it room temp so I tried to mix them. But they are too soggy anyway. The noodle has too much soy and had cabbage so the flavor and texture are completely off. 

Since I was alone, I didn't get the more expensive dishes. But the tables of Asian frat boys and the Cantonese family seemed perfectly happy. So who knows.
author: W C.

description:
Best Soup Dumplings Ever!

  It seems there are two schools of thought here. The people who like the thinner wrapping and those who like it thicker. I'm a member of the former rather than the latter and Shanghai House is perfection. My friend and I ordered one steamer of dumplings and Dan Dan Noodles. After tasting  the dumplings we realized we should have ordered more and skipped the noodles. My biggest problem with soup dumplings is the temp of the soup inside. If the wrapper is too thin, then the soup is too hot and it burns my mouth. No worries here as the soup was the perfect temperature. This is a no frills spot but if you love soup dumplings it worth the trip to BFE.  This is a great spot to come with friends, sip some tea and eat some yummy dumplings.
author: chelsea b.

description: Pretty tasty.  A bit slow.
author: Michael E.

description: I came here on default when Shanghai Dumpling King down the street was closed. Again, I got the xioa long bao and the drunken chicken. I also got the veggie dumplings and the bean paste desert. The xiao long bao were great and I ordered a second basket. They too were devoured instantly. The drunken chicken was definitely drunk. I will come here again, for sure. The sacues here were good, but I am still wanting both this place and Shanghai Dumpling King to spice things up with a bit more hua jiao sauce.
author: Brian J.

description:
This place gets 3 stars because my experiences vary from visit to visit. The first time I came here, I had a great experience just because their onion pancake was better than shanghai dumpling king up a couple blocks. 

From the reviews I've read, I decided I wanted to try tan tan noodles and dry fried chicken wings. The tan tan noodles reminded me of the cold noodles from San Tung except they weren't peanut buttery. The noodles were really oily and I regret ordering them. The chicken wings were delicious and way better than the ones San Tung served. However, when I ordered them again on a second visit, the chicken was bland and tasteless, so if you ever order it, cross your fingers that they marinated it right. 

The only items I would recommend would be the onion pancakes and maybe the pork and veggie steam dumplings.
author: Connie C.

description:
Bring your goggles because one bite into their juicy XLB may shoot a stream of steam hot pork broth into a fellow diner's eye causing permanent blindness.  After dodging streams of broth, please be sure to also use proper protocol when eating XLB to prevent burns to the roof of your mouth, they are as follow:

1. Use both chopsticks AND soup spoon to transport from the steam basket.
2. Slightly nibble and puncture the skin
3. Slurp and suck the broth, like Edward on Bella.
4. Drizzle the vinegar ginger sauce onto dumpling.
5. Eat

My method of choice is to wait 5 minutes and place entire dumpling into the mouth broth and all.  

We also order the Dry Fried Spicy chicken wings (7.95).  They were delicious wings.  Each wing is encased in an extra crispy batter protecting the tender and succulent meat from the perfect blend of a sweet sticky sauce of garlic and peppers punctuated by fried basil.   A must order when visiting Shanghai House   

Conclusion- Shanghi house is small but clean Chinese restaurant in the outskirts of the Richmond. I prefer the XLB (5.50) here over Dumpling King a few blocks down and gladly pay the extra 25 cents.   Solid and reasonably price food make this spot a good choice for Sunday brunch; a welcome change from pancakes and eggs.
author: Jordan T.

description: Good and greasy authentic chow that comes with fair amount of sour attitude. Potstickers are amazing and on that alone they get three stars...
author: David H.

description:
Soup dumplings here are whack.  Very little juice and when I do get a wet one (a drop's worth), it aint even flavorful!  Did they put chips of ice in here and think it'd amount to some soupy pork goodness?  Fail.

Wrapping was gummy and dry.  Dry from not having that broth!  Not to mention that I've seen bigger marbles than those dudlings.

Dry fried chicken wangs... the heck?  Tastes like a caramel apple!  Meaning it has a hard candy shell around it smothered with burnt pieces of chili, so I'm burning my tongue off and getting a cavity at the same time.  Damnit!

Ok, their hand cut (add $0.50) noodles are pretty unique though.  Basically shaving a huge brick of dough to create strips of noodles.  Velvety and slurpable... broth not so terrible either!

Redeeming plate -- The Vegetarian Duck.  Basically some fried soy bean strips stuffed with shitaake mushrooms in some OoOOoo-wheee sauce!  And it kinda does look like strips of peking duck.

Service was odd.  Kinda crazy when the dish washer comes out and serves up your plate.  Very hygenic for not using your bare hands, but hey is that some soap scum on your gloves?
author: Chris T.

description:
Gyeah, take me back here!  I'm not a shanghai dumpling aficionado but these dumplings are pretty damn good to me.  Also, you must order the fried chicken wings - almost as good as San Tung's.  The tan tan mein is good, spicy than other places I've had it.  Their potstickers and green onion pancake are average.  The rice cakes are pretty good and taste homemade.   

The two times I've been here I haven't had to wait for a table.  So if you want your San Tung of the Richmond - come here.  The service isn't 5 stars but the food makes up for it.
author: Meredith K.

description:
Old classmates/friends gathering of four.  This was few months back and really the things we ordered did not really stood out.  Some dishes along the lines of a Shanghai rice cake, potstickers, xiao long bao, veggie dish, sweet buns for dessert.

I do remember that the service was ok, food was cheap, we were so damn stuffed.
author: Vanna S.

description: Whenever I come to sfo, I want to eat here.  Yummm
author: S S.

description:
Shanghai house gets a good review for one major reason: they offer a decent Chinese meal for one person.  All too often, a single person going out for Chinese is stuck getting one big heaping serving of orange chicken or some similar dish that is best had with a big group, not all by one's lonesome.  Here, however, there is a 'Meal for One' option that includes soup, and egg roll, rice or chow mien, and an entree.

The food is really good, the service was fast and friendly, and the prices were very reasonable.

Overall, quite tasty.
author: Eric M.

description:
The rating is based mainy on their vegetarian goose, a fried outer layer of bean curd with mushroom filling, which was cheap, tasty, and filling.  Everything else was up to par, like their fried rice and my friend's beef and noodle concoction.  

The bargain prices and aloof waitress might have you think you're dining at "just another Chinese joint", but the food is a notch above.  It's deep in the Richmond, but I wouldn't hesitate to return.
author: Marsha Z.

description:
I tried the XLB from Shanghai Dumpling King and Shanghai House on the same day.  Shanghai House has the edge.  perfect size, rich juice, more flavorful contents and just the right wrapper, steamed to perfection. SDK has more dumpling variety including crab dumplings, but their wrapper is a little thinner and contents a little less flavorful.
Of course, this all goes out the window, compared to DTF.

I agree though that you have to choose the right things from the menu to appreciate this place.  focus on the shanghainese stuff, like the savory soy milk and the sesame dessert in rice wine
the dry fried chicken wings are good too
the place itself is tiny with no room to wait (also, how often do you walk through the kitchen to get to the upstairs bathroom?)
interior stark but clean
author: Rob C.

description:
Great food in SF is everywhere. But great food with easy parking and light on the wallet is a hard find. This place beats that notorious place on Irving. I gladly sacrifice minor hype for immediate seating, unlike that other place... on Irving hmm hmm , where I have always waited 45 min plus for seating. 

This place is pretty good. Authentic Shanghai Cuisine. Offers all the originals you'll find at other places. The chickens wings are damn good, it has that special sauce. Shanghai Dumpling is $4-$5 bucks!!!! beat that you other places. The noodles are very good. Had the pork shoulder and egg write scramble. Shanghainese has another name for it. 

All in all it's good for the soul and wallet.
author: Phillip K.

description:
Yum!  I've let my friend who is familiar with real Shanghai and other Chinese cooking take me to the best Shanghai spots on Balboa, and I really liked this one.  

We just let her order whatever's good.  We had dumplings, spicy beef tendon, a rice cake dish, and a satay soupy/stewy clay pot.  

We had baby dumplings, which were yummy and came with the soy/vinegary sauce.  One dish of 10 dumplings was enough to split among the three of us.  These Shanghai dumplings were comparable to those from other Balboa Shanghai spots.  She always shows us the proper way of eating different dishes.  These dumplings are soupy inside.  You place it in your wonton spoon, pour some sauce over it, and use your chopstick to hold it down, while biting into it.  The broth might spill out into your spoon, and you continue eating.  Yummy!!!

They allowed us to choose the degree of spiciness of the spicy dishes, so that was good because two of us can't handle very spicy food.  The tendon was good, if you've never had it, it's good to try -- it comes cold and served in an oily sauce; it comes with beef and tendon pieces.  I LOVE rice cakes, so the rice cake dish was my favorite besides the dumplings.  It comes with noodles.  The satay clay pot was good...it had meat, mushrooms, and vermicelli.  


The restaurant didn't seem that small to me, and we didn't have to wait at all to get a table.  
The two reasons I didn't give it a 5 is because of the service and the ambiance.  We were waiting for a refill for our tea, and finally, my friend had to get up and ask.  And they don't reallly check up on you...but most spots like this are like that.  They weren't so big a deal, but that is just why it didn't get a 100%!  Also FYI!, this place is cash only.

The price was very decent...for all that food for 3 of us, it was only $10 each!!!
author: Liz C.

description: My wife and I tried this restaurant for the first time on Sat. 06/14/14:  Their deep fried chicken wings are not as good as the other well-known Chinese restaurant.  The chicken tasted bland.  We also ordered friend bananas and they were so-so.  Besides the wait was a bit long:  about 20 minutes!  We won't be going back!
author: Paulus S.

description:
My friends and I came here. We waited 20 minutes at the host stand and no one even approached us. The place was not busy.

Also, it smells like a rancid fart.
author: Don H.

description: Terrible customer service! Overpriced bland tasting food. Long wait time, no wait list system, people stand around waiting and they give the tables to people in incorrect order. We had 7 people in our party and they refused to join two tables together to accomodate us. The old lady was very rude and ignored us. We waited at least 45 minutes to an hour to be seated then another half an hour for the food. Everything tasted average at best. Definitely not worth the wait and would not recommend this place.  Go to Shanghai Dumpling King instead.
author: Mike W.

description: very over priced....goo tr what you get.. super salty... service is straight from fobs who just don't care.. which means it's non existent.
author: One L.

description:
It's 3.5 stars but the cleanliness really pushes it up to 4 stars. 

Since its a Shanghai restaurant I ordered two simple dishes. 

1.) Xiao Lung Bao (Small Steamed Dumpling)
2.) Postickers

Xiao Lung Bao is very very delicate, a good Xiao Lung Bao is defined by its uber-thin skin, juicy meat inside, and just the right amount of weight to be picked up by chopsticks without juices flowing everywhere. 

Shanghai House's version is good but not perfect.  The skin is a little thick, not unbearable but a bit thick.  Juices a little thin and the bottom sticks a little bit.  What's important though this restaurant produces a very good authentic version of Xiao Lung Bao.  It's not perfect but very very good. 

I also ordered potstickers.  Potstickers is one of those dishes that's so common it's hard to imagine anything out of the ordinary.  If you think  potstickers are all made the same, I highly recommend trying Shanghai House's potstickers.   The filling is nice and juicy, the bottom is crispy, it's a delight to eat, I throughly enjoyed mine. 

They also have Chinese breakfast including Sweet and Salty rice balls, soy milk, fried dough etc.  I'm gonna try to head back on the weekends to try out their breakfast.
author: matt c.

description:
This place reminds me of real, authentic Shanghainese food.  Living in San Francisco, all I have are Cantonese flavored Chinese food.  Any variety is fine with me and a welcomed one at that!

I am biased though, being Shanghainese I know what comfort food is...the dumplings, crispy tofu stuffed with mushroom, the hands pulled noodles....I am drooling as we speak.

Go check out the Shanghai House, formerly known as Old Shanghai on Judah and 9th.  Love the boss lady, super sweet and walking in their doors just feels like home...

Enjoy!
author: Alice H.

description:
Im not sure when Shanghai House opened, but when I went there 2 weeks ago everything was super clean as if it were all brand new. Restaurant is pretty small and superly QUIET. The 4 of us ordered a bunch of food including XLB (has juice inside!), green onion pancakes, soy milk w/ chinese donut, a few cold dishes and a few other dishes that I dont quite remember. Anyway, the food here was pretty good and the service was excellent. I shall be back.

note* 100pts on score card
author: M W.

description:
My friends who used to live in the city were in town yet they had never experienced the joy of San Tung's chicken wings. PURE BLASPHEMY. So we head on over and grab a great parking spot. But something is amiss...

Me: Wait, where are the people? Where are the lights? WHERE ARE THE CHICKEN WINGS?!

There's a sign that says they'll be closed until April 6th. 

OH GOD, WHY HAVE YOU FORSAKEN ME!!

After I calm down, we head on over to their sister restaurant, So, because I'm a man on a mission. But they're closed too. 

OH GOD, WHY ARE YOU PUNISHING ME!!!

Desperate and hungry, we cross over the Golden Gate Park and even farther out into the avenues. I decide that we should go to Shanghai House because it's new, they had great xiao long bao the last time I was there with Ed M, and there wouldn't be a wait. 

We're seated and I realize that I don't recognize anything on the menu. Hunan prawns? Garlic eggplant? Where's the hand cut pan fried noodles? WHERE'S MY CHINESE FOOD?!

Shanghai House has two different menus. Me and Mikey the Whitey got the white man menus while Ed (not M) and Kathleen got the menus with the good stuff. Goddamnit. 

But oh wait, what's this on the white man menu? Dry fried chicken wings? OH SWEET SWEET IRONY. 

I order the dry fried chicken wings and they're DELICIOUS. Crispy and golden sweet on the outside, juicy on the inside. Kathleen even made the bold statement that these might be better than San Tung's chicken wings. I'm still on the fence about it but they were oh so good. 

Excellent xiao long bao and dry fried chicken wings without the wait? Oh, I might be in love.
author: Patrick L.

description:
Point A: creepy bathroom located in an attic-like room. Stairs leading to it contains no source of light. Felt like some guy was going to jump up and scare my friend and me. If it was just me going to that bathroom, it would've been the fastest trip of my life. 

Point B: super, super crowded. Kept bumping into the waitresses and other diner-ees. And the place was really small. 

Point C: accepts only cash, so make sure you bring enough money.  

BUT, there are good news 'cause otherwise, the place would've received 2 stars. The food was yummy, especially the Shanghai noodles. I have super high expectations for them because I've eaten them at various places, but these noodles satisfied me. And the dumplings were great as well. 

Come here if you're not claustrophobic and don't mind enjoying a great Shanghai meal with people at every corner.
author: Steph W.

description:
I went here with my boyfriend a couple of weekends ago to try out the XLBs... normally we eat at Shanghai Dumpling King but we thought we'd try this place out. BIG MISTAKE!!! Seriously the service is so SLOOOOOW its unbelievable that they are still in business. 

We ordered 3 dishes and it took over an hour for the dishes to come! It seems that they were highly unorganized and didnt know what table ordered what dish.  A large party of 8 arrived 20 min AFTER my bf and I ordered and they promptly recieved all of their food! WTF!  Bad service!

I WILL NEVER GO BACK HERE becuase I value my time too much and the food wasnt all that. I'd rather eat SDK.
author: Julie F.

description:
Food highlights:

-Green onion pancake
-Dry fried chicken wings (you can get them not spicy)
-XLB

We also tried the beef brisket noodle soup but it was just okay. Taiwanese style is so much better. The chicken wings were special; I've never had anything like it! It's got like this honey glaze with cilantro, sesame oil/seeds, fried to perfection. I loved every bite! So bad for you but definitely worth a try.

The restaurant is small so expect a little wait if you're coming during peak hours on the weekend. It's clean inside and the staff is as friendly as it gets for an Asian place if you know what I mean. They're all busy so understandable that they are abrupt when taking your order.

Prices are pretty good. In the end, I would still choose Shanghai Dumpling King over Shanghai House any day. Sorry, but the food is just better there. Period.
author: Yee-Shing W.

description:
At Shanghai House, you get a good meal at a good price.  And it's in a clean restaurant with a clean bathroom, which isn't always true in this part of town.

But first, something to remember before you get there: CASH ONLY.  Fortunately, there is a BoA about four doors down the street, but it's better not to have to run out at the end of the meal to get some cash.

Another thing to know is that there are TWO MENUS.  They may bring you both menus, but you have to look closely because they look almost the same.  If you only have the gringo menu (no jellyfish in the appetizer section is a sure indicator of the gringo menu), ask for the other menu.  And you can call it The Other Menu, this is well understood.

Now why do you want The Other Menu unless you like jellyfish and pig's feet? (I like both, but that's not the point here.)  Maybe because you LIKE FISH.  There's no fish on The Gringo Menu, only on The Other Menu.  And the fried pompano with spicy sauce, is fish worth having.  If you're not used to cooked whole fish, it might be frustrating at first, but it's worth the effort.  My only complaint is that the fish is a bit small.  Afterwards, you have this beautiful fish skeleton with a head and tail, I wish I had brought my camera.

There are other fish dishes and a lot of other dishes on The Other Menu, but I forgot to bring all my relatives so we could try them.  I can only report that, in addition to the excellent pompano, the vegetarian goose tastes nothing like goose, and looks even less like goose, but is very tasty, the sesame chicken is one of the best sweet fried preparations of anything I've had, the spareribs are good in a sauce that might be a little bit too rich, and the house special eggplant is excellent.

The food is incredibly hot when it comes to the table, it's only about forty steps from the wok to the table and the kitchen doesn't have any real staging area (you see it when you go the bathroom), so let it sit before you burn your mouth.  The tea is good and the fortune cookies are fortune cookies.
author: Spike S.

description:
2 1/2 stars. i came here many years ago when it first opened...now i remember why i never came back until now. the hubby wanted to try this place and from the reviews seems like it got better.

service is slow. only one person working, but place is small.

the dumplings weren't bad, but the skin was a lil hard on top

the green onion pancake-needed to be more cripsy

the chinese donut-wasn't bad at all and wasn't super oily which i liked

the sticky rice noodle-super bland and the veges that came with it didn't even match. has these yellow crunchy things that were sour

the claypot rice with salted pork and veges-super bland too. i had to put lots of soy sauce and the salted pork they only gave 2 pieces. the rest of it was so finely chopped up that u can barly see it or taste it.

super disappointing. will never ever come back.
author: Karen H.

description:
This place is rated $ sign on yelp. Our bill came out to be $55 for 3 dishes and a chinese donut, you be the judge.

This place is located in a very quiet and quaint part of the city. It has about 8 tables and seats approximately 25-30 people. The food here is pretty good. The soup dumpling is a must if you have never had it before. There are some elements of  "Chinese American" in their food but no gripe here.

Shanghai House's noise decibel is not typical of a chinese restaurant. You don't have to yell to communicate with your party
author: Tony N.

description:
This is the best shanghainese food in SF. Really, the xiao long bao (little dumplings) are the best this side of the pacific. Also make sure to try anything "dry fried," sure its not 100% authentic but its very tasty. 
If you care about great tasting food for not much $ this is the place to be. Oh and to those complaining about the service, take a shanghaiese speaker w you, they'll love you for the introduction and your party will get faster service.
author: yang t.

description: I had the rice cake, shanghai dumplings and savory rice roll. Definitely try their dumplings and the rice rolls! The rice cake was just very greasy and lacking flavor.
author: Shirley W.

description:
Shanghai House is my new favorite Chinese restaurant in San Francisco!

This is what I order with my girlfriend all the time here:
-Shanghai Dumplings (so very wet and juicy and good)
-Potstickers (also very juicy and good... makes me forget about AJ's open ended wrapped potstickers)
-Hand Cut Noodles (oh man soooo good it makes me cry)
-Savory rice wrapped hand roll with chinese donut (I don't know what it is called exactly because I always order this in mandarin... but it is a fried chinese donut wrapped with pork sung and rice.)
-Savory or Sweet Soy Milk!  They offer cold or hot for sweet soy milk!

This place can accomodate more than 6 people parties, but VERY hard.  So the perfect amount for this place is either 2-4 people.  The place also get get very packed so prepare to wait... but sometimes if you cannot wait there is a nice japanese restaurant called Miki right next door that is also just as awesome.

Parking is semi-tough... this place is right across one of the few independant theaters and boy do alot of people still go there.  Balboa theater probably is the main reason why all the parking is taken... #2 reason would be maybe Zephyr's Cafe.  I sometimes park a block up on Anza because of how packed it can get.

The only negative I can say about this place is the service.  As nice as the lady is to us now that we are here so often.. it still isn't the best service out there in a Chinese restaurant.  Suck it up and ignore the staff and enjoy one of San Francisco's best chinese spots!  This place is truely a hidden hole in the wall!

WARNING: This review is based on not trying the other dumpling place 2 - 3 blocks away also on Balboa.
author: Benny S.

description:
The food was okay, some of the dishes were better than others.  We had a lot of people so we had the opportunity to try quite a bit.

* Xiaolong bao - The skin was okay, there was juice, not bad, but not 100%
* Vegetarian goose - Perfectly crisp and great flavor!  
* Tea soaked duck - It was not bad, it had a smoked flavor. It only comes with 4 buns, they looked softer than it tasted. Order more if you have more than 4 people
* Green Onion Pancakes- Just pass, it is very doughy, not flaky and crispy
* Shanghai Noodles - Was saucy, i believe it is supposed to be cooked dryer. the noodles were not good at all, very disappointing.
* Tan Tan Mein - it was good, not bad. much better than the Shanghai Noodles
* Pig's knuckle - you must pre-order from my understanding. We had the crispy one, it was fatty and good!
* Stewed pork with preserved vegetable - Okay, not sure if this is really the name, but it is a stewed pork with sweet preserved vegetables, this was good too! 

The service could of been better, the lady (waitress) wasn't really nice. place is small, so reservations are recommended with big groups. They did take our group of 10. 
last but not least, BYOB! =)
author: Eva L.

description:
Why anyone would rate this great little place less than 4 stars is a mystery to me--perhaps they ordered the wrong things or maybe they came from outside this neighborhood...Yes I guess if I bussed, biked or drove over here from the Mission, I would probably not give it 5 stars, but this yummy, inexpensive restaurant is in MY neighborhood where good restaurants are far outnumbered by really, really dismal ones. 

My first favorite restaurant in this stretch has always been Miki's right next door...but now I have TWO new favorites on Balboa. Yu Zen and Shanghai House. 

What did I eat there that made me this excited? Well, the first thing I tried, I ate four or five times before I moved on to anything else and that was the Kung Pao chicken. I tried only that partly because I liked it so much, partly because I got it at least 4 times to go--you can't order from the "Shanghai" menu on take out orders--and partly because if you order two orders + rice for two you can feed 4 people (take out) for $20! And that's eating really stand-out Kung Pao--smoky peppers and smoked tofu, lots of veggies (mostly zucchini but it's good here) and tasty chicken. Just right. 

My interest in Chinese Food in my neighborhood (exception of all exceptions: Ton Kiang for brunch) has seriously waned ~ it seemed every time I went for Chinese the last  few years I ate something that was too greasy, too sweet or just not memorable. 

Talk about memorable! the Shanghai style Vegetable Soup with hand cut noodles I had here last weekend has been stuck in my savory, sensory memory ever since and I just can't shake it. Out of all three dishes I ate that meal (my friend and I were hungry and determined to sample more of the menu) the said soup was actually the least "exciting" dish,  but for some reason it's the one that won out as top memorable sense that I can still "taste". I was actually most "excited" about the Bok Choy with Wheat Gluten Dumplings. This was amazingly good and yummy with a delicious sauce soaking the dumplings and the perfectly sized baby bok choy (you don't have to make a slippery slimy fool of yourself with these as you do with typically sized bok choy). Plus I am a sucker for really yummy "meat alternatives". 

And then to show that I am also a sucker for some meats, I also highly recommend the Tea Smoked Duck. It's so delicious! and for someone like me who doesn't eat meat other than poultry or fish, Duck prepared like this is as tasty and decadent as any pork dish might be (read: fatty and delicious and crispy).

So yes, you should try this place. But make sure you look at the Shanghai Menu. it's a mysterious practice they have of only giving it to you with the other menu (straight american chinese food?)--so some people may never even see it (esp. if you order take out)

update: since this review I've tried a few other notable dishes: the Vegetarian Goose (with shitake mushrooms) is delicious as are the Vegetarian Steamed Dumplings. The Mu Shu Vegetables were just right, too. The Vegetable Soup with hand-cut noodles wasn't as exciting as the first time I had it, but that happens sometimes ; ) Obviously plenty for a vegetarian to eat, although I'm not vegetairian. 

update #2: Now that I eat all meat, I can rate the Shanghai pork dumplings too--more delicate and nicer than the (notorious) ones up the street. And the Golden Prawns are my new favorite dish! Yum Yum

update #3: for some reason, after all of these years, I had never ordered the chicken wings until sometime the end of this last year. Oh my! Now it's the new 'must have' --hot, spicy, sweet, crunchy--it's a meal and dessert all at once. Leftovers that we have been known to fight over the next day ("hey you took two pieces!") Chicken crack.
author: Liza B.

description:
I agree with T D. that the XLBs (Shanghai steamed dumplings, Shanghai soup dumplings, Little Dragon Buns, etc.) here are the closest I've found to those at the legendary Taiwanese chain Din Tai Fung.  Be sure to eat them with a soup spoon!

Props also to the hand-cut noodles, as other reviewers have described.  I would pass on the regular boiled pork and vegetable dumplings as well as the braised meatballs (lion's head).  The former were nothing special while the latter came in too watery of a sauce.

Sterile is the best way to describe the dining room, but that's not necessarily a bad adjective when it comes to Chinese restaurants.
author: Eating Sleeping T.

description:
What is the deal with this place?  It's been buzzin amongst the Asian community for the past few months and hyped as THE premiere Shanghai restaurant in the city. All I have to say is you're going to be severely disappointed.

Today was my third visit to this place and as I sat there, I kept on wondering why I continue to come back. I think it's because I really do want to like this place, but they keep on coming up short. I'm a huge fan of Shanghai cuisine and have been looking  for a replacement for my fave Shanghai Restaurant, which closed down at Ranch 99 a few months ago.

My gripes. Someone needs to tell the chef to ease up on the flames.  All the noodle, rice cake, and chow fun orders I sampled were overcooked and mushy; all I tasted was dough. The portions are also  ridiculously small. Their potstickers are the equivalent size of Mcdonald's chicken nuggets. No joke. The bulk of their food is pretty bland, and I found myself dousing quite a bit of soy sauce for more flavor. Perhaps my biggest gripe has to be the owner/server there. It's an old woman with this look on her face that makes you think she's going to kill someone. Ok maybe a little harsh, but she seriously NEVER smiles. Not even the slightest grin. Ever. Go see for yourselves and tell me if I'm lying.

I'd say the only thing this place got going on for them is their Shanghai steam dumplings, or xiao long bao. Although a little on the small side, they're probably one of the best I've ever tasted. Immaculate skin texture and cooked to perfection. These lil suckers are probably the only reason I'll ever go back there and why they're getting 3 stars instead of 2.
author: jeff c.

description:
Good location in front of the theater, but definitely not as good as Shanghai Dumpling King. The chicken was also old, so it tasted not so great inside. The initial flavoring on the outside of the Santung wannabe wings was decent, but it didn't soak into the old "freezer burned" chicken. The wonton soup was also bland with no flavor. I probably won't go back here unless it's the only thing open. They also forgot our rice, but I canceled it. 

The only reason why I'm giving this place a 2 star is because the service was ok and the xiao long baos had a lot of soup in it, although they were small. 

Please note to all the people who use the 7x7 list for reference on what to eat in the city...RESTAURANTS PAY TO BE ON THAT LIST...it's not because they are necessarily the best.

No credit cards here either.
author: Katherine F.

description: Service is slow? Be glad to even get service! We ended up sitting ourselves, had the servers look back at us numerous times, never received menus....flagged someone down to ask for menus, and he snags one off someone else's table and leaves. Too bad this wasn't a place we could even give a chance. Being SF, there are many great Chinese restaurants around...just gotta know the right places to go guys!
author: Erika C.

description: Long lines from being in SF 7x7. I was waiting across the street to try out Purple Kow when I saw people form lines outside. I walked over to see if I could place my name on a waiting list only to find that they don't operate by lists. You've got to physically be waiting in line - they also angered this man in front of me by serving takeout to the lady behind him before him. Hard to say because you have to serve takeout since she wasn't waiting for a table...but understand where he's coming from - they had a ton of miscommunication. She seated us (table of 2) in the inner most table over the table of 3 (angry man) which caused him to give me angry stares from outside the window. Then he was seated next to us. Awkward. Either way, you're supposed to reserve the pig knuckle one day ahead but since this was a spontaneous dinner, we weren't able to try that. We ordered the XLB (didn't taste the meat - i think it's overrated for this), the knife cut noodle in wonton soup  (I was really impressed with how hot they kept the bowl of soup and the bowl itself - love my soup burning scalding hot!), and the ham bamboo beancurd casserole soup (also really good, wish there was more vegetable and bamboo) but the soup was really good. Overall, a good place - prob has other dishes that are amazing. Want to try the ribs, wings, noodles next time!
author: Jamie T.

description:
The Tea Smoked Duck with dumplings is really, REALLY good. I was close to saying the hell with family style, I got mines -- but I restrained myself just enough to make it look like I wasn't getting the lion's share. The skin was just a bit crisp and the meat was tender and perfectly done, with a subtle smoky flavor that combined really well with the dumplings' hint of sweetness.

I also liked the Green Onion Pancakes (light and moist) and the Mu Shu Pork (one person disagreed, saying they taste burnt, but I loved that the cabbage still had some crunch in it). Service was perfunctory at first but the woman running the floor warmed up as we went: I got a beautiful smile when I asked for a to go menu. She even folded it for me :-)
author: Karsten P.

description:
I've been here twice in the last few weeks. Both times with a part of around 8 people. Which meant we were just about half the patrons in the restaurant.

Good food. good prices.  Small restaurant.  Food came fairly promptly, even though the waitress seemed overworked.  And she was still friendly, too.  Maybe cuz we'd always be sure to have our Chinese speakers order and talk to the waitress.  Actually, that's probably it.

Four stars for worth coming back for good Chinese food.  Preferably with a Mandarin speaker, which I am, so any of you can feel free to take me out for lunch or dinner here.
author: Robert L.

description:
Today my family and I came here for lunch after my youngest sister's high school graduation. Lots of parking and there was a BOFA at the corner. There were about three handful of places to eat at in this neighborhood ten years ago. Since then, lots of new places have popped up.... Shanghai House being one of them. There is even a "People love us on Yelp!" sticker on the window.

This small establishment serves a variety of traditional Shanghai-ness dishes - from green onion pancakes, shao lung bao and dumplings to dun dahn mein and drunken chicken. All the ten plus dishes we had today were good, but nothing was spectacular and service was mediocre. The great thing about this place is that the food isn't overly greasy. My favorites from today were the green onion pancakes (very light and crispy) and drunken chicken (doused in alky... YUM!). 

Since this place is usually packed and there's quite the wait, I recommend coming here on a week night or Saturday lunch after 1pm.
author: Teresa Y.

description:
I would just give this five stars if it was only based on the food.  The service is simply lacking...sloooowwww.
That being said, the food is some of the best chinese I have had.  If you dine in be sure and ask for both menus.  They have one menu of standard chinese fare but done better than any place I have tried; kung pao chicken, twice cooked pork etc. And one menu of more esoteric dishes that they probably wont give you unless you are asian or if you ask for it.  The second menu has sizzling clay pot rice, pork belly, pork knuckle...
Be sure and check this place out
author: Vincent C.

description:
This place is not the Shanghi Dumpling King! It is however not too bad. I recommend it. Since I live in the hood I decided to check out the competition.  So right in the middle of ordering the Show-lum-bows BOOM 5.6 magnitude earthquake. The waitress, mindful of good customer service, drops her notepad, darts for the door and stares back through the glass.
Food is nothing spectacular but again I recommend it. 

who-nan beef
Melon soup (tang)
Fried pancake with green onion bit
show-lum-bows
author: William H.

description: Horrible service. Waited 25 minutes after ordering and the food still have not arrived. People who sat after us has been served their food. There are only 5 other tables that are present! I hope this is only a one time thing.
author: Tim M.

description:
Good Soup Dumplings, not sure if it should be on the "Top 100" things to eat before you die list.  

You get 10 fresh soup dumplings for around 5 bucks.  Not a bad deal.  

Some of the other food was so so.  

Overall, I'll try more of the food here and update my review.
author: Chase F.

description: Absolutely love this place.  Not been too exposed to shanghai food. We ordered dumplings (so delish!) chicken wings (crispy and flavorful) tofu ( though way too hot and spicy for me to eat slot, I love it!) string beans ( wow!). U definitely have to try it if you have not.
author: Rose O.

description: I ordered sesame chicken for a takeout. I was enjoying the food very much until I chewed on a meat that has a tiny but hard ROCK inside it.... It scratched one of my teeth really bad now I have to spend my money on a dentist cuz of this... I really can't imagine myself going back to this place cuz honestly I'm too scared to go back...
author: Chris L.

description:
I'm a fan of this place. It's like my second home to San Tung. Unfortunately, San Tung doesn't have the dumplings - xiao lung bao, so I gots to go here. 

Wings - tasty and sweet. I prefer San Tung, but when I need a fix and can't wait for those long lines this is a great back up. 
Dumplings - good all around. The best I've had in the city so far, but always on the look out for better. 
Rice cake stir-fry - good balance with the meat, veggies, and rice cakes. 

Just be aware that all the times I've been here I've only seen 3 people work. 2 in the front and 1 in the back - translation: they're slow. The food is good enough to endure. Go here, it's good!
author: Harvey C.

description:
The chicken wing here has always been the only thing I liked here. Not a big fan of the XLB  here. 

I hope the next time I come here, the food would taste better.
author: William C.

description:
I think Shanghai House is my new favorite place for xiao long bao! The bf and I had been hankering for xiao long bao for a while now, after being not-so-pleased by the ones we got at Taiwan Restaurant in Berkeley (oh my gosh... they were like the thick-skinned ones you can grab at dim-sum-to-go places!), we had been on the prowl for real xiao long bao, and this place came up.

So a few of our friends went last Friday night, happy to take up one of the last remaining tables of four. The lone waitress was kept pretty busy with the full house, but was still friendly and knowledgeable. Here's what we got:

Xiao Long Bao - A MUST EAT!! they're so tiny and precious, yet still delicious and juicy as they should be!
Green Onion Pancakes - pretty good, no complaints
Hand Cut Noodles - very interesting... cooked Shanghainese style with tons and tons of veggies
Little Sweet and Sour Ribs - just like I imagined... thick, dark, and sweet! I kind of wish the rib pieces were bigger tho... it takes a lot of chewing around bones to get to the meat!
Lion's Head Meatballs - wow, so good! the meatballs were really tender and tasty, with lots of veggies and huge mushrooms in a tasty sauce... great with rice!

One thing to note is that they do have two separate menus... one with the Shanghainese specialties and one with the standard Americanized "Chinese" fare, so be sure to look for the real deal. All in all, very happy with this discovery and will definitely come back!
author: Andrey C.

description:
Good example of REAL chinese food.

Simple ingredients that enhances the flavors.  Not greasy or "Sweet / Sour"
The Pork/Cabbage dumplings are good.  And of course, the dry fried chicken wings (I'm bias since I love this almost everywhere I go...AND you don't have to wait an hour for San Tung - a bit over rated)

Try the noodle soup, chicken wings and dumplings.  Just remember its a Shanghai restaurant...and don't expect the normal Chinese "style" Restaurant.
author: Eddie C.

description:
Came here on a Monday around 11:30am and the place was already full with one group of two waiting for a table before us.  There was only one waiter taking orders and one lady cleaning the table so everything from waiting for a table, ordering and getting the food took a while.  If you want to try this place be sure to have ample time waiting.  My boyfriend and I took approximately 30-45 minutes to eat only and we didn't get to leave until 2:30pm.  

As far as the food goes:

Dumplings (xiao lung baos) - Good..like the thin and soft skin to it. Not much soup  in the dumplings though.  Meat isn't as tasty as the ones in Old Shanghai restaraunt on Geary but overall I like it because of the thin skin.

Green onion pancake - A little too dry and hard but otherwise tastes the same as any other places I've tried.

Potstickers - Would like it if it was bigger in size.  Never seen potstickers this small before but they sure look cute! =P

Shanghai Stir Fry Noodles - Had better at Old Shanghai Restaurant on Geary.  This one didn't have enough flavors to it and the noodles are not as chewy as the ones on Geary.  

Place is clean and prices are rather cheap.  Maybe worth to wait for the dumplings only.
author: sidney c.

description:
I would give this place 4.5 stars if I could.  The food here is great, but the service can be very slow at times.  It's basically one woman taking care of the entire floor and sometimes her daughter.  Going at off times is ideal.  If you're going to order takeout, call ahead.  

They have a dish called dry fried fish.  It's like the San Tung dry fried chicken wings, but with more molasses taste over fried fish.  Quite tasty, my favorite dish there.  The XLB generally are very tasty, but I have gotten it on an off day once where they weren't nearly as juicy.  

Last I went they don't serve alcohol, but you're allowed to bring in your own.
author: Joann C.

description:
You will not be disappointed with the following I promise. Ive ordered these items a number of times and I believe them to be consistently flavorful and satisfying. 

"Soup"/ Shanghai Dumpling's when they arrive and eat carefully to experience the burst of broth. And you might as well get two orders since you waited so patiently.

String beans with garlic and chilies are always perfect.

Lions Head Meatballs in Gravy are nuts! Light fluffy and perfect over rice with the string beans.

Spicy Chive dumpling. The best way to get some spice  and the dumpling wrapper is different then the soup dumplings so its nice to explore the different kinds.


Green Onion cake- crisp and mild adds a lovely crunch to the experience.

I have to admit anytime the sweet  sugar coated puffy custardy fried balls come out I take a plate. They should be eatn upon arrival as well.
author: maxwell c.

description:
When you live on the Westside of L.A., scoring decent Chinese food requires a map, a tankful of gas, and a whole lot of patience. My sister and I once logged about 200 miles on three separate trips looking for a legendary (and apparently closed) noodle shop in the San Gabriel Valley. 

Luckily, I live in S.F. now, where even BFE is nothing compared to L.A. standards. So I celebrated by driving to Outer Richmond for some hand-cut noodles. 

Found Shanghai House through Yelp. I can back up the complaints about bad service. The food took forever (soup noodles are generally fast food) and the first time it came out, they got the order wrong (I asked for hand-cut noodles, and you should too). If you forget to specify hand-cut, they will bring you inferior noodles that taste like overcooked spaghetti. Since I did specify, I sent it back for the good stuff. 

Broth was not too greasy, noodles were nice and chewy, price was definitely right. Not mind-blowing, but definitely a solid option for noodle lovers. They will hand you two menus. You want the Shanghainese one (duh).
author: Katherine T.

description: We are regulars at Shanghai House. We love their rice cake noodles with pork. You can ask to remove cabbage from the dish because cabbage waters down the flavor. Their steamed Shanghai baby dumplings are the best in the city.  We always bring our out-of-town friends there and they were always wowed with their food.
author: Melody S.

description: This is for Soup Dumpling only (XLB to you west coast snobby  anti east coast  Soup Dumpling name peps).. well frankly the skins were tough, the filling was not too hot and the meat was fairly bland..sorry but these do not rate in the top of the pantheon of great Soup Dumplings..
author: Jason C.

description:
**UPDATE: 2nd Visit was much better.  Better food, better service.  Still just 3 stars

I wanted to like Shanghai House.  Another Shanghainese restaurant in Richmond?  The more the better!  But sadly, it still comes far behind Old Shanghai (the Best Chinese restaurant in SF).  But when you put Shanghai in your name, it only leads me to compare...even if it's unfair.

The Xiao Long Bao, the staple of any Shanghai restaurant scored a B.  Little juice inside, skins not delicate...as they should be.  They were a step up from frozen ones...and just average at best.  

The shredded noodle dish was oily, lacking much of any flavor.  Ordered it with shrimp...which apparently were not fresh shrimp but instead something all together.

We arrived late, around 9pm.  I know the wife is the waitress.  She was tired from a long day...but should we suffer?  She made us wait for 15 mins while she cleaned 2 other tables basically ignoring us.  She apologized and all was fine...but the food didn't make up for it.

I want more authentic, great chinese food...especially in the Sunset or Richmond...Shanghai House doesn't pass.
author: Sir Paul L.

description:
4 Stars because it was a clean and quaint restaurant AND the food tasted fresh and was NOT  greasy !!! Major pluses!!! 

Food was about 3.

We ordered:

Shanghai Dumplings- did an excellent job on the skin - very thin and and not so chewy or soggy. The inside (meat filling) was moist but not filled with juices as it should have.,  BUT this is still better than Shanghai Dumpling King a few blocks down....(Shanghai Dumpling King's food has really dropped dramatically in taste and quality over the years.... I don't understand why people still line up for that place... SDK is sooooo overrated).

Mongolian Beef -  was good because it was not drowning in oil like how most Chinese restaurant cook it.  It came with rice , but the rice was not fresh, maybe I just got the bottom of the rice cooker ... who knows, but let's not dwell on it.

Hand Cut Beef Noodle soup -. This is very very very good!! They did an excellent job cutting  the noodles in thin slices.. and was cooked perfectly... not too soggy and too chewy. The soup was light in flavor but not bland and not heavy with salt or MSG.  They also gave a good portion of this dish. I absolutely LOVE hand cut noodles and I have tried many many places....... this place does it right. It is also really hard to find a good place in SF that even serves this type of noodles. 

Service: Slow.....Well.... there is only  one waitress, and boy.... that is one pokered faced lady... If she was holding a 5 card dud  in her hand and her opponent is holding a Royal Flush... she'd make that person doubt, fold and she'd win!! She'd be THAT good!!!!!.I.. think the only time she cracked a smile was when my  toddlers saw  her coming to the table with food and the kids jaws drop because of the sight of food. That jaw dropping , gwaking face of my cutties... finally put a grin and a light chuckle to her. We took our time eating... and eventually made small talk with her, which was nice (yes, her face was still pokered when we talked) but we did have a nice conversation.

Over all, we will definitely be coming back here. Clean, quaint, and good food.

Note: They have 2 different Menus. One is their Shanghai Menu and the other lists all the Chinese generic dishes you find every where else. I say.... stick with the Shanghai Menu.

And for those of you wondering what our small talk was about..  here you go: the Master Chef is from Shanghai.. have been living in the states for 10 years... his wife (the pokered faced lady is the waitress).....they had owned another restaurant for 7 years prior to Shanghai House).... and on and on.... like I side it was a nice conversation.
author: Elle W.

description:
Great vegetarian duck!  We had read about it on the various newspaper clippings in the windows while waiting for the restaurant to open & it did not disappoint!  

One thing I want to try next time is the pork knuckle!  Sounds strange and needs to be ordered in advance, but I'm up for some adventurous eating...  (I'm not very fond of chicken feet and pork knuckle doesn't sound too far off, but I'm down to give it a try...)
author: Allan H.

description:
Deep fried fish filet (gan(1) pen(1) yu(2)) = ULTRA CRACK
Soup dumplings (xiao(3) long(2) bao(1)) = SHANGHAI DUMPLING KING MINUS THE GREASE AND MINUS THE MSG OVERDOSE
Homemade knife cut noodles (dao(1) xioa (1) mian(4)) = CRACK
Green onion pancakes (cong(1) you(2) bing(3)) = DECENT CRACK

Okay, it's not really crack, but better and purer. Coke ok?

Since they are just blocks apart, the cleanliness of Shanghai House over Shanghai Dumpling King makes this place my coke dealer of choice.
author: Cathy H.

description:
Shanghai House - weird experience

We ordered: 2 orders pot stickers (tiny bite size), Shanghai pan friend noodles, Shanghai sliced rice sticks, bean curd wrapped w/mushrooms, and shrimp fried rice.

Service was OK, waitress a bit cold.  Dragon lady type.  The Shanghai noodles & rice sticks (very salty).  The fried rice (sliced carrots, mushrooms,  & cabbage)  Is this Shanghai style?  Bizarre...

The pot stickers were tasty (TINY), the bean curd was very good.  CA$H only!  I prefer Shanghai Dumpling King best so far - need to try Old Shanghai next.
author: Rich W.

description: I come to this place quite often, I love how inexpensive the xiao long bao is, I love the shanghai dumplings. I also love their special chicken wings, but only if its not spicy. The tan tan noodle is quite spicy, so not quite for me. The only drawback is that it's really small, but its worth the wait. its a nice cozy local jewel in the outer Richmond.
author: Susan K.

description:
Before trying Shanghai House, I tried Shanghai Dumpling King down the street and ended up with a case of the green apple splatters.  So I was feeling a little gun-shy about eating in tiny hole-in-the-wall dim sum places.  However, I found myself eating at Shanghai House only a few days after my episode, thanks to my addiction to xiao long bao.

I think the dumplings here are similarly priced to Shanghai Dumpling King's, maybe slightly more expensive.  (Apparently the price difference is negligible since it wasn't enough to make an impression on me.)  They were delicious, as were the Chinese donuts that we ordered.  

The restaurant itself looked clean (much cleaner than Shanghai Dumpling King), and it was well-lit.  

The food was excellent and cheap, and I did not get food poisoning.  I'm just taking one star away from this place for the slow service.  So don't come here expecting a quick meal before catching a movie at Balboa Theater!
author: Dwigt S.

description:
Yes, good Shanghainese cooking:

We all go expressly for the Hsiao Lung Bao, but my very most favrit is the Lion Head meatball casserole.  (The Shanghai noodles are iffy.)

It's true:  Don't expect the servers to grovel all over you w/kindness.  After all, they ARE Shanghainese.

Need I go on?  Bon appetit!
author: Clifford L.

description:
Finallly, the bamboo basket arrived! I carefully opened the lid. The hot steam amoebically escaped into the air leaving the sweet and floury fragrance to be captured by the olfactory cells. I could sense my insulin level kicked up a notch.

Salivating, my parotid glands went nuts. 

I carefully layered the spoon with the vinegary reddish sauce. My chopsticks placed two thinly sliced strands of ginger on top of the air-cooled baby dumpling. The folds on the dumpling skin lightly waved when the chopticks held it tight. 

Another round of the captivatingly sweet fragrance disappeared into the air when the dumpling footed onto the bottom the boat-shaped spoon. The vinegary sauce splashed. 

Tightening, my parotid glands went nuts again. 

Without delay, the entire boat with its victim landed on my tongue. Popped, the dumpling let out such warm and sweet broth, mingled with the sourness of the vinegar, saltiness of the soy sauce, and tanginess of the ginger. 

This was it! I was home again. Only at Shanghai House. The long lost twin of Din Tai Fung Dumpling House in Arcadia, Los Angeles, I had been desperately seeking. 

Goodbye low carbs. Hello xiao long bao. Give me another ten, and I woud gulp them down like there was no tomorrow.
author: I'm H.

description:
Ordered the fan twan (rice roll with chinese donut, pork sung, pickled vegetable filling), xiao long baos, and knive shaved noodles. They were all so-so... Sad because we had such high expectations of the dumplings... They weren't even that soupy and just didn't taste right. In fact, nothing tasted quite right...THEN we became sick. Oh so very sick. 

Never ever again.
author: Sandy K.

description: Decent chinese food, nothing more to say about it; potstickers and chowmein.  Prices were cheap and service was efficient. The one thing I do have to say is there extremely slow here!! Came here once in the morning and there was only one other table and we waited 40 minutes for our food. Maybe its there strategy to keep the place looking like it actually has customers.
author: rwanda t.

description:
First of all, they don't accept credit cards. Cash money only.

If you only want reaally delish authentic shanghai food, this place is great  for that. It's also a great place if you're looking to OD on some MSG. Don't expect anything else good. The place is about the size of 2 dorm rooms & very much crowded. The waitress had to make these 2 ladies move to another table during their meal just to seat us (a group of 5). I needed to use the bathroom and I felt like I was on a jungle trek going through the sketch ass kitchen & pitch black stairs to a teeny bathroom at the top. Glad I brought my friend with me or one of the creepy cooks could've raped me.  

Other than the bad ambiance/environment, they have the best shanghai noodles & dumplings!!  Soooo...yummy.  Fried rice was ehh..starchy and weird.  Beef & Brocolli dish was good and so was the duck. I left quite satisfied with my food & the fortune on my cookie.
author: Alexa M.

description: JUICY PORK DUMPLINGS!!! man, these little pouches of deliciousness explode flavorful juices that you could only dream of. haha. all perversion and jokes aside, 3 orders of these badboys just wasn't enough. the onion waffles along with potstickers and rice made for one lunch that I would love to replay over and over again.
author: Alvin P.

description:
sweet + spicy
dried + fried
chicken drummettes
+ chicken wings

tiny + slippery
warm + flowing
succulent meat
in juicy goodness

crunchy green
string beans
salty soy 
with sour pickles
author: Lisa W.

description:
So I consider myself a xiao lung bao connoisseur, considering I've had it where they originated - Shanghai, China.  I've also had it in Hong Kong, and at various Chinese food establishments in Southern Cali (Monterey Park, Arcadia, Rowland Heights, etc).  Although I feel that the xiao lung baos that I've had in SF doesn't compare to any of the above-listed places, Shanghai House is pretty darn close.  Each dumpling was filled with juicy soup goodness and the pork mixture was very well seasoned.

However, the dish that I was most impressed by was the steamed pork and vegetable buns.  The pork and veggie mixture was similar to that in the XLB, and the bun was so soft and fluffy.  I wanted to order extra to go, but my friend wanted to eat Philly cheesesteaks afterwards (see my review for Phat Philly and yes, I am a pig), so I restrained myself.

I definitely would go back here for a XLB fix, but I also do wanna try Shanghai Dumpling King, which is just down the street.
author: Jolene W.

description:
I'm not an expert on Northern Chinese food, but this place seems pretty decent and authentic.  The xiao lung bao (shanghai dumplings) haven't failed me, yet.  I've had my share of pretty bad xlb in San Francisco and was on the lookout for good ones.  These dumplings are served to you piping hot in the bamboo steamer.  The filling is very tender and full of soup.  The best thing to do is to order one basket of xlb, for 2 people.  I don't mind sharing, I just don't want to end up with ONLY 2 dumplings for my portion.  At least 1/2 an order is enough for me.

The other dish to try is the dry fried chicken wings.  If I recall, they're on the menu with the chow mein and such.  When they give you the menu, make sure you get both versions; the traditional and the Americanized one.  Some dishes appear on both menus, though.  The wings are pretty good-sized and very tasty.  They come out piled high on a plate, glistening and sticky, from the sweet and spicy sauce.  Fried super cripsy, so that it seals all the heat and moist chicken inside.  Be careful though, they're sweet and very hot (in temperature), so either wait a bit or make your first bite a tiny one.  These wings are really addictive.  How can you go wrong?  They're deep fried, super crunchy, sweet, and spicy.  Forget buffalo wings, these are the way to go!

I've tried some of the other noodle dishes, but will have to go back several more times, to try other items, and add them to my review.
If you should decide to eat here, make sure you have plenty of time.  There will be a wait.  There's only one server and food comes out of the kitchen at a somewhat moderate pace.  I don't mind, because I know that the dishes are freshly made.
author: CE Y.

description: Sweet and spicy chicken wings, roasted tea duck, shanghai dumpling fresh and juicy and pig knuckle to die for. The owner is the only waitress and three people cooking in the back. Even when empty it does take time to get your food. If you show up on a day that is busy its going to be a long wait but well worth it. Parking is not too bad but they need to fix the dam door that doesn't close properly.
author: Dennis K.

description:
"Damit! I should have taken pictures!!"

That's what I say everytime I try a new place that I love.  I never remember until I'm done with my meal.  This place was the highlight of my week., considering I had to work on a Good Friday...not that it matters since I'm not religious...it's just that I really wanted the day off..

Let's see..we ordered: 
Shanghai Dumplings
Dry Fired Chicken Wing
Salted Pork w/ Veg. Rice Claypot

They were gooooooooooooood.  There's so much more on that menu that I wanted to try, but it was just the two us and there wasn't anymore room in our tummies.  So I will DEFINITELY go back to try the other stuff.  Hopefully I will remember to take pictures.
author: hello k.

description:
Hand cut noodles!! If you've ever seen the process of hand cut noodles, you would understand why there is excitement when a place is found that serves hand cut noodles.  

I've said the phrase "hand cut noodles" 4 times now..   

The xiao lung bao is okay... not as good as in Shanghai, but you can't really compare...    All of their noodle based items are good as well... but the soup base was a little bland.   The hand cut noodles had a great texture and a big heaping bowl of those will have you rolling out of the door rubbing your tummy.    The only downfall of the noodles is that they are very slippery thus making for a hard time using chopsticks.  

Bathrooms are thru the kitchen and up the stairs.  

The next time, we are going to try them for dinner, and see how their actual dishes come out. 

Hand cut noodles!
author: Herb C.

description:
Cheap eats in a sparse and clean space.

We really enjoyed the tea smoked duck and rice cakes. The wintermelon soup is also good but I know that I can make it at home for like a fraction of the price. The dry fried chicken wings weren't as tasty as expected and the dumplings were nice but not out of this world.

I am used to eating Cantonese style Chinese food and this was a nice diversion from the usual. 

I like how the dining room is just that. It's so small that every inch of the front of the house is used for seating customers. And the customer base makes it feel like you're in someone house. I saw a woman feed her elderly mother at dinner and it was just so sweet.
author: Jacquee P.

description:
I must admit that I had high expectations of this place having driven by it so many times.  It is exciting to see a Shanghainese style restaurant in a neighborhood that is so dominated by Cantonese restaurants.  I wanted to try it because it was different so I dragged my mom with me.  

We arrived early because we knew it was a small restaurant and didn't want to wait.  Upon looking at the menu we decided upon
1) Spicy mixed Beef and Beef Tendon 
2) Pot Stickers
3) Shanghainese Noodles
4) Shredded Pork w/ Bean Curd
5) Braised Bean Curd

All the food was decent, nothing outstanding.  I've actually had better Shanghainese food in Davis.  The restaurant however was very clean, but the service was lacking because it was family run and they seemed new to the business.  This isn't a huge deal for me as I actually prefer it this way cause it gives it an extra touch.  I did learn however that there is only one chef (the owner) and because of that the food took longer to come out than most Asian restaurants.  I don't mind this either because again, it adds an extra touch to the meal.  There is one dish that I wish I tried but couldn't, it was the Pork Knuckle.  You must order this 1 day in advance and let me tell you it looked good.
author: Ben M.

description:
They were OUT of Xiao Loong Baos (XLB!) Boo....
Another table was requesting the same and they were sold out since the early evening, overheard two other call ins for XLB as well. They must be really good and famous and to be out of them on a Fri evening? :(
We ended up with a melon soup, white fish braised in wine sauce (a tad too much rice wine), the version at Great China, Berkeley is much better and preserved vege with tofu skin and also a glass of soya bean milk which was good. 

Will raise the star if I try their XLBs the next time. For now, 3.5 stars.
author: Yan M.

description:
The Xiao Long Bao is excellent. I debated whether to stick the first one in my mouth whole, because I didn't know how how the insides were going to be (it's soupy inside), but was pleasantly surprised (and grateful) that the soup was hot but not too hot - it was the perfect temperature. The skins were maybe a bit doughy, but it was still good.

The Green Onion Pancakes were really thick - I prefer the thinner crispier kind but they were pretty good. We really liked the beef brisket noodle soup and plan to try other noodle dishes next time.

The restaurant does kind of have a weird odor inside and the lady is kind of a grump. She speaks Cantonese but I think she'd rather not speak it if she doesn't have to (sticking to Mandarin/Shanghainese). She seemed to warm up after a bit though. Also, we got our dishes one at time so service was indeed kind of slow....
author: Pamela L.

description:
What a disappointment. The place looks extremely clean but service was extremely SLOW not to mention the patrons at the next table were irritating the crap out of me.

The hubby and I entered the restaurant and got seated.
