About 5 mins later, we were asked to be moved to a smaller table--I usually don't mind but the entire 5 minutes that we were sitting at our original table, the patrons waiting for us to move were just GLARING at us (it's not our fault that we got there before you!). We moved to the next table and were served our tea (which was not even luke warm).  Our food came out rather quickly--we enjoyed the xiao long bao, but the rest of the dishes we had ordered were so-so. It took us about 15 mins to get our check.


My story of the patrons sitting at the next table:

Our XLB came out and the hubby and I dived right into eating it w/vinegar (yum). The creepy old man (at the next table) was smiling and watching us as we ate. He said something to the two women sitting next to him and they BOTH turned around and stared rudely for about 2 minutes at how we were eating at our food. I even stared at them back for a minute and said out loud "What are they looking at???"...and they still wouldn't turn away.  w.t.f.  They made our dining experience not very enjoyable..and it didn't help that our smaller table was seated right by the door (and it was a very cold evening).


Sorry...but I think I'll just stick with Shanghai Dumpling King.
author: Jocelyn W.

description:
This initial review is based on my initial visit but I am sure I will be back since it is in my hood.  But what we ordered the first time was a relative hit and a miss.  

The relative hit were the Xiao Long Baos.  I thought they were okay.  Not the worse I've had but not the best either.  But they were cool.  10 for $5.95

We also tried their Shanghai Thick Chow Mein.  There was not much flavor and we had to end up adding some vinegar, hot sauce and soy sauce ourselves to make it taste okay.  However, most places I have went to, this dish has been pretty subpar.  I've had it really good at least a few times but the majority of the time, it ends up very very average.  

Their prices are right.  What seemed to look good was the fried fish with some sauce over it.  A few tables ordered that so maybe it is one of their signature dishes???  

Next time we come, we will certainly order that and maybe the star rating above will get boosted but until then.......
author: Mark W.

description:
This is the #1 reason I have become obsessed with xiao long bao. It's probably the second best place in the city to get those soup dumplings but considering the best place in the city costs like 5 times as much (at that one place I can't remember the name of near Embarcadero) I am plenty happy to come here for my xlb cravings. 

Everything feels handmade and authentic and it reminds me of the tiny restaurants my family loved to eat at growing up. I've been lucky and never had a long wait but the tiny and humble interior can force a line to form...or so i have been told.
author: Minh-Chi T.

description: I believe this is an update to a previous review i gave this restaurant.  Anyway there are always 3 standards we order when coming here the dry fried chicken wings (sweeter than san tung), the xao ling bao soup dumplings, and the pan fried home made noodles with pork.  His doesn't leave room for much else unless ur eating with more than 3 people.  Anywho the last time we came here (last week) of the 6 times i've been here the chicken wings were freak'n amazing, it looks like thy have perfected their cooking method.  I mean the wings were always to hot to touch when they came out, but his time they were super crispy and the sauce stuck to them with all the little garlic and chili pepper bits.  Don't over look their hand made noodles tho, their soft and chewy texture is created from hand rolling the noodles, and some times you'll get a glimpse of them making them when u pass by a room on the way to the bathroom upstairs.  All in all this place is always consistantly good, but this last time was great. The only downer would be the that the owner whom i assume is the server lady isn't always in the best of moods lol
author: Spencer W.

description:
There's a sense of sadness in this restaurant.   The boss lady looks tired with sad panda eyes.  The kitchen staff all look very sad too.  It's almost like walking into a funeral.  Sorry.

However the food is totally awesome.  XLB does have thicker skin, but it's not unreasonably thick.  None of the 2 orders of XLBs broke.  Thick skin has its benefit.  Everything else we ordered were nicely done too.  We didn't order any of the Americanized food, although the fried chicken wings were tempting.  I guess the wings are similar to San Tung's.

We prefer this place over the other 2 popular XLB restaurants.  This place is newer and cleaner.  The seating is not as cramped.  Although the workers look sad, the service is decent.
author: Kimo L.

description: My boyfriend and I are regulars here.  The food is amazing, especially for the price.  Our favorite dishes include the dumplings, the pickled vegetables and bean curd sheet, the garlic chicken, the sesame chicken, and the beef vermicelli clay pot.  All the soups with the hand-cut noodles are outstanding.  I hope Shanhai House stays around for a long time.  It changed my perception of Chinese cuisine.
author: Victoria R.

description:
My boyfriend took me here after I had a dream about dumplings and these were as good as the ones in my dreams. The outer skin was a perfect and complemented the creamy texture of the meat perfectly. The dumplings come with a vinegar and ginger dipping sauce. The only sad thing about this meal was that not all the dumplings had soup in them. This inconsistency was disappointing until we went to Dumpling King a few blocks away and all their dumplings were soup-less. Compared to Dumpling King I would rather have Shanghai House dumplings. 

We also ordered the Dried Fried Garlic Chicken Wings which were awesome! I loved the sweet and spicy flavor with a hint of basil that coated each chicken wing. The chicken wings were fried to a perfect crunchy texture. I would totally order this dish again for sure!!

The service was pretty decent considering that there was only one person serving us and consistent flow of people coming in. The price is pretty reasonable. 10 dumplings for $5.50 and the chicken wings were about $7 for 10 wings. For sure Shanghai House would be my place to go for dumplings.
author: Lang T.

description:
Something eerie happened the night I visited here.  I had heard this place can get real crowded with a line waiting out the door.  But on this night, there was not a single person in the place.  We walked in and the waitress had to come out from the back to speak to us.  We sat at a table for 6, within 4 SECONDS the ENTIRE place was filled to the brim.  Still have no idea what happened.  I hear the service isnt great here but the ONE waitress serving the tiny place wasnt bad at all.  She got our orders right quick and refilled everything in a quick fashion.  The place is much cleaner than the dumpling place next door but has a smaller selection.  They had two menus:  one for the Asians and one for the non Asians.  Aka one had things like sweet and sour chicken, broccoli beef and the other had things like pork knuckles.  

Tip: get the fried chicken wings.  To DIE for.  Don't use the creepy bathroom upstairs, save your shit for home.
author: Tiffany L.

description:
I came here to treat my mother to some noodles, but it seems that I corralled more relatives along the way and it became a sizeable group. If we knew the size of the noodle bowls, we wouldn't have ordered 5 noodles! We really liked the spicy Tan Tan noodles. It wasn't so spicy that you'd scream 5 alarm fire, but just tangy enough to be good. We weren't impressed with the shanghai dumplings. My mom says that the pork fillings were a bit too sweet and I thought that the skin was too chewy. The shredded eel noodles were quite good and filled with veggies. The other noodles were okay, but not as good as tan tan. 

Service was spotty, with only 1 server to handle the entire floor...sometimes we were waiting for a bit. I'm glad there's another noodle house out in the Richmond area, I just wish it was more than what I had expected.
author: Pauline L.

description:
Wow, the place was incredibly clean, and even though the waitstaff was slow in such a small place, the food was worth it.

The sweet and sour pork was excellent! Flat thinly sliced pieces in a crispy batter, not too heavy or too sweet.

The Sesame chicken and dried fried chicken wings were way too sweet for my taste. The Buddha's Delight veggie combo was awesome, even though it didn't have the customary fried tofu pockets and glass noodles.

Will definitely come here again if I find myself near the beach soon!
author: dj z.

description:
I went here for work lunch as recommended by one of my co-workers. It's a pretty new resturant- about 6 months or so, which is kind of small, but cute. It's a pretty clean place, but the service was SLOW. 

The food, I would say are average, but they are pretty decent in prices. I ordered Shanghai dumplings and it was okay, and I also had seafood fried rice. I have to say that the fried rice was rather bland. The green onion panckaes were crispy, but again, it was bland. Even the tea itself was watered down. So sad. HOWEVER, what was good was the CUTTLEFISH. Suprisingly, it was GOOD and that was the only highlight of my lunch. 

I saw that they have dim sum, too. So, maybe next time IF I come around the place again, I would try them. But, I won't make special trip to the place although they have good cuttlefish. I rather go down to Chinatown to eat good chinese food although the place isn't that clean, but it's Chinatown!.
author: Daisy S.

description:
If possible, I would give it a 3.5.  I can't say with all my hear that "I'm a fan," but "A-OK" seems a bit low.  They do offer the best steamed pork dumplings I've had in the city (I didn't realize they go by XLB now), and the rest of the Chinese breakfast we had was tasty too.

Their Chinese donut was definitely fried to order, and was also the best I've had in the city.  The green onion pancake was the loser of the morning, but the silver threaded bun and the donut wrapped in rice (I forget the name) made up for it.  I didn't try the regular entrees, but I'm sure I'll be back for the Chinese breakfast.
author: Mike W.

description:
Read about this place in "Best of...2008." I have been looking for a good soup dumpling place in SF for awhile now and boy did Shanghai deliver. 

Came for lunch, got the dumplings and beef and brocolli. This was perfect amount for 2 people and cost less than $12.  Make sure you look at all the menus. There are two different menus. One will have basic chinese food favorites, the other, the Shanghai specific menu, with the dumplings, 10 for  $5.50!! So GOOOD.   

I wish this place was closer though. 38th and Balboa is deep.
author: Jimmy L.

description:
My new favorite Shanghai place. The food is good and autheric. The dumpling is comparable to Shanghai Dumpling King. Some might find the dumpling skin a little think. I think it's ok since I can pick it up without breaking it. That way the juice is still trap inside. Most of the time there's one or two dumpling was broken at Shanghai Dumpling King. 

The newspaper on the glass wall recommended veggie goose. That's a good choice but I'll recommend the drunken chicken. It's a cold dishes but the taste is super, even better than Shanghai Dumpling King. 

The only problem to me is parking. make sure give yourself at least 15 mins to get a parking spot.
author: Jason L.

description: I tried this place originally because the chinese place I usaully had gone to for so many years had changed owners and the food now tasted awful... so I ordered some food from this place I mean I still liked the other place I had gone to better because the food was just alright.... then I went another time where I actually ate at the place and I was a little grossed out..... There was a lot of people having coughing fits and spitting into towels and uhhh it wasn't a pleasant environment to eat it and the place was packed with only one almost non-speaking english waitress...... so I think I stick to takeout with this place until I can find another place!
author: Sophia C.

description: I don't know why it took me so long to find this place. It's not for the ambiance, it's for the food! Shanghai dumplings, sesame chicken, dry chicken wings (not dry... i don't understand, but who cares) spicy cold plate combo are my favorites. CASH ONLY
author: James F.

description: Delicious hand-cut noodles and veggie steamed dumplings - good sized portions. All good.
author: Liz B.

description: My favorite Shanghai restaurant in SF! I always come here whenever I have a chance to come to the city! They have THE BEST dry fried chicken! These crispy golden of goodness are coated in a delicious sweet and spicy sauce that I cannot get enough of! Fresh noodles, silky soy milk, juicy xiao long baos- everything I've had so far was really good, no complaints!
author: Tiffany W.

description:
I have to say, I was impressed.

Actually intended to go to this place a few weeks back, but upon getting there at dinner time, the place was empty.  "Not a good sign," we thought, so headed elsewhere. 

Don't be fooled!

Went here recently with some friends - it was still empty when we got there, but we went in anyways:
-- it's small but surprisingly new/clean; not your usual dingy little chinese place
-- there are 2 menus (one of which was definitely for the white folk), so get the good one, which has plenty of decently translated english.

We had:
* seafood clay pot - great flavors, lots of seafood in the pot
* shanghai xiao long bao - a little disappointing because it was too sweet; but then again, it's hard to find a good place if you've had the real stuff overseas
* some pork stir fry dish, which was yummy

For a city dominated by cantonese cuisine and usually mediocre, americanized chinese restaurants, this was a nice change.
author: Linda C.

description:
$14 (including tip) covered dinner for two! We got the XLB and the Tan Tan Noodles. Both were meh. Not bad, not great. The XLB didn't have much broth in them, but on the other hand, weren't that fatty/greasy. In exchange for putting up with non-spectacular food, you get a nice, quiet, clean restaurant with friendly service.

We came here for a XLB-off against Shanghai Dumpling King up the street. The King is King.
author: Rob T.

description:
Unfortunately whilst at Shanghai House this weekend I either had horrible reception, or was mildly dehydrated.  Nature just didn't call, thus I cannot report on the state of their facilities.  I can imagine them being clean, minimal and utilitarian.  Nothing special.  I absolutely need to return to SH for those excellent spareribs.

Anywho, maybe you wanna know about the food...

As I said, went to SH this weekend with my friend, let's call her April.  We ordered four dishes, let me tell you in descending order of goodness:

Sweet and sour spareribs:  By far my favorite dish!  A cute pile of ribs atop a thick black pool (looked like crude oil) of the sweet and sour sauce.  All the nooks and crannnies of the ribs, in perfect little bite size pieces, allow tons of sauce to stick to them. Ragnarok!

Cucumber and bean thread salad:  This dish reminded me of a little bit of the dan dan noodles back at A&J (http://www.yelp.com/biz/a-and-j-restaurant-rockville#hrid:uRTGIS3KdUPKe2-YzvG2gg/query:A&J).  Mildly spicy and with a hint of sesame, nice cold pieces of cucumber, yummy noodles.  Soooo good.

XLB: Pretty good, a good amount of soup and nice thin skins.

Finally, knife cut stir-fried noodles with pork and vegetables:  The noodles in this dish had great texture, nothing beats home made noodles (they're better than being spanked with a wet noodle).  But all in all the dish was a little bland, needs something salty or spicy, but I don't think that any of it went back to the kitchen.

I think I walked two miles in our wonderful freezing winds before a bus caught up to me and got to ride the next 35 blocks to SH, but I think if I walked all the way there, I would have been happy (as long as I could have rolled home).  The wait wasn't my favorite part of the dining experience, the dining room is tiny, and it didn't help that we wanted dinner at 8:00 PM on a Friday night, so all-in-all 30 min wasn't too shabby a wait, especially since it allowed us to examine other peoples dishes and decide what we wanted.  Thankfully, mt wallet was not conversely emptied as my stomach was filled at SH, the whole meal set me back less than a $20.  I'll be back.
author: Adrian L.

description:
Sigh.... This is problem with living in NY. Don't get me wrong, I embrace SF as my new home and it's the only place for me outside NY. But this is why I am spoiled; NY people just do shit proper. 

A homey come from Shanghai and says he wants to open a restaurant and serve xlb, in NY, he does that shit right. People are getting away with murder here, and I'm talking pizza, ramen and all those other things you here people arguing authenticity about in yelp. Don't feature XLB unless you got it locked down. JUST stop making pizza. How freaking hard is it to make freakin ramen? 

Shanghai House is receiving the brunt of my continued frustration but seriously San Franciscans, DON'T SETTLE FOR SUBPAR. Demand your xlb be juicy and tasty and filled with glorious soup. Demand the crab option. Demand that your shanghai noodles have some goddamned taste. May you not have to get up just to get the attention of the waitress. And a warning, if you like the xlb's here, don't ever go to NY Chinatown, cause you'll come back and join me in this perpetual hell.

And to you fake restaurants out there, you may be fooling some, but go to sleep knowing that there are some out here who know you as frauds. Don't serve shit unless you got it. You know when you make that shit and taste it, you know it ain't right!! YOU  know. And now you know that we know!!!
author: Jay N.

description:
A new neighborhood spot to enjoy some yummy "xiao long bao" aka shanghai dumplings. They were bite size and fresh. We also tried their salted pork and vegetable rice in clay pot and it was very simple, very bland. I felt bad for having to add soy sauce to it...and I NEVER add soy sauce to rice. I also enjoyed a cup of their sweetened soy milk, served very hot.

The dining room is super small but very bright thanks to the ceiling-to-wall glass windows and door. The place was clean and simple. One server was typical Chinese restaurant type - no smile, and not necessarily rude, just made you feel like you were bothering them with your petty requests. The other servers were nice and said "thank you."

I might have ordered the wrong thing on the menu, but I would definitely give this place another shot because of the dumplings. They were delicious and their prices weren't ridiculous. Plus, I like how they keep the operation small so the food is served fresh...CASH ONLY.
author: Vicki F.

description:
i love this place for so many reasons, most of which will probably not apply to most of the people reading this (i.e. it's close to my house and i've been away at college where they do NOT have anything close to this kind of food.) 

The green onion pancakes are a MUST. i could seriously chow down a whole order on my own. My other favorites are the xiao long bao (dumplings,) beef brisket noodle soup, and chow nian gao! so good. just thinking about it makes me hungry... 

if you're in the neighborhood, check it out! The wait might be a litle more than desired, but it's mos def worth it!
author: Kimberly K.

description:
This place is waaaaaaaaaaaaaayyyyy out there in Richmond....but worth the drive!  The food here is pretty good and inexpensive.  The vegetarian goose (crisp tofu skin with mushroom filling) is really delicious.  Spring rolls are good too.   As with the rice cake, steamed dumplings, and the yan du xian (it's soup with an intense flavor of smoked ham).
 
Decor is simple and clean.  Finally, a Chinese restaurant that does not write menu items on a strip of red paper and tape it on the walls like it's decoration!
author: Aila L.

description:
I live near this place and will almost certainly eat here again, so it's possible my opinion will improve, but after two visits, I would say:
-I prefer the dumplings at Shanghai Dumpling King up the street, for their thinner wrapper and better flavor. This is not in any way an authoritative or expert opinion, just my preference. But these were reasonably tasty too.
-The sweet and sour sparerib sauce is interesting, very dark and almost coffee/syrup like. I found it had a bit too much charcoal taste to it, for my liking.
-The handcut noodles with shrimp were garlicky and pretty good.
-I enjoyed the vegetarian goose.

Service was pretty prompt when we were there on a weeknight, even though the place was busy. The place is clean and bright, as others have noted, if small.

The fact that they handed my friend and I the boring Chinese standards menu on my first visit there irritates me even more than being given a fork rather than chopsticks. I never would have known they served anything worth eating if I hadn't seen an article mentioning a second menu.

Overall, I give an edge to Shanghai Dumpling King-- but this place is closer, so I suspect laziness will help even the score!
author: Sara G.

description:
Yummy soup dumplings and sweet-and-sour ribs, meh everything else. Salt overload, and the noodle dishes and meatballs we had mostly tasted like vinegar. 

The mushrooms in with the meatballs were tasty. Maybe next time I can find something on the menu that is mostly mushrooms. Otherwise I am sticking with dumplings and bringing some beer. Mmmm, beer.
author: andrea s.

description:
I love this place! I've been here so many times since Shanghai Dumpling King failed me thrice in a row! 
Every time I come here, the lady server/host looks really depressed and hella tired.  I feel bad for her to have to be there all the time and dealing with the same crap everyday but she runs a great place!

It's a nice, small and clean ( for the most part) place to have a quiet meal.  It really does seem like she's the ONLY person working there even though they've got like 5 people in the back.  I love the shanghai dumplings and vegetarian goose (su arr) here! I noticed that the dumplings are better if you go at certain times.  One time  I went for a late lunch in the mid afternoon, and the dumplings were all deflated but every time we go for dinner, it's great! 
The lady doesn't really tend to your every need at all times but you have to understand that she's the only one out there! So she's totally outnumbered.  She isn't very friendly at first but if you go there enough, she'll warm up to you.  I tried to brush up on my mandarin with her and practice ordering the three things I always get: 2 shanghai dumplings, 1 vegetarian goose, and 1 cucumber bean curd salad.   Very reasonably priced.  I'd recommend it!  Just don't expect to be super pampered with exceptional service but expect to be satisfied with a great meal!
author: Tu L.

description:
See, I have a thing for Shanghai food. In fact, it's my kryptonite. I will go to great lengths to find the perfect xiao lung bao, even scale the Empire State Building just for one lion's head meatball. Thankfully, my search is over! Here at Shanghai House, is probably the most authentic you can get. 

Soup Dumplings: Skin is a LITTLE too thick for my taste, but then again my tongue is very jaded after having spent a week in Hong Kong. The meat is very flavorful and tender, while dripping with soup.

Lions Head Meatball: The meat is so moist and soft, it's almost rare. It comes in this sizzling clay pot with other goodies such as bamboo and mushroom.

Fried Chicken Wings: Jesu Christo, these are good! Portions are huge so you'll want to eat more than one, which isn't a good idea since these are 90% pure fat. They may look big, but most of it is just fried batter. The batter is great and forms this thick crispy shell around the chicken. The sauce that comes with it is tasty too. In fact, it's so good I was tempted to deep fry my fingers and dip them in the sauce (I was really tempted. After all, I'm Chinese, I eat all kinds of meat).

Our food did take a little too long to arrive, and rice is exorbitantly expensive, but all in all the food is worth it!
author: Sharron C.

description:
I love how there's a Shanghainese restaurant in my neighborhood. After moving from NYC, where Shanghainese restaurants are cheap and plentiful, I was scared that I wouldn't be able to have my soup dumpling fix ever again.

Wrong. Although true Shanghainese style of soup dumplings is small, I can't help compare it to Joe's Shanghai in NYC (no one will ever beat those crab dumplings). All I really need to make me happy is an order of soup dumplings, and an order of Shanghai rice noodle cakes. So cheap. I love it.

Good service too. When we walked in with our party of 4, there was only one table of 2 available, and the party of 3 offered to move to sit our party there. That was really nice of them.

Can't wait to go back!
author: Jeanne C.

description:
This place serves THE most authentic Shanghainese food in all of San Francisco.  

Didn't try their soup dumplings so can't speak to them (and frankly there is a LOT more to Shanghainese cuisine than soup dumplings....).  But their dinner dishes (which you can order during lunch - instead of their lunch plates) were down to the bone authentic and delicious.

So happy I found this place.
author: J K.

description:
Visited on 10/07/07
  When I finish my quest to eat at every Chinese restaurant in SF - which should be over this year - I want to concentrate on particular regional styles, like Shanghai. This new little spot will be high on the list. I've had beef tendon in pho, but never by itself in a hot pepper oil, which gives flavor to anything, just like bacon. The first test for a good Shanghai place is dumplings, and the Pork and Vegetable variation I had was very good. I  definitely have to come back with friends.
author: Chili Bill E.

description:
The Shanghai dumplings are DEELISH!  Better than Five Happiness, better than Shanghai Dumpling King up the block, better than Ding Tai Fung!  Focus on the Shanghai dishes menu, try the stir fried shrimp.  This resto passed the authenticity test by my Shanghainese family =)

Cash only spot.
author: Vivian L.

description:
back again today for the same thing . . . -green onion pancake

dumplings
hand cut noodle
dry fry chicken wing

vg

clean bathing room
author: Jeff D.

description: For some of the reviews that gave one or two stars.. are you guys even from shanghai? Have you tried REAL shanghai dumplings? Have YOU realized shanghai is thousands of miles away?! Their shanghai dumplings are pretty decent considering Shanghai is so far away. I for one am Shanghainese, the food is authentic. Yes service is slow because this is almost like a hole in the wall. The waitress is probably the owner, and the rest of the family is working in the back. At least you know the food is authentic, and made fresh! Every time i come here lines are out the door. Service is sometimes slow, but what do you expect ? If you want fast service, theres always fast food
author: Mike H.

description: I came here with my boyfriend on a very slow weekday. The service was HORRIBLE. There was only one other table and we were barely acknowledged. The food was alright, but I've experienced better. When we were done with certain plates, the owner would walk by and look at it but not pick it up. Also, I had to wait 15 minutes to order when I was ready after 5 minutes. I tried getting the owner's attention but was completely ignored. I would recommend to go elsewhere for Shanghai food.
author: Rebecca T.

description: Ordered shangai stir fry thick noodles, shanghai dumplings, savory rice roll, and green onion pancake. Shanghai dumplings were good, skin did not break and a lot of soup but the skin turned hard after a while. The shanghai thick noodles were not good at all, the noodles were overcooked, the veggies in it were soggy and I did not like how it was drenched in gravy. Savory rice roll was good, pancakes were lacking that buttery flavor. My boyfriend was also very disappointed. He said he is sticking to shanghai dumpling king from now on, and I agree.
author: A L.

description: Their dumplings are nothing special. Bean puff tastes is as bad as it looks. My mom can make the same dish ten times better. The beef brisk soup tastes like soy, and the knife noodle is tired and under cooked. All and all, there is no depth in their food.
author: Apple G.

description: First Chinese restaurant in SF after sometime, and what a huge disappointment.  I can't believe there are such good reviews of this place.  What a joke!  xiao long bao (soup dumplings) were pasty, overcooked, and disgustingly sweet, while the main dishes we ordered tasted exactly the same (again the nasty sweetness), and consisted of chopped up slop in MSG sauce.  Yuck.
author: Risha L.

description: Really good chicken wings--almost as good as San tungs though a little too sweeter and some days the taste is different than others. Other food is ok.  But terrible, terrible service and they can hardly be bothered  to answer their phone anymore for take out orders.
author: shimon t.

description:
Not bad, not bad at all... But growing up with asian food, my expectations are quite high. And this place just made the cut.

The place was smaller than I had anticipated. Pretty clean and decently modern decor with some asian influence. 

Their oh-so-famous shanghai dumpling. Pretty good but not something I've never had before. It's comparable to Koi Palace's shanghai dumpling and only a little more than half the price of Koi's. Good stuff.
Potstickers, not bad. MIni-sized but packs a decent punch.
Tea soaked duck. A little on the salty side and a lot of fat. Boo...
Tan Tan Noodles. Spicy. Good. Lots of oil. Clogging...
Bean Curd Puff. The review they had up had a picture of it and the plate did not look like the picture at all! Deception! But it was still good. Although I could have made it myself at home. Easy stuff.
Shanghai Noodles. Bland.
Sweet Soy Bean Milk. Hot. Wanted to try the savory one because of the picture on yelp but they didn't have it. Whack! Sweet one was whatever.
Chinese donut. Doughy. Eh...
Green Onion Pancake. Also doughy. Should have listened Natalie L.'s advice.

Bathroom. Through the kitchen, up the stairs. Apparantly the stairs only leads to the bathroom and nothing else. Weird.

Good dinner though. Probably better for lunch.
author: Jimmy N.

description:
Finally rolled out of bed and got all freshened up for a late Sunday brunch. I was craving Xiao Long Bao so we came here per a friend's suggestion. We found parking a few spaces outside the restaurant on this sunny afternoon - GREAT start! We walked in, stood there like idiots for a full minute before we tried to get their attention. What's up with the no acknowledgment?!  After the waitress knew we exisited, she sad us down and brought us the menus.  Maybe it was because we we're Asian (or they just totally suck in service) but the couple that came in after us never got their menu - they had to walk to the counter and retrieve it themselves.  We were ready to order in 5ish minutes and have been getting their attention - NO ONE responded even though we were waving our hands like morons in the air.  There was TWO waitresses so no excuse. One was mainly waiting the tables, etc. The second, older waitress was just at the counter eating her soup and being lazy (aka pretending not to see us).  Finally after counting to a billion or something like that, we shouted for the waitress' attention and got our order (one order of xiao long bao and jaja mein) in. 

Finally the food arrived.  As the waiter put down the steaming hot xiao long bao, my mouth was watering and stomach already making noises.  I carefully picked one up so I would not break the skin and let the juice all spilling out. I took a small bite, trying to savor the juice that will flow into my mouth - disappointed! Where's the JUICE?! Maybe the second one will be better. NOPE! The next three had the same result.  *shakes head* How can an authentic Shanghai restaurant not have great, at least good, xiao long bao?!  The jaja mein were disappointing too. The sauce was too soupy for my taste.  

Took a while for the waitress to see we were done with our meal.  

The bf wanted to come back here to try their other dishes for dinner. I told him no - I'm young but I don't have patience for people who won't acknowledge their customers and SLOW service.

-1 star for no acknowledgment
-1 star for taking forever to take out order / slow service
-1 star for no satisfying xiao long bao
author: Joanna W.

description: Came here last night so I could check it off the 100 things to eat list.  I was concerned that the Asian items on the 7x7 Top 100 eats list would be suspect but the xiao lung baos at Shanghai House are actually not bad, not bad at all.  Why only 3 stars?  The XLBs probably are worthy of 4 stars, the service is probably 4 stars, the fried chicken 3 stars, the green beans 4 stars, the green onion pancake 3 stars but the dan dan noodles are probably like 1 star.  It was the weirdest dan dan noodles I've ever had - no sign of the sesame spicy peanut goodness of dan dan noodles.
author: Jen C.

description: My weekly shanghainese breakfast place. Chinese donut wrapped in sticky rice (salty) = awesomeness!
author: Joanne X.

description:
Let me start off by saying this used to be one of my favorite Shanghai dumpling places in the Bay.  

This time the restaurant was a total FAIL.  

The restaurant was half capacity when I got there.  Service was painfully slow.  It was 15 minutes before someone took our order.  

The dumplings were HORRIBLE.  They were not fresh and tasted like they had been open and exposed in the refrigerator for a week.  I could have gone to Ranch99, bought frozen ones, and they would have tasted better.  Not to mention the skin was dry and old.  

You can't go wrong with hand-cut noodles, right?  WRONG.  Totally undercooked.  The center of the noodles were raw.  

You can always judge a good Shanghainese restaurant by their dumplings.  I will probably give them one more chance in a few months, since I've had good experiences before.
author: Dan M.

description: I really like Shanghai Restaurant. Its a hole in the wall kind of place, right in the hustle and bustle of Oakland's Chinatown. Everything here is solid. Its no Yank Sing, but thats ok- Its also 1/3 the price! I get the Green Onion Pancakes, the pan-fried pork dumplings, the Xiao Long Bao (Shanghai Soup Dumplings) and then usually I'll ask the owner to recommend something new.  Today we had a wonton purse soup which was good, but needed soy sauce. Soup dumplings are hard to find, so I always get those. At shanghai Restaurant they have a thicker wrapper, and sometimes the soupiness is inconsistent, but whatever, they're $6. And delicious.
author: Selin K.

description: My only complaint with this place is that its cash only.  Shanghai house is great on the weekend for a late breakfast early lunch.  The special pork dumplings contain broth inside giving them great flavor.  I also like the spicy dry fried chicken wings.
author: Joel M.

description: I love chinese food and I have found there are usually ok, and good, rarely knock your socks off with flavor fantastic, but... This place rocks! I tried the Vegan Goose on suggestion from a few people and WOW, it was delicious. Oddly I hate goose. It doesnt taste like goose to me, but the flavor in their dishes is remarkable. They claim they use no MSG, and fresh spices. It is rather gourmet tasting food at reasonable prices. I have only tried 6 items on the menu so far (not all at the same time!), and each was superb...
author: chris c.

description:
went back the another hood i grew up in.. the rich. i used to go to elementary school right up the street. i remember playing double dragon at this little comiv book shop up on balboa. i remember running into my sister and her buddies at the sugarbowl that used to be here....

xlb?
hand cut noodles?!??!?!
chinese donut with sweet and a savory soy milk?
rice roll thing that was FUCKING INCREDIBLE!!!!??!??! sweet, perfect texture rice on the outside, a crispy donut thingy inside with shredded pork and herbs!!!!!! yes, OH YES, GIVE IT TO ME BABY!!!


yes, the boxers came off.
author: Euge L.

description:
The baby soup dumplings are tasty, but they came out a little tepid for me. Just right if you want to pop the whole thing in your mouth right away, but i prefer my soup dumplings hot. Definitely NOT the best soup dumplings ever.

But the real reason my friend and i came to Shanghai House was to have the knife cut noodles. And so our aggravating experience ensues.
We order the wontons with the knife cut noodles. It comes out with just wontons, so we ask the waitress where the noodles are, and she says..."it's not good with noodles." My friend responds with, "the reason we came here were to eat your knife cut noodles." And the conversation goes back and forth as to why it's not good with noodles, and why we want their noodles. So the waitress takes back the wontons hesitantly. She brings back the dish moments later without the knife cut noodles and with regular noodles. Both of us are very confused considering we had a nice little conversation with the waitress about knife cut noodles only moments before, and told her that's why we sent the dish back. So we nicely point out to the waitress that we ordered knife cut noodles, to which she arrogantly responds...."well, you should have been clear when ordering." I think a 2 minute conversation with her about the knife cut noodles that we wanted added to the dish should make our order sufficiently clear. Her attitude and demeanor with the other customers was just as rude. Suffices to say, SERVICE HERE IS HORRIBLE.  The food isn't even that good to warrant such arrogance. 

Basically, if you can live with out knife cut noodles, and can go down the street to the other Shanghai-nese restaurant, DO IT.
author: Ernest N.

description:
Shanghai House was a solid 2-star until the bill came... and after realizing that $8 per person (including tip) got our plump selves squared and good to go, I decided to add one additional star.  

This unassuming Chinese (or should I say, Shanghainese) establishment was tucked away in the far end of Richmond, away from the hustle and bustle of Clement Street (where, quite possibly, 90% of Inner Richmond Chinese restaurants are located).  As a result, parking situation is a tad better, and as we found out, prices are a lot lower.  

The wait... was still expected.  But then again, we had a large group and it was prime dinner time, so a 40-min wait was not horrendously out of line.  

As always, we had to try the pork Xiao Long Bao and compare it with the other legendary XLBs: Din Tai Fung and Joe's Shanghai.  While neither of these places could beat the price - 10 for $5.25 - I wasn't too impressed by the small, doughy variety with much-less-than-expected amount of soup in those little packets.  

The other dishes were forgettable: flat stir-fried noodles with beef and vegetable, green onion pancakes, spicy braised tofu, and honey walnut prawns, while not the best in their respective classes, were actually good value relative to the prices.
author: Ange L.

description:
this place is great for:
-xiao long bao's ie.  little buns (juicy and tasty on the inside, nice chewy firm skin on the outside.  better than shanghai dumpling king down the street, but remember that SDK has crab dumplings, which are very unique.)
-hand cut noodles (chewy noodle slices tossed with lots of veggies , which give it a great texture.)

this place is okay for:
-dry fried chicken wings (they seem to just fry the wings and toss them in the sauce so the chicken itself is a little bland when you get to the  meat part.  definitely not as good as san tung's wings.  my guy friend thought they were spectacular, though.)

this place is not great for:
-salt and pepper spareribs (bland and flavorless)
-service (only one waitress so very slow)

on sundays they open for lunch until 3pm and open for dinner at 5pm.
author: Josie M.

description: I come here for the Shanghai dumplings and the hand-cut noodles at lunchtime and I'm never disappointed (though sometimes impatient). Steam rising from soup, tea, and soup dumplings always makes me feel like I'm in a Wong Kar-Wai movie. It generally feels like a pretty authentic neighborhood place - small, with lots of Asian families and a taciturn proprietress.  Things move pretty slowly here, don't bother if you're in a hurry.
author: Heather D.

description:
I feel like a fool!

I was trying to get to Shanghai Dumpling King, but didn't know the actual name, only had a friends vague directions to someplace on Balboa. I've gone to Shanghai Dumpling King since and regret ever coming here.
I walk in "do you have soup dumplings?"
Women spraying disinfectant on the tables "yes!"
I sit down and order two portions. 
I waited 45 minutes and...
I have to interrupt myself, think about what I just said: forty five minutes! Unacceptable.
The waitress finally brought them out. After I had one I had to ask if they were actually XLB, there was no soup; it is my understanding that soup dumplings are not in fact ironically named. 
She said they were, and having no evidence to support her statement I had to take her word for it. 
After about a 20 minute wait to get my tab I left cash and unfortunately had to leave a large tip because she wasn't coming by to take my cash.
Well, whatever, she can have my tip, but she certainly can't have my business again.
author: Ross G.

description: I am surprised I could fit my fat ass through these doors.  This place is so small my belly was rubbing against the opposing walls.  Some skinny ass told me about this place.  The skinny person said this was better than Shanghai dumping king down the street.  Never trust a skinny person.  The Xiaolong Bao was definitely not as good.  However, the dirty vegetarian goose was pretty good and the savory rice roll almost reminded me of the savory rice rolls you get in Taiwan.  The portions here are on the smaller side.  I am fat so I need more.  I also prefer to have a fat wallet, but this place stole most of money because it so fatty expensive.  I actually almost forgot I ate at this place.  I will be down the street back to my usual dumpling king with the rest of the fattys.
author: Fatty A.

description: Love it even more now that I can't have it everyday!!!!  I used to live a few blocks away and come here a few times a week.  The Shanghai noodles are off the hook.  If your just an average blue eyed blondie like myself make sure you ask for the menu they give their Chinese patrons.  I found this out because they always give my chinese boyfriend a different menu than me.  Definitely had better options on his menu.  Now that I live on the other side of the city I miss this place dearly!!!!
author: Devon M.

description:
Remember to BRING CASH.  This place is Cash ONLY.

Drawn in by the 7x7.com list, I was very disappointed.  Service took forever.  Maybe it was because it was a Monday night.  But it seemed like the kitchen did not have its act together, which you can read below and see why.

I ordered 3 dishes, in the order received:
1. Salted duck
2. XLB
3. Hand-cut beef noodles

First, the salted duck.  Normally this is prepared ahead of time, so usually you would receive this within 10 minutes of putting in your order, but I sat around for at least 15-20 minutes seeing other people getting their orders.  It was an indication that the kitchen did not have it together.  Once it arrived, it was not salted, but it did have a strong gamy flavor.  The meat was dark which made it look like the duck had suffered some sort of abuse before being killed and then salted.   I've had better.  

About another 10 minutes later, the XLB was brought over, the 7x7 touted 100 things to experience before you die.  It was decent, but I've had better XLB.  The flavor was good, but they were not bursting in soup.  Plus, the vinegar and ginger sauce that they serve with the XLB, over powered any wonderful savory XLB-ness offers.  Good thing I only made the mistake of dipping one of my XLB in that concoction.

Finally, after waiting what felt like another 15 minutes after inhaling the XLB and the salted duck, the hand-cut beef noodles finally arrive.  Now, if you ask anyone who has made fresh noodles, they will tell you that noodles cook faster fresh than from the box.  While this usually true, that means that the noodle dish will arrive before the XLB, since the XLB takes at least 25 minutes to steam through.  For some strange reason, the hand-cut noodle dish comes out last.  Now, the person working the front of the house was following up with the kitchen asking when the noodles were going to come out, well, that just says to me, that the kitchen was asleep at the trigger.  On top of that, the hand-cut noodles were like slugs floating around which was not appealing at all, not the nice thin sliced noodles that you would expect in a noodle soup.  I decided to not judge immediate and to taste it, the broth was good, the noodles were not so great, they tasted like they were overcooked.  There was only 2 decent sized pieces of beef.  If I wasn't such a soup person, I would probably have rated this dish a failure.

Needless to say, I've checked off an item from the 7x7 list, but I won't be going back anytime soon.
author: Mei C.

description:
The food is quite good but not worth the wait.  Once you sit down, expect to wait about 30 minutes before your first dish comes out when at over half room capacity.  I've come here a few times, and have tried both there dimsum and entrees.

(+) Food comes out sizzingling hot!  Lunch specials (under $6) with large portions and fresh ingredients.  Noodle soups and claypots are also quite good.
(+/-) I think the dimsum and chow mein here is very average and tried vegetarian dumplings, shanhai dumplings, onion pancakes etc. There are definetly places much better places in the City.
(-) Service: Only 1 waitress for the whole restaurant, including handling the cash register. I'd guess there is only 1 chef working and they don't have an efficient system down - as it takes 30 minutes for dim sum to come out!

For me, I've come here several times, and will not come again due to the amount of time it takes for the food to come out.
author: Hotung T.

description: 3.5 stars for me. I had forgotten to bring my lunch to work that day and I work very close by to this place. I called my buddy up and we decided to come here because we were in the mood for noodles and soup but more importantly I wanted to check out the dumplings :). We ordered the baby shanghai dumplings and I ordered wonton mein and my ordered a regular wonton soup.  The baby shanghai dumplings were like little pockets of bursting flavor and broth. The first bite i took , i was like whoa and then the broth dripped out. lols i was like eh O_o The noodles were hand made, the texture, taste and firmness of the homemade noodles were dead set perfect. I love eating noodles with my soup. I could eat noodles for breakfast, lunch and dinner and even as a snack. My only complaint was that there should have been more wontons for the price we paid.  I will return and try more of the dumplings.
author: Jonathan W.

description: This place is pretty good. No real complaints. I've been here a few times and have always had fast service--but not the most friendly by any means. The Shanghai Dumplings are pretty good, although I've had much juicier ones. Their Dan Dan noodles, Meatsauce noodles and onion pancakes are pretty good as well.
author: Emily C.

description: Outrageous "shiu long boa", or little dragon dumplings.  scary good.  our usual order: dumplings (2 orders), five spice beef, green onion pancakes (varies, but usually tip top), vegetarian goose (pressed tofu skin) stuffed with mushrooms, chinese style sweet/sour pork - read: Chinese style, not the orange goop, special noodle (knife cut - their speciality).  i usually roll out the door and into the car.  a walk around the block (okay, several blocks), I am ready for another dumpling run.  Run, do not walk there.  You won't be sorry!
author: Sonia C.

description:
i love this place...food is yummy, parking is easy, place is relatively clean for a chinese restaurant. only setback is the slow service...there's usually only one lady working the tables and register and it takes awhile to place your order, and quite awhile longer to actually get your food.

once the food arrives, i usually forget that i was grumpy (about the wait) and happily chow down on the xiao long baos and other yummy dishes (hand cut noodles...mmmmm). but just a warning: prepare to wait!
author: Jill L.

description: Tried to find this place but the address on 7x7.com is incorrect.  It should be 3641, not 3541.  So go one more block.  Ended up going to both Shanghai Dumpling King AND this place and while ok, it was nothing special.  The soup dumplings aren't as tasty, the sauce is waaaay too sweet, and the service wasn't that friendly.  We were the only people in there at about 8:30pm.
author: Tim T.

description: I give this place 3.5 stars.  The xiao long bao where good however not the best I've had in San Francisco.  I actually reserve that for Yank Sing in the Rincon center.  The skin was a little to thick and not sturdy enough which may sound weird.  The amount of broth and flavor was right on.  The hand cut noodles and rice cake were great as well as the green onion pancakes.  I would definitely go back because the food was good and well priced.  Small place so expect to wait.
author: goldberg d.

description: The food here is ok, nothing to write home about, but the service sucks.
author: Quailty P.

description: Yummy xiao long baos and green onion pancakes. Simply deelish, especially after the experience I had at Spices II the same afternoon. I really like the look of the place too. It was clean and didn't look like a tacky Chinese restaurant. The service was alright, nothing to complain about. I will definitely come back to try the other items. They look so yummy!
author: Audrey T.

description:
Eating at good ethnic/Chinese restaurants makes me wonder why I pay $5 and up for a sandwich or $10 for a plate of pasta. The amount of effort that goes into making a good bowl of noodle soup or plate of dumplings makes me feel guilty that I am paying them so little.

Anyway, Shanghai house as the other yelpers have pointed out is way out there in the 30th ave and Balboa area. There is not much else in the area except for a movie theater and some other ethnic eateries. But  I would definitely make out a trip out here again just for a meal.

The restaurant is small, clean and fairly new. We ordered the Shanghai dumplings,  green onion pancakes, pork/noodle soup,  and the dry fried wings. Total approx $25. The dumplings were not the best that I have had, but very good. The noodles in the soup were hand cut(not hand pulled) and perfectly chewy. The dry fried wings were perfect. as good as So's. better than the wings at OB town in Oakland.  

Food *****
Value *****
Decor **
author: T L.

description:
i prefer SDK but this place has some dishes that SDK doesn't.  the green onion pancake is better here. 

dishes that SDK doesn't have:

dry fried chicken - good but not as good as san tung.

handcut noodles - pretty good but the last time i went they were skimpy on the noodles and heavy on the veggies. not a good sign.
author: julia t.

description: The entrees had me wishing that I ordered a second helping of soup dumplings.  Not that the entrees weren't good, they just weren't memorable.  Food at other people's tables looked better than ours so maybe we just didn't know what to order.
author: T-Bone L.

description: Shanghai House has become my favorite restaurant in S.F. The dumplings are quite simply the most delicate and tasty I have ever had. The dipping sauce has shards of fresh ginger and is perfect. Also, the "vegetarian goose," which is made of crispy tofu skins fried with mushrooms inside and a sweet sauce drizzled over the top is extraordinary. I am usually not into vegetarian dishes, especially when they pretend to be meat substitute, but this is not remotely in the league of the aforementioned. The atmosphere is plain, brightly lit and there is an air of greatness in cooking. The front is all glass and the neon marquis of the Balboa Theatre across the street is all the artwork one could hope for.
author: Barbara S.

description:
small space, clean and bright.  the room filled up around 6:30 on a weeknight, but there was no line and the turnaround time for tables was rather quick, especially considering there was only one lady working up front.

i love duck, but their tea smoked duck was dry, salty and i was pretty sure that i ate the whole plate without biting into a single piece of meat.  just fat.  the poor thing was probably caught before its first migration because it's obvious it had never worked a single muscle in its entire life.  the green onion pancake was crunchier than the ones you find elsewhere and i liked it.  the shanghai rice cakes was a little bland, but it's not drenched in oil.  as for the xaio long bao, it was tasty but i've had better. 

they have no vinegar available on their spice tray and i have a little beef with that.  don't call me petty - that thing is like our ketchup.
author: Andrew P.

description:
so annoyed.  i went here specifically to try their shanghai dumplings, and they didn't have anymore wtf!!! and this was at lunch time.  i don't get it, maybe all the local highschoolers ate them all.

green onion pancakes were okay, a little on the salty side.
make sure you call first too see if they have any more dumplings left.
author: Jen C.

description: This place is small, so be prepared to wait during prime times.  The XLB was juicy, the dry fried chicken wings were good, not quite as good at San Tung, but decent.  Good place to have a good Shanghai meal during off peak hours.  Come when its busy and the food becomes inconsistent.
author: Alan N.

description: This place is t-i-n-y. We are talking 8 small tables and no decor on the white walls. Perhaps the most eerie thing about Shanghai House is that it is freakishly quite. People patiently wait for their dumplings in absolute silence. The dumplings are very tasty, but not quite as good as Shanghai Dumpling King down the street. In fact, I only came here because SDK was closed since the owners were on vacation. The dumplings are 25 cents more than SDK and there are no yummy Chinese egg doughnuts. Solid dumplings, but no doughnuts.
author: Dana H.

description: With the exception of the dumplings, the food was below average as was the service. My party didn't even bother boxing up the leftovers.
author: Jane K.

description:
excellent green onion pancake, hand cut noodles are good, the vegatarian goose was good
xiao long bao was ok

fan twan(rice logs with chinese donut, shredded pork, was not good

will need to come back and try other noodles
author: ray l.

description: This is totally a momma poppa shop. They only seat about 25 people but they do get the food out quick enough.  The Shanghai dumplings are great!   This is definitely a must try.  I had this soy bean with bean thread sheet dish and it was really light and tasty.  I couldn't help saving some for the next day so that I can enjoy it again.  It is definitely worth the drive out to outer sunset.
author: Carmen C.

description: Waaay overrated. Had some shanghai dumplings that were so dry, I didn't even finish it. For anyone who knows shanghai food, their dumplings are supposed to be filled with soup. Green onion pancakes were soggy and oily. I'm not going back....
author: Tommy B.

description:
I just had lunch at Shanghai House with my elderly mother and brother.  We came out of there angry!  This never happened to me before, angry with a restaurant enough to write about it.  The food is not bad.  The service is slow and very disorganized, but that's not my complaint.  

When the waitress/owner picked up our cash for the check, she commented that we ate two orders of the XLB.  (I think this was an after-thought, since she only billed us for one, I think.)  We ordered one order.  They gave us one order.  We finished one order.  Of course we denied having had two orders.  She stated that we did, and said 'never mind' and went off to clean another table.  My words can not describe to you her negative facial expression and body language toward us.  We are definitely NOT going back!!!!!
author: Esther K.

description: They serve the best pork dumplings (xiao long bao) in the Bay Area. (Haven't found any that is better) Other delicious dishes that are my favorite: pot stickers, soy beans (edamame) with bean curd noodles & pickled mustard greens, green onion pancakes, Shanghai noodles, braised noodles with green onion and dry shrimp, and malted dry chicken wings. This place is small, but the service is attentive and quite clean. Cheap but cash only.
author: Cindy K.

description: Great Chinese food, but the service sucks all around. If you have time their shanghai dumplings are one of the best!
author: Kris H.

description:
My family checked out this place for our regular Friday night dinner.  The 9 of us tried a variety of dishes and I was impressed, esp. with its price. 

This place is fairly small so make reservations. They pulled 4 tables together for our family. The place was packed all night.  

Service was so-so. There is only one waitress and she looked stressed out and angry most of the night.  I felt sorry for some of the patrons because their food took FOREVER to come out probably because the kitchen was cooking all of our stuff. There were tons of people in and out for take out orders as well. 

Their "little dragon buns" were really good. There was juice in each one. The vegetarian goose was very good too.
author: vernice l.

description:
wahh.. how come no one talks about the fried chicken wings? they're amazing! just as good if not better than san tung. 

xiao long baos are ok, but weak compared to joe's in NYC - skin breaks too easily, not enough soup. the other little buns are really good tho.. they're like.. pan fried version of XLBs w/ bready wrapping instead of dumpling skins.. i forget what they're called..

crappy service, but the food was awesome for the most part
author: m y.

description:
small clean place.  

shanghai dumplings were a solid 3, the wrapper was the right consistency, and they had soup and didn't immediately fall apart.  the chicken wings, have a great sauce, but i feel the wings are coated in a little bit too much batter.  but im not complaining about that, i'm a guy and love fried stuff.  the hand-cut rice cakes were pretty decent, not something you couldn't get elsewhere, but still of decent quality and taste.
author: Jason J.

description:
thanks to my fellow yelpers, i found this place on my way home from the old cliff house. (what a tease... paid $125 to attend a networking function and didn't even get dinner! thank goodness it was expensed)

anyhoo, i was craving some comfort food and a new restaurant to try. drove out looking for the old king of thai right by the entrance to the lincoln golf course and found myself at shanghai house. i ordered the XLBs (of course), lions head meatballs and wor wonton.  by the time i got home and food on the table (about 1 hour later), the XLBs were not as juicy as i had dreamt they would be, but still yummy all the same. the meatballs were interesting... yummy, but interesting (not what i was expecting for a chinese meatball. tasted more like american meatloaf).   the wor won ton was pretty good too. the place was clean and the staff were friendly (wow. very rare for a chinese place, and a gem of a find at that). i'd go back and try it again fresh and hot for the true experience
author: joyce l.

description: Smoked duck...Fish in wine sauce..both well worth the trip.
author: Bleep S.

description: Eat here at your own risk.  I went there three days ago and I'm still suffering from diarrhea.  I've had food poisoning before from hole in the walls, but damn, 3 days?  Food wasn't even that good...
author: Chris O.

description:
its fairly decent food, but service was questionable on my first visit. but thats with all chinese restaurants so i guess that point is null. onto the food though, it tasted pretty standard. but finding the breakfast foods like this is hard in a restaurant, the only place i can find these dishes are in certain 99 ranches and hole in A.J's. so if getting to those are impossible, this will do fine. 

side note : if you want dumplings, find a din tai fung
author: Ray H.

description: I love this place.  I've been a few times with my friends and we've always enjoyed ourselves. This place is amazing for shanghai dumplings and chicken wings.  The place is kind of small and it gets busy, so you might have to wait a bit but its totally worth it.  Definitely recommend this place to anyone looking for good Chinese food.
author: gareth l.

description: Nothing tastes better than hot dumplings on a cold night in SF. Great Xiao Long Baos and nice crispy potstickers and some goose wrapped in tofu skins. what can be better? also ordered the shanghai fried noodles, but the dumplings were better dishes. only downside is that it's a small place and gets a little crowded and and the friendly staff (of 2) is frantically running around refilling tea, getting checks, and dropping off more Xiao Long Baos at different tables. This place reminds me very much of The Noodle Shop near Hillsdale Mall.
author: Douglas F.

description: The food here was flavorless and oddly portioned. My friends and I decided to try this place out and order acouple things to share and to experiment. 1st soy milk shouldn't taste like water. 2nd my shrimp fried rice had exactly 4 shrimp and 95pecent vegi. Every bite i had more vegi than rice. and 3rd noodle soup had sat out to long before bringing it to us which cause the noodles to obsorb all the soup. Overall this place is very nice visually and service is great, but food isn't great unless you like no flavor and unbalance dishes.
author: David M.

description: Their Shanghai dumplings were pretty good here, I don't think they made their own wrappers, but they were still juicy and quite tasty.  Unfortunately, nothing else stood out much, but I'll definitely come here again for more XLBs.
author: Kit E.

description: I thought the place was clean and cozy.  The food was pretty good.  Service was a bit slow since the whole place was run by one woman.  The XLB was awesome but my bro disagrees and thinks the dirtier place down the street is better.  I have yet to try that one out so I'll probably update this review next week when I have a comparison.
author: R A.

description: Great dumplings, although the meat and veggie ones tasted the same. Onion cakes good the noodles good also. Just came back from eating in Hong Kong, my gold standard. Stick with what people recommend.
author: R H.

description:
Excellent dumplings and other dishes, especially the clay pots, vegetarian goose, veggie dumplings, chicken wings (deep fried crispy chicken wings), green beans.  However, there are 2 different menus so make sure you look at both menus.  Also, it helps to look around the room and see what looks good and maybe even ask other customers because the server is not helpful at all.  There are a lot of dishes that I've never heard of on their menu.  When we first came we didn't know what to order and one of the dumplings that we ordered turned out to be just balls of dough that are used in a bau.  

Pluses: Great food other than simply dumplings.  If you want dishes other than dumplings then go here, if you want mainly dumplings and faster service then go to Shanghai Dumpling King down the street.  Pretty cheap (dishes are under $10) and BYOB- you can bring your own wine or beer.  They will open the bottle of wine and give you wine glasses for free.

Cons: Service is very slow and not helpful.  I don't think that she speaks much English or cares about the customers.  If I scored this place on service only, it would get a 1 star, but if you have time to wait, the food is worth it.
author: Melanie G.

description: Love the Shanghai dumplings!  The place is tiny, so there will be a little bit of waiting.  They do share table, but that's how it is with Chinese style eating joint.  The dumplings were juicy and yummy.  Definitely worth the wait.
author: Marilyn Y.

description: I like their salty soy milk.  Their shanghai noodle was decent.  Their gluten puff appetizer was not too good, however I had intended to order another cold platter of gluten and got it mixed it up.  The one I ordered came out warm like the Chinese "zai" with the gluten puff, mushrooms, and stuff and that dish was pricey.  They have a spicy noodle similar to tantan noodle, which was spicier than I like, but my friends liked it.  Service was somewhat slow, but the waitress was very kind to package our food for us.
author: John L.

description:
wow! yuuuuummmy! 
i couldn't give this place 5 stars and here's why- a tsingtao is always fantastic with a chinese meal and there is no liquor license. also, the single waitress for the restaurant was just not nice. i'm well aware of cultural differences, however service is service and she would not smile, was not attentive, paid  no heed to the order of dishes or amount of space available on the table for food. i also noticed it was not just my table (me being black and my cohorts being caucasian)- but she was equal opportunity cold, withdrawn and indifferent to every table- oh, and ps- there is no life or decoration at shanghai house. i think one plant. luckily my 5 companions were worthy of paying attention only to my immediate surroundings...and the food.

the food was phenomenal! the vegetarian goose ( i AM NOT a vegetarian- far from it!) was amazing. a light tofu and mushroom dish with unexpected delectable flavor. the dumplings were pretty good. not the best i ever had, but better than most. the potstickers were...not good potstickers. more like funny shaped shanghais, crispy on the bottom. the chinese eggplant, chicken and shrimp dish left me wanting more and the sesame chicken was perfectly crisp and saturated. the fish and shittake mushrooms (our best guess was some kind of bass) left my mouth humbled, thinking that i had had it better before. all in all, i will definitely go back and enjoy the food immensely.

i should mention that we brought a 6-pack of brew in and there's no corkage (screwage, whatever)- so if you like a cold beer with your chinese cuisine- do it!

and last but not least, the bill for 6 people who lurrve food and have no shame in saying "another one of those, please" was (drum roll please)...75 bones. yes, shanghai house...your cold and aloof waitress, room devoid of personality, spectacular food and more than accommodating prices have won me over...and i'll be back!
author: Missniche W.

description:
Just went there for dinner tonight.  Overall the experience was ok, nothing spectacular.  Got there around 8:30pm on a friday night, so the whole place was packed.  Asked about how long the wait is, so the waitress told me 15 mins.  After 15  mins, got a table...ordered tofu seafood soup, fried chicken wings, veg. goose and the xlb for 2 ppl.  

tofu seafood soup:  ordered reg. size- pretty thick, tasted ok..lots of mix ingredients which i thought was too much

chicken wings:  tasted pretty good, crunchy, however i bite into a piece of wing that didn't taste too fresh

xlb:  tasted ok, not enough soup inside, skin a little thick...very mediocre

veg. goose- crunchy outside, mushrooms inside...pretty good

The food wait was fairly long, tea was not hot enough..probably  might come back again
author: Yvonne M.

description: It's a decent neighborhood place for Shanghai food.  The dumplings are pretty good.  They always walk around with freshly made Chinese donuts which are clearly not healthy but are quite tasty.
author: mardou o.

description: We went to this place yesturday night for Dinner. It was almost 9:30pm, that's when they close but they sat us down. The tables were really nice. looks very expensive. The menu is also big. They gave us two menu. They have Dim Sum not allot but good amount. We had Garlic Chicken which was real good and Mogolian beef which was actuall good and Veggie fried rice which was not oily. Everything was really good. The Place is small but I always like that about a restaurant. The customers were very Diversed which I also like. The waitress was nice. We will deifenlty go back there more often. We will need to get there a bit earlyer so we can look at the menu better. I think this is the best spot we have near our house for chinese food. We ordered 3 items and only spent like 23 bucks which is cool. Yeah!!!!!
author: Ge I.

description: Foods tasted good. Dumplings were pipping hot. They were juicy and the skin were not thick like other places. We ordered Shanghai fried noodles which were not swimming in oil like other places. Finally the red bean paste pancake dessert was delicious. It was made as we were finishing our meal and it was so fresh and crunchy. Prices were reasonable. Service was not bad. What else can you ask for?
author: Sandy N.

description: Just tried for lunch: Had the dumplings, handcut noodles, and vegetarian goose (Layers of dofu wrapped around mushroom filling). Everything was fresh and tasty and not greasy - a big plus to me! Only negative was friendly but slightly slow service - so go for a leisurely, relaxing meal! Good prices but still cash only.
author: Gale H.

description:
You can get a good food here. We'd drive all the way just to have little brunch at Shanghi House. One of us likes a warm glass of sweet soy milk, and the other likes a large bowl of savory soy milk with little pieces of Chinese donut in it. Xiao Long Bao and vegetable buns meet the standard. They serve nice noodles too.

The downside is the uniformly slow, and often unresponsive, service. I think they are under-staffed.
author: Sherwin L.

description:
I was so irritated by this place that I decided to sign up to Yelp and write about it.

First, the food ain't all that.  The only reason we decided to have lunch there was because Dumpling King was closed for vacation.  The xiao long bao was not juicy and whatever juice that was there was lost since the skin was so fragile and ripped as we tried to pick them up.  We tried the chicken wings since everyone else there was having them too.  The skin was yummy but the meat itself had no taste.  The green onion pancakes were dry and doughie - really subpar.

Now for the irritating part... We patiently waited for a table for about 30 minutes.  Once we sat down, we thought, great, food is coming up!!  Well, it took 15 more minutes for us to get some tea!!!!  Another 15 min for the 1st dish to come out, another 15 minutes for the 2nd and so on... we were there for 2 HOURS!!   I had the urge to leave the restaurant 3 different times.  There was a period of more than 15 minutes that the kitchen didn't come out with A SINGLE dish to ANY table...  

I'll never go back.  EVER.
author: Silvia L.

description: They make their shanghai dumpling fresh, unlike some places. Also they make some wonderful dried spicy chicken wings, combo noodle soup, can't forget the tea duck. People have to be patience to have a great meal. This is a family run business. So if you looking for a mom and pops place. This is the one for you.
author: Jason F.

description: Great place to catch lunch. Always ordered the XLB because thats the reason I come. Good portions for two ppl to share. Not too salty, but can add more flavor. Red bean fried pancake is always a delight for something sweet at the end of the meal. The service is quick and a nice clean small place.
author: Cor N.

description: great place for shanghai dumplings it's a small place but very good..plus it's pretty clean sometimes there can be a long wait as well
author: jonathan h.

description: Hey, this is the best dumplings I ever ate!! I also ordered the pan fried-cut noodles and they were awesome,!I also ordered the Tan Tan mein and it was super! I reccomend this place alot!!!
author: Shawn I.

description:
Xiao long bao (shanghai dumplings) were okay.  The skin was on the thick side and there weren't too much filling nor "soup" despite the thick wrapping.  Disappointing....

Do not order the chicken noddle soup with vegetable. The noddles were very soggy--soaked up all the soup and the chicken strips were bland and boiled.   

Service- was extremely SLOW and non-attentive.  We waited over 15 minutes for the soy milk.  When the XLB came, they didn't provide us with any dipping sauce.  We had to ask them for that and for the spoons.  
Also, one of our teacups had dried food stuck on it so we asked for a new one. 

It was just bad all-around. Wouldn't come back again for the food nor the non-existent service.
author: Teresa H.

description:
I would never come back to this place.  It's the worst dining experience ever.   They don't give you a menu right away.  You wait even longer for them to take your order and then waited over 40 minutes for the food.  20 minutes for my soy milk which I couldn't even drink nor pick up since it was so darn hot!  The Xiao Long Baos (XLBs) are a disappointment.  They have thicker than normal skin so you figure you'd get some decent "soup'--wrong!  Hardly anything in there.

Oh, bring enough change with you because you have to wait forever for them to give your change back.  Maybe they do that so that you get fed up waiting for the change so you'd leave and give them a big fat tip.

If you want xiao long boas--just walk up a few blocks to Shanghai Dumpling King.  The XLBs are better there.  They have thinner skin and wow soup inside!
author: Jen S.

description:
update:  7/16/07
---
had the classic shanghai "yan du xian" in a stone pot today, and it was awesome.  The broth was white and rich (way better than a tonkotsu broth because of the smokey ham flavor), chinese style ham/cured pork, tofu skin rolled and tied in knots to soak up the broth, and freshly boiled bamboo shoots (definitely not canned), made for a perfect classic soup.  Could have used a vegetable like qing gang cai though, but ah well.

The vegetarian goose was AWESOME.  It's basically a roll of tofu skin (read:  many layers), with chinese mushrooms inside (shiitake I believe), fried, and then cut up so it kinda looks like goose breast meat.  flavor and texture were awesome (except I hate mushrooms, so I picked those out).

The loufa melon with gluten puffs was good--would have been better if they peeled all the skin off the melon to remove the bitterness, but overall it was stir-fried right.  

xiaolongbao has dropped to B-/C+ grade.  They were stuck to the basket, and all of them were popped.  No soup.  Skin was thick, and overall they seemed overcooked.

original review:  4/16/07
---
FINALLY a passable shanghai restaurant in the city.  FINALLY.
Shanghai dumpling king:  mediocre, heavy handed crap.
Old shanghai:  decent food, but not shanghai food.
shanghai noodle house:  decent, but not made with the craftsmanship I'm looking for.

The xiao long bao were mediocre--B grade.  Some soup, and the skin thickness varied from passably thin to way too thick.  Also, the lack of napa cabbage under the dumplings let the dumplings pop because they stuck to the basket.

But the stir fried food themselves... were actually decent.  Only had 3 dishes so far, but they were:
-spinach with tofu "bai ye", like tofu skin but a little thicker with a slightly rougher texture.  THis was stir fried beautifully, and the spinach was nice and clean--no sand.  The chicken broth added just enough flavor, soaked up by the bai ye.

-sweet and sour ribs.  ALMOST perfect.  These were black like they should have been, but weren't sour enough to match the sweetness.  Also the ribs were not fried quiet enough--the ribs weren't falling off the bone, and the bones were not edible.  BUT, they were still tasty, using the right black (zhen jiang) vinegar.  We asked for more vinegar and poured it on top, and then it was sour enough.

-wine sauce fish.  ALMOST perfect.  A little too salty, and needed to be a little bit sweeter.  But otherwise, it was stir fried perfectly, and the black wood ear fungus was very tender and just right.
-salted mustard green (aka snow cabbage, xue cai), edamame (mao dou), pork strand (rou si)  knife-shaved soup noodles (dao xiao tang mian).  On Ed's recommendation, we had to get these knife shaved noodles.  The noodles themselves were the perfect texture and consistency--nice and chewy--though the length and thickness of the noodle could have been better (it's tough to control, and takes a lot of skill to make right, because you shave the noodles directly off of a lump of dough, into the boiling water).  The soup however... had soy sauce in it?!  and was too salty with not enough flavor.  not the tasty, clean, chicken-pork white broth I'm used to for salted mustard green soup noodles.  Still, it was good.  These are all shanghai classic dishes by the way, as we were deliberately testing the chef.

For dessert, they had fermented rice with mochi rice soup balls (filled with sesame paste).  This is a shanghai classic dessert.  The chef added osmanthus flower, as he's supposed to, and just the right amount.  It totally hit the spot.  They also have an "eight treasure rice" (ba bao fan), which is sticky rice (aka sweet rice, mochi rice, or glutinous rice) steamed with 8 "treasures" including lotus seeds, red beans, etc, and honey on top.  But we'll have to order it next time.

with the bill, they brought us half an orange, cut up--as they do in many true chinese restaurants.  no lame-ass fortune cookies here.

I loved it!  I've been forced to lower my shanghai food standards ever since I've come to the city, and this place finally hit the spot.  It's nowhere near best in the bay, but finally, there's a passable shanghai place in the city!

(the large bowl of knife-shaved noodles.. were only 5.75 ea before tax and tip.... my people rule)
author: Fong L.

description: Okay. The food isn't bad. But do not EVEN try to call in an order for takeout. Check this out...they do NOT answer the phone half the time (yes I have double checked to make sure I have the correct listing). Do they think they have so much business inside that they do not need to answer the phone for takeout orders? I'm sorry, this is either arrogant and rude, bad business, or just plain ignorance. There are several other Chinese restaurants in the area that are glad to answer the phone for takeout customers.
author: A R.

description: I'm so hard pressed to find a truly good Shanghainese place that I'm tempted to give this place 2 stars only.  The shanghai dumplings are a 5 out of 10.  Call me a shanghainese food snob but I've tasted dumplings infinitely better than these.  Tough skin on the top?  Come on.
