However, given that there's not too many super delicious perfectly done dumplings near by, I'm happy it's decent & was still able to enjoy the meal.  Expect a wait, though!
author: m c.

description: My favorite Shanghainese restaurant in the city.  My family and I have been going there at least once every three months, for the past two years.  Everything is SO tasty and consistent.  It is a family-run restaurant, the wife is in the front of the house and the husband is the chef.  I think the prices are reasonable and they only accept cash.  I honestly don't have anything bad to say about the food.  You can also BYOB.  LOVE IT.
author: Monique C.

description: Just came here today with my friend to try this place out . The Shanghai dumplings came in very tiny morsels . They were ehh .. alright , but the dumplings didn't really have much soup in them . Some had a little in them while some didn't have any in them at all . The steamed pork dumplings were okay as well . Shanghai noodles were alright but didn't taste like anything special . The noodles tasted like they were overcooked . The onion pancake was really good though . In fact , I'm munching on some right now . The soy milk was good too but it's really hot so be sure to be careful drinking it ! Service-wise , the waitress barely ever makes any eye contact with the customers so it's really hard to get her attention . But other than that , this place really isn't that bad . Cheap , quick & acceptable Shanghainese food . Only bad things about this place is that it's kind of small and there's no source of entertainment whatsoever . And of course , the service could improve .
author: Eileen L.

description: I went here with my cousin last Saturday. The Shanghai dumplings were really good. We were able to get all these bite sized dumplings off the steamer without breakage. Each bite was perfectly juicy and the wrapper was the perfect thickness. I would definitely go back just for that. We also tried the onion pancakes and it was good too. We also got the special rice cake dish. I thought this was okay. We had way too much food for the two of us. We also shared a cup of the sweet soy milk warm. It was the best I've personally had. It was lite but very flavorful. The staff was also friendly. They were very busy. The place isn't that big.
author: S N.

description: Food generally very good.  But go for the dry fried fish (or chicken).  That's the star!!
author: Ritch G.

description: What surprises me about this place is that despite the fact that I thought we had over ordered, we somehow managed to finish everything. So from start to finish, we had the green onion pancakes, dry fried chicken wings, pork and preserved green hand cut noodle soup, lion's head meatballs (not really a lion's head people), XLB, and soy bean milk. I'm pretty sure I'm missing something since I counted 7 things on the check but for the life of me can't remember. Everything we had was delicious - my favorites being the lion's head meat ball, hand cut noodle soup (mostly because of the noodles - I think I've had the beef noodle soup and I think I liked it more), and the dry fried chicken wings. Note: Everything else was good, just picking my favorites. The chicken wings actually have a leg up on Santung and are spicier/crispier. The only thing with the wings is that they are sweet, but I have a feeling if you like Santung you won't mind this one too. Just working on watching the sugar + calories, so that made me a bit sad... had to restrain myself from eating the whole thing so I wouldn't have a heart attack.
author: Jeannette L.

description: Dumplings were tasty, hot soy milk was perfectly sweetened, salty soy milk was oddly palatable, and the hand cut noodles were decent but not wow.  The best part of the entire meal was our timing.  My party of 6 showed up right before the crowd and scored a table without having to wait.  Beware of the MSG effect post-meal.  I seriously downed a couple glasses of water to wash it away!
author: sasaw A.

description: This is the best Chinese food I have ever eaten. It is fresh and flavorful and the textures are bang on. If you want greasy, heavy Chinese, don't come here. I have brought many different people here and they always love it. Faves include potstickers, vegetarian goose, kung pao prawns and anything else we ever order. This isnt the place to go for proper, timely service and they don't serve alcohol but you can bring your own! I often bring my own wine and glasses!! No Corkage fee... and again, the food rocks. It's like cornstarch never existed and the only types of vegetables were fresh...
author: let's c.

description: In terms of the environment, it's cleaner and warmer than Shanghai Dumpling King. Foodwise, the bitter melon soup and handcut noodles are fantastic, but the xiaolongbao are subpar. And it doesn't have the lion's head.
author: A. T.

description: My first few times here were with some friends and at the time, I remember the food being really good (especially the xiao long baos).  The xiao long baos were soupy and normal size.  Unfortunately, the quality has since headed for a down turn.  I'm not sure if it was because we went a little later at around 8:30PM and possibly they were running low on the meat filling.  The dumplings I had yesterday were tiny and since there was little meat it reminded me of the cheap wontons that you get at the crappy Americanized Chinese restaurants were it is mainly the dough wrapper.  Also, due to the small amount of meat in the dumpling there was little soup since it probably got absorbed into the wrapper.   In addition, to the dumplings we also ordered string beans, a pickled vegetable casserole with fish and the Shanghainese vegetable rice.  The rice was very bland, so I decided to bring it home to add some dried scallop or bacon flavor into it.   The casserole was ok, but I've had better down in south bay.  Overall, I'll probably end up coming  back with friends, but I'll insist that we come earlier in the day.  (Hopefully, there'll be more meat filling then.)
author: Sharon W.

description: I know people rave about the "xiao long bao" but there are a few places in San Francisco you can get similiar -- not the least is another Shanghai place just a few blocks from this on Balboa.  In my opinion, what makes this place stand out is the Knife cut noodles.  I don't know of another place in San Francisco offering this.  The only place I've had this is in Foster City.
author: Amy V.
